Impressive and accessible. We visited the Blue mosque the first evening and were drawn to the night lighting and happy crowds. The next day, we went back to enter the central area that had been closed the night before for prayers. Posters along the outer court wall explain much about the structure and Islam. The architecture is more impressive than beautiful

Great Site In A Nice Area. The Suleymaniye Mosque is worth a visit when staying in the historic section of Istanbul. It's a massive site with gardens and an old graveyard. The Grand Bazaar is within walking distance and there are a number of cafes and small merchant shops nearby.
Suleymaniye Mosque. Many say it is the most impressive mosque. It is a steep walk up from the water and just as we arrived it was closed for prayers. It is great from the outside. Plan carefully.
Amazing place. A must see while in Istanbul. Wonderful Ottoman history and culture. Be sure you have a guide that knows the interesting stories.

Simply impressive. Ok, so like many things in Istanbul it's a little hard to find, but worth making the effort. It lacks the splendour of churches in Rome or Venice, but actually is the more impressive for it. An amazing building, beautifully decorated without being flash. It feels like what religion should be about. Also very welcoming and no charge or pressure to donate.
Walking round old city. Really interesting we hired a guide to take us round the old city much better than reading guide book tells you all the things that aren't in books

MOST BEAUTIFUL MOSQUE. This is one of the best mosque in Istanbul. The echo is wonderful. It is said that the architect Sinan who built the mosque used water pipe to find the accurate echo. It is a must see mosque in Istanbul.
Beautiful. Some say that once you see one mosque, you've seen them all. But this is absolutely gorgeous. It's a must see in Istanbul!!

Must do!. I liked this mosque a bit more than the blue mosque! Less crowds/tourists. More intimate and even more beautiful. I recommend visiting this mosque to get the actual, intimate experience of history.

Lovely grounds.. This mosque near the Grand Bazaar has lovely open grounds and a small park situated on the top of a hill, making it very pleasant after time in the busy streets below. The mosque itself is nice but unexciting.
Charming mosque. It is a really nice mosque without the crowd. The work on the walls are really nice and the views from the grounds are beautiful
Incredible & unforgettable mosque!. Something that making you be amazed for long time! It's such a powerful mosque with full of history inside!

My first service. We got there just before the sermon started. Although we didn't understand the language or practice this faith, we stayed through the service. I don't know if it was the voice of the orator or the structure of the building but we were so relaxed by the time we left. It was a very nice, different experience. The decoration is beautiful and a lot less tourists than when we were at the Blue Mosque.

Suleymaniye of History. It's amazing attraction, so much historical and you can feel all of those history once you find yourself inside. It's one of those attractions i will certnaly come back to see again.
The Most Amazing Mosque. I loved this mosque! Such a spiritual feeling and so beautiful! Istanbul has many Mosques that you should visit...and this is definitely one of them!

Charming Mosque without the Crowds. This is a quite little mosque in Istanbul. Though it is as big as Blue Mosque the crowds here are less. The Architecture is amazing and surrounding grounds are beautiful. It is a very serene place to spend time away from bustle of the city and the tourists.

Magnificent Suleymaniye Mosque. One can feel the imperial effect of this very special mosque...It took 7 years to finish this great building between 1551 and 1558. The architect was the great architect Sinan and he built this mosque by the orders of the emperor : The Magnificent Suleyman. By looking from outside, you can see the grandeur of the building and when you enter inside you can feel that it's a real piece of art and great wit. There's not even a crack at the building though Istanbul had more than 100 earthquakes since the 16th century and even this proves the professionalism and uniqueness of architect Sinan.Inside the mosque, it's awesome with all the attention to details...Architect Sinan was a genius, he built inside the mosque so that the air current can lead the lampblack of 275 oil lamps lighting inside, towards the lampblack room over the entrance and the collected material could be used in making ink...Please note that it's just an example of architect Sinan's master builder period before his expert builder era!Suleymaniye Mosque is a must see and visit piece of great art of Istanbul.

Lovely, calming, uncrowded - perfection. The opposite of Agia Sofiya or Blue Mosque-- few people, calm, quiet, with enclosed cemetery and tomb site. The latter was especially appealing: cal and quiet, peaceful and serene. The interior of the mosque is lovely with great ceiling and tiles, and no crowds!

Not as famous as the blue mosque, but even more impressive. Any tourist that visiting the amazing Istanbul is thinking when to visit Aya Sofia and the Blue Mosque, two amazing sites. To me, as a big fan of the ottoman history, the visit in the Suleymaniye Mosque was one of the picks of my visit to Istanbul.Located in Fatih ditrict, this amazing building that was built in the 16 century is the embodiment of the ottoman architecture as it was designed and planned by Sinan.The Yard and the cementery is well worth a visit by themself as they are well kept and cleaned.You should probably have to take a special ride to this area cause it is not in the touristic area - don't miss it.

More peaceful than the Blue Mosque. Lovelier than the Blue Mosque because of its simplicity and fewer crowds. A brief stop in our busy schedule but well worth it. As a given, visitors can't go in during prayer times, but there are plenty of opportunities.In a city with so many mosques, do not miss this one.

Simply love this place. If in Istanbul, you must not miss this mosque! I know it is difficult for me to be 100% objective because I love this city with all good and bad in it, but trust me on this. Beauty made of simplicity. On top of it you can feel the calm coming through your body and your mind,.... And, if you know bit of a history of this place than you can seize the whole meaning in its beauty. Do not miss the Turkish tea in one of the tea-houses around it.

Incredible interior with magnificent dome. While this masque is not as beautiful inside as the Blue Mosque, it is even more impressive, architecturally. Well worth spending some time inside this beautiful space.

Another beautiful mosque.. This lovely mosque is just off the beaten path enough to discourage hoards of tourists. It is large and extremely beautiful. We walked up the hill to the mosque, through wonderful neighbourhoods full of the hustle and bustle of everyday life in the city. Just remember to dress respectfully and keep your voice down in the mosque.

Fascinating. Amazing building. Well worth a visit. I find it hard to accept that it was built in the 1500s. Ensure that you avoid prayer times as it is closed to the public then, and please show respect and cover shoulders etc when going in.

Incredible photo ops and views. Our focus was on the Blue Mosque, and we were not planning on spending much time on Suleymaniye Mosque due to time constraints. We decided to walk through the University of Istanbul and found ourselves at the Mosque, which is adjacent to the campus. Incredible photo opportunity. Very interesting. If you walk from the campus to the location you come from a higher elevation and views of the mosque, the Bosphorus Straight, and greater Istanbul. Well worth the time.

Beautiful Mosque - Little tourist. Take a tram up to visit Suleyman Mosque (or better, have lunch in this area – there is a university so good cheap options). This mosque is also beautiful and less busy than the Blue Mosque. On the way take to the mosque take a looks at Valens Aquaduct. At the mosque:• Turbes (tombes)• Kulliye (mosque complex)• View from terraceWalk to the Rustem Pasa Mosque, beautiful blue tiles. This is a small mosque, but worthwile, also not many tourist. Combine with spice market. Easy to miss because it’s not at street level. Make sure you bring some plastic shoe bags from another more touristy mosque, as you’ll not find them here. If you leave your shoes outside they may disappear (that’s what our guide told us).

Well worth a visit. The sheer scale of this mosque is impressive and has to be seen - photographs do not do it justice. If you are female, take something to cover your head if you want to go in. Some headscarfs are provided for visitors but may not always be available at busy times.
monumental. I liked everything in Istanbul, city, people, atractions, food etc. Its fun for everybody here, for less or more money...

Beautiful Mosque. It is not as popular as the Blue Mosque and its location is also not near the toursit areas. If you walk from Grand Bazaar, it's not that far but because of its location on top of a hill, it can be quite tiring. Having said that, the mosque is beautiful in architecture and decorations. One of the earliest mosques built in Istanbul. Looks grand from a distance, and even grander when your there. Dont miss it if you have time.

Peaceful Perfection. I was fortunate enough to spend almost 4 months in Istanbul. My only regret in that time was not visiting this mosque sooner. Istanbul is an extremely busy and populous city, but Suleymaniye Mosque was one place that provides quiet and peaceful pleasure.Walking up from the Spice Market looks further than it is. Be sure to spend time inside and outside the mosque as they truly compliment one another. I would certainly recommend this mosque over Blue Mosque (which is also spectacularly beautiful, but incredibly touristy). Also, visit the surrounding neighbourhood and try to eat at one of the delicious local establishments to meet some friendly locals and support their community. Enjoy!
it is a must. Brilliant! A place that state the great age of Suleiman and its exquisite taste. Nice and simple colours.

Do not miss. I loved this mosque. In fact it was my favorite place in Istanbul. Go in between prayers, bring a scarf (ladies), socks, cover legs and arms and enjoy the interior. Afterwards eat at Kurucu Ali Baba Kanaat Lokatansi across from the mosque.
Quite an enchanting history. I liked everything about this lovely place! There was truly nothing t o dislike. This is a must-see in your visit of Istanbul.
Great Historical Place. If you want to see old Istanbul in Ottomans time, I recommend to visit this place especially the Sinan architect Hamam

Excellent, but not as much for the interior. This isn't super central--a 10 minute, dull walk from the bazaar--so it has far fewer tourists than the Blue Mosque. There was no line when I went, while the line at the Blue Mosque had stretched 200 meters long (waiting for it to reopen after afternoon prayers). The interior space is graceful and huge, but other than sitting and admiring it there isn't much to do, unless you read Arabic script that lines the walls. Remove your shoes, and sit behind the barriers, people watching a bit (e.g., non-Muslim tourists and Muslim women who can only pray from the back). The exterior offers more to enjoy and learn from. There are tombs, including Sinan's, and you also get a great sense of how Islam provides a full social system, with the equivalent of a modern day soup kitchen for the poor (now a restaurant) and school. The mosque has very nice grounds: green grass, great courtyard, all more pleasant than the Blue Mosque. Across the street, there is a long row of restaurants that are less touristy, specializing in Turkish beans. But don't miss the below-ground courtyard outside the southwest corner of the Mosque--great atmosphere. And the bathrooms on the grounds of the mosque are clean and free (unlike the Blue Mosque, for which you have to pay a lira). Of course, by night, you can see the mosque beautifully illuminated, but I don't care for this neighborhood at night--it seems that you have to walk some fairly quiet and in some cases dodgy, barren streets to get to and from here, especially if you're going back toward the Golden Horn / Galata bridge neighborhoods. All told, this is a nice sight to see, but I can't see how it is currently the #2 rated attraction on TripAdviser. It should be more like your #6 to #8-ranked attraction.

My favourite mosque. Not too far from the Grand Bazaar this mosque does not get nearly as much traffic as the blue mosque which is a good thing.Much more peaceful inside obviously with less people around and just outside there are restaurants where you can sit outside and relax before heading back to the madness of the bazaars

Suleymaniye. Magnificent tombs of Sultan and his family. Check out Sinan's (architect) tomb too. Peaceful gardens and surrounds. Make sure you arrive when the mosque is not closed for services - particularly on a Friday which is the weekly prayer day- check prayer times.

Should to visit. Suleymaniye Mosqdue is on the hill if you walk from emininu should walk around 15-20 mins but on the way to mosque you can shopping along the street because it's wholesale market. The decoration of mosque is very nice with stained glass and and surrounding is green including you can visit tomb of sultan behind the mosque (tomb close at 5pm)

Peaceful and tranquil. It's located away from the main sights in Sultanahmet, yet is near to the Grand Bazaar and can be covered as part of a walking tour. We arrived in the afternoon and found this to be a tranquil little haven far, far from the crazy crowds we encountered all day. We just sat and rested, in quiet admiration of Mimar Sinan's majestic masterpiece. Worth a visit.

Sad to see disrespect.. Sad to see disrespect. history and culture was a highlight of a trip to Instanbul, but I was so very disappointed by the "tourists" who obviously had this on their bucket list, and disrespected the request for silence and observance of religious protocol.

Much peaceful compared to blue mosque. you will avoid the usual tourist traps as it is in a quiet neighborhood. From the view point of the mosque at the back side you can see roof top cafes. We went to the mimar sinan cafe and its entrance is close to the grave of Mimam Sinan. This cafe is mostly visited by students of Istanbul Uni, Menu is all in Turkish but try to find an english speaking waiter and they can help. Prices are much cheaper. Views from the roof top are amazing and you actually get a flavour of the local culture as the place is full of locals.Best find our stay in Istanbul.
impressive. Wonderful welcoming atmosphere, even for non-moslem tourists; beautiful tiles and so obviously full of living faith
Incredible Mosk. Take time to go and see this mosk, it's beautiful and not busy at all. Near the Bazar.It's really worth it.

Impressive, even under restoration. This huge and historic mosque is impressive even though a good part of it was blocked off for restorations when I visited (May 2014). It sits on the crown of a hill in Old Stanbul, commanding the skyline.

Probably the best in Istanbul. The mosque is situated in a very special places surrounded by green. Inside is really stunning, in particular for its ceilings. Enjoy the visit and don't miss all the surroundings. Good to be coupled with a visit of the Gran Bazar, which is 10 minutes far by walking. Suggested for a 30 minutes visit.
Splendid. This place really enthraled us! It is a necessary experience to live! That makes you feel very different emotions!

Beautiful Mosque. If you walk north through the Grand Bazaar then past the university grounds on you left you will come to the mosque. Many less visitors than the Blue Mosque but I found it visually more stunning and entry is a much more relaxed process. There is some building refurbishment at the back of the complex but it still has a really good view over Galata Bridge and the Bosphorous.

A True Delight. As part of a walking tour we were privileged to also enjoy this mosque. It is warm and friendly - welcomes all with open arms. Very tasteful in it's detail supporting the Muslim religion. Was an ex expected delight - all should try to take it in as part of their visit.
Beautiful. Definitely not to be missed, this place is huge and well worth spending a few minutes to take it in close up.

Beautiful, so worth a visit.. Its a bit of a trek to get here from the Grand Bazaar, we got lost in the many back streets but so well worth it when we arrived. It's much less showy than others, and also off the usual tourist route. Because of this it's so calm and peaceful and beautiful inside, and, with almost no tourists, just locals coming to pray, it has a wonderful atmosphere. Some renovation is going on in the grounds, limiting what you are able to see, but even so there are some wonderful buildings in the grounds and locality and the outside of the mosque is spectactular. There are fabulous views from the grounds over the city and Bosphorus.Just outside there are a couple of cafes with rooftop terraces giving wonderful views back to the mosque and surrounding areas.Do not miss seeing this beautiful place.

Worth a visit. This is a lovely working mosque that is a it away from the main tourist attractions but worth the walk. It is smaller than the blue mosque and thus you get a more authentic feel. Just make sure you are dressed appropriately as they don't supply clothes like the blue mosque does

Favortite Mosque of the Trip. Cinan was amazing! His design was so forward and thoughtful that even a novice like me could appreciate how brilliant his work was. It was neat to see his tomb just outside of the mosque walls to the north.

Süleymaniye Mosque's Magnificent Dome. Süleymaniye Mosque is the largest in Istanbul and one of the must-see sights of Istanbul. The large dome is supported by half domes. Visit this place after Ayasofya so you can compare the domes. This dome was based on the dome of the Byzantine Ayasofya. For more photos and explanation see http://terraencounters.blogspot.com/2014/05/day-4-pm-suleymaniye-mosque.html
Grand structure. Huge mosque....worth a few minutes to stop in and see the historic building. Some knowledge of the history will help here..

Well worth the visit. While the mosque is generally not included in brief tours, this was one of highlights of our trip to Istanbul. It is huge, graceful and simple in design, and not overrun with tourists,
Go see. Lovely visit. Wear clothes suitable for a mosque otherwise you can borrow garments. Very worthwhile.

Big mosque, very beautifull inside.. no shoes. as most mosques you cant wear shoes inside, the mosque itself is beautiful and tranquil, just remember you are in a private place of worship and try and stay quiet, women aren't allowed in front of the gated area so back of the bus ladies..

Giant Mosque. This mosque was a great visit and an educational experience as long as your tour guide knew his/her stuff. Ours did have a wealth of knowledge and spoke clearly for easy understanding. I definitely enjoyed the experience!
another mosque. more of the same, but if you must visit a mosque, istanbul is the place to do it, and this is the best example to choose. it is one of the best reasons to visit istanbul

A place of great beauty and serenity.. During our stay in Istanbul, the Blue Mosque became a familiar landmark. It was very close to our hotel, and each morning and evening it would dominate our view as we sat on the balcony. Beautiful, inspiring and serene, this is a place I will never forget.

big mosque. -the mosque is really nice and really big.
- You have to take the stairs to enter the mosque.
- u can have a good view for golden horn.
- some renovation works are taking place around the mosque complex.
- U have to walk up hill to reach the mosque.

Wonderful place. As a non Muslim visitor You probably can not admire the religious significance of the place like Suleymaniye Mosque, but You can always admire the architecture, the skill and the craftsmanship of the builders.
Also being in the "presence" of one of the most significant leaders in the history of the region, Suleiman the Magnificent, makes You feel humble!

Magnificent monument. Many visitors like Blue Mosque but Süleymaniye Mosque is far superior to Blue Mosque in terms of its architecture and design. A masterpiece of Sinan which is a must to visit in Istanbul.

Fantastic. Excellent building and well worthwhile a visit.
Istanbul such a fantastic vibrant city. Staying in old city nearby and also walked to Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque etc

Beautiful. The grounds, the inside of the mosque and everything about its appearance is awe inspiring. I think this was my favourite mosque of all that I visited in Istanbul. It was a bit of a walk getting here, but it was definitely worth it. A must visit when in Istanbul!
Must-see. A short walk through the Grand Bazaar and up the hill and you are in this amazing place, so peaceful, wonderful classic architecture and not to be missed.

Worth to see. This Mimar Sinan's masterpiece is located at a place a little bit far from Sultanahmet (the center of sight-seeing spots) and there is not so foreign tourist visiting there. But, I think this mopsque is more worth to see because the old buildings attached to it as school, hospital, soup kitchen and so on. One of them was restored into a restaurant.

Very beautiful. Very beautiful, peaceful, and recently renovated (if I'm not mistaken). The surrounding area is also very nice (there are tombs of Sinan and several Sultans, too). I prefer this mosque to the Blue Mosque.The interior is also very beautiful, with relatively brighter color palette compared to the Blue Mosque. As I prayed there, I find the atmosphere very calming, again compared to the Blue Mosque. Even though you are not going to pray in the mosque, I still think it's worth the walk.Definitely a must visit.
a must see when in Istanbul. As in all active mosques, non-members are restricted to a small part. Still able to appreciate its beauty.

Don't miss it. We knew about the Hagia Sophia and the Blue (Sultan Ahmet) Mosque, and we loved seeing them, but the Suleyaniye Mosque was an unexpected treat. The decoration is not as elaborate as that in the Blue Mosque, but it has an exquisite simplicity. We visited (and loved) many mosques, but we would put this one on the short list of must sees.
very nice. extreamly beutifull and peasfull. be aware that women must cover head arms and legs. legings ar also not aloud. also it can smell a little like feed in there.

Beautiful. It is about half an hour walk from Topkapi Palace. The place around the mosque is quiet and there are not as many tourists as at the Blue Mosque. I visited on a Sunday and many local families were there. A bride was showing off her white wedding dress, a group of turkish ladies were having a fresh grapefruit juice... The mosque is just beautiful, the carpet is a bit different, the atmosphere is relaxing. I think it is absolutely great that non-muslims can visit every mosque in Istanbul.

Blue Mosque. After visiting the 'Grand Mosque' in Abu Dhabi, this mosque is nice but not as stunning. If you have seen the Grand Mosque I would not bother visiting the Blue Mosque, good news, there was no entry fee.
A gem. While the Blue Mosque is wonderful, I found this one much more moving in its beautiful simplicity. It was designed by the greatest Ottoman architect.

The beauty and the atmosphere must be experienced. The Suleymaniye Mosque dominates the city skyline when observed from much of the Bosphorus. It is easy to run out of superlatives when reviewing all the historic attractions of Istanbul - and it would be possible to run of them on this one alone. It occupies a significant amount of ground space - incorporating not only the Mosque and its courtyard but also a school and two mausoleums - the tombs of Sultan Suleiman I and his wife Roxelana; both significant historical figures. The beauty and the atmosphere of Suleymaniye Mosque must be experienced. Being a little removed from Sultanahmet Square it is less thronged and more peaceful. It is a beautiful, serene and deeply spiritual place. The architecture is at once both impressive and sublime, every detail delicately woven together to create a place of awe and beauty. Spend some time soaking up the atmosphere and allow yourself experience this wonderful place. It is an active Mosque so be aware of prayer times, particularly on a Friday as there will be - understandably - restrictions on your visit. It is within ten minutes walking distance of the Grand Bazaar - come out from the opposite side to the metro station end; we found it very easily with a simple map as a guide. Indeed the area surrounding it is very historic and we found some good shopping too. A definite attraction to visit.
lovely. We went on a Friday and had to wait to get in as that day is their Sabbath.It is very beautiful inside.
Huge mosque. Just see and feel it.It has unique features . Enjoy having tea around.Also surrounded histrocal areas

Not as blue, but much quieter. This mosque is within easy walking distance of the grand bazaar but it doesn't attract the crowds that the blue mosque does. It is very large and very beautiful so is well wortha visit if you are in the area and are not all mosqued out.
Very spiritual place. Even though its located out of the city centre I would suggest to visit this mosque for everyone seeking calm and beautiful place in rush city.
Serene. This mosque is beautiful - far more serene than the blue mosque (which is swarming with people). Worth the walk.
beautiful. not so many tourists in it. it is the second largest mosque in Istanbul. beautifully designed and well kept. there is a nice view from there, and also an interesting tombs next to it.

Better than the Blue. I thought this mosque was much more beautiful and interesting than the Blue Mosque -- and there were no lines. Also, the Suleymaniye Hamami is right beside the mosque. Great Turkish bath that only takes couples or families.
Istanbul May 2014. Beaurtiful mosque. More light and brighter than Blue Mosque (which was fantastic also). Architecture is amazing. I am not religious but found the atmosphere very soothing.
Breathtakingly beautiful. Be prepared to queue for ages, or pay someone to take you in and tell you all about it. It is certainly one of those buildings you really have to see.
Amazing. My first sight of the mosque was very emotional, and I said my prayers,I just sat inside airing the beauty surrounding me. Unbelievable.

A must see. Even though it was my third time in Istanbul, I have never visited Suleymaniye before. Thinking it would be no different than other beautiful mosques I visited, especially because I had to climb a million stairs to get there, I could not have been more wrong!!! It is one of the most beautiful sights I have seen. Huge, spacious, with breath taking architecture, and a scent of rosewater, people lining for prayer and a small exhibition of gorgeous paintings with Islamic motives, it left such a strong impression. I also witnessed two local weddings!!!After I spent almost and hour walking around and taking pictures, I crossed the tiny pedestrian road and rested at one of the cafes, looking directly at this beautiful master piece of Mimar Sinan (he's tomb is also nearby). Also, I got the best souvenirs from there, jewelery that resembles bracelets, earrings and rings that Hurem wore:-)))) I will definitely return to explore more!

Beautiful, less touristy. After tourist visiting hours are over, that is really the ideal time to visit this mosque. We happened to stumble across it after busy hours were over while exploring on our first day in Istanbul on our own and were thankful we did! The interior is just as magnificent and majestic as any of the more popular mosque. We felt the added bonus was that it was used by locals and still functioned as a mosque should rather than be simply reduced to a tourist attraction.

Stunning. Fascinating to learn about the architect & the history, and how it was built to withstand earthquakes. Makes me want to learn more about so many aspects of the culture, and the sultan that had the mosque built!

peaceful. This mosque was much more peaceful and interesting than the Blue Mosque in my opinion. There are beautiful views over the river. Go upstairs to look around too. Set in a nice area near the university and with cafes all around.
Totally amazed. Not so crowded and amazing. Go there early before tours buses arrive. Spend some time in the back contemplating the sea.

A must for all visitors. Visited this incredible structure during my first trip to Istanbul, a must for all visitors...
It is quite large and although not all areas were open to the public, there is a lot to see. This impressive Mosque has been featured in many movies.

An example of Turkish architecture. An amazing complex and especially the mosque that was erected in honour of Suleiman the Magnificent. Make sure to get there before prayer times to be able to have a nice look inside the building. Around the complex there are few interesting things one might wanna see including the university of Istanbul that overlooks it and plenty of little restaurants if you get hungry after your tour.
Beautiful. Worth a visit as it is just as beautiful as the Blue a Mosque. Go upstairs to check out the Viking graffiti on the perspex covered handrail and the beautiful mosaics.
Better choice than Blue Mosque. Very beautiful, impressive and not crowded compared with the regular attractions like the Blue Mosque. From the garden you have a great view over the Bosforus.
Magnificent. I liked this mosque by MIMAR SINAN more than Blue Mosque. It is not as popular as Blue Mosque but I recommend it.

Outstanding. Unfortunately we couldn't see the interior as it was prayer time but the exterior is beautiful as is the view down to the Golden Horn and the graveyard. The peace and tranquility was in real contrast to the Blue Mosque. Make the effort to get here.

Among the best of the Large Mosques. Personally, I prefer the more authentic small Mosques for their authenticity and the experience that can be had by actually participating in the ritual instead of observing. Having that been said, the Blue Mosque, New Mosque and Suleymaniye Mosque are a must to visit and are all extraordinary to view up close from the outside. Suleymaniye is a little further away but no less spectacular from my point of view, I highly recommend it.

See the mosque, the grave yard and the tea garden. Tombs are closed.. We walked to this mosque from the Grand Bazaar : this is wear the Turkish people shop and eat. The mosque itself is very impressive as is the grave yard. Unfortunately the tombs of Sultan Suleymani and his mistress Roxelana were closed when we visited. The tea garden, called Lale Bahcesi, is outside the mosque and realy nice to have a cup of Turkish tea.

Masterpiece Off The Beaten Track. Not too far from the Great Bazar. But what a contrast! Outstanding architecture which one can enjoy "undisturbed" because there are so few tourists in comparison to the Bazar and the Blue Mosque for example.Afterwards you can have a drink in one of the rooftop cafes giving you the best view over Istanbul.
Great Mosque !. It is the best we have ever seen with architecture and stories ! You must see this mosque if you are in Istanbul and get more information about Sinan !
Better than the Blue Mosque!. Beautiful building, especially the grounds around it and a lot quieter than the Blue Mosque. Make sure you visit the tombs of the sultans while you're here.

Beautiful view into history. It seems a lot of people confuse this with the Blue Mosque in their reviews. Don't be confused, this is a very beautiful and large mosque further north along the Golden Horn.The site is fantastic and seemingly a lot less busy than the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sofia and that really busy tourist section. The building is beautiful and ornate and not unlike the Blue Mosque however, being less busy made it a more enjoyable experience.The cemetery is supposed to be open to visit but I have been by it several times and its always closed with no real explanation. I see this has been an issue for many people based on a variety of reviews on numerous sites.My comment for all religious sites is to do some research ahead of time and know the customs and some basics of the religion as that will really help understand the site.

Worth seeing. Not much to say that hasn't been said before, definately a must-see. It's quiet, huge and specacular. Be sure to respect the premises and if you wish to enter the mosque, wear at least a scarf over your head (for women) and be prepared to take your shoes off. Walk around it as well, you get to see the mausolium through the walls.Respect the times of prayer, when the mosque will also be restricted. As for the restaurants and cafes near by, they're great, but some very touristic, I would recommend something more traditional a bit further away.Walking distance from both Eminonu and the Grand Bazaar, but note that it's uphill from Eminonu, while the walk from the Bazaar is mostly straight. (There's also a Metro stop right outside) I would recommend the walk from Eminonu though, you get to see the 'sokaks' and the true "spirit" of the European side of Istanbul.
Marvelous mosque. Takes you back to the days of the Ottoman empire.Beautiful from the outside, magical and mysterious from within.
The most beautiful mosque of Istanbul. Well worth a visit, even if it means foregoing Blue Mosque or Hagia Sophia. Marvellous location with a great tea place right next door.

No queuing necessary!. We didn't want to waste valuable time queuing for the more well known mosques and palaces so decided to investigate near our hotel. I'm so glad we did - loved the whole experience

Spiritual. Still functioning as a mosque today. This old structure is surrounded by lush gardens. The interiors are filled with Ottoman era designs. Women are required to cover their heads to enter the mosque.
Worth a visit. Impressed by the dimention and the great sempicity inside, but worth a visit in the area...punfortunatelly the tombs of the sultan was closed.

Beautiful AND Less Crowded. This was my favorite mosque I visited in Istanbul. This is because it's not only beautiful, it's also much less crowded than the Blue Mosque. You can get there from Sultanahmet by walking through the Grand Bazaar, which provides a neat contrast of nutty bartering and serene spiritualism. I stayed in the courtyard and just read my book for a while, it was so peaceful. Also, this mosque holds the mausoleum of Suleiman the Magnificent, arguably the most important Ottoman sultan, who presided over the largest growth of the Ottoman empire. In sum, GO HERE.

More wonders.. I can only agree with the majority of other reviews. All the mosques are wonderful, it's just a question of which ones to visit on a short visit, but don't miss this one, or you'll regret it.

A Beautiful Mosque. In my opinion it is not a must see in Istanbul unless you have the time. We were wondering around the bazaar district and decided to go in. Glad we did as it is a beautiful mosque and is very quiet and spiritual in comparison to the Blue Mosque.

Beautiful, magical, mystical, sensuous Istanbul. Love this city and its beauty. Sinan the Great, architect of so many majestic and exalted beautiful mosques and buildings in and around Istanbul, was prolific and this one is amazing. My favorite is Rustem Pasha, a small and most exquisite tiled mosque with such beauty and tranquility above the spice market. Have been there 7 times and will again.By the way, the paragraph that credits Sinan with building the Hagia Sophia also is incorrect. It was built long before the Ottoman Empire conquered the Greeks, converting it to a mosque and covering the Byzantium tiles of Christianity and icons depicting the Biblical stories. Minarets were added a couple of centuries later.Don't miss this amazing city and country!

Grand old Mosque. This is actually a complex including a mosque and other buildings surrounding it (not open to public). The architectural design of this grand old mosque is beautiful with its four minarets. The interior is magnificent and well decorated such that you feel safe and relaxed while inside.

Worth the walk for an alternative to The Blue Mosque. A good attraction to couple with a visit to a The Grand Bazaar. Leave by the back door of the bazaar, walk through the atmospheric back streets and search out this impressive and emotive mosque. Much larger than The Blue Mosque and far less crowded we certainly found it more inspiring and religious space. Worth noting that it is an active mosque which understandably excludes tourists at prayer times but use that time to have lunch or coffee in one of the local restaurants with outdoor seating.
Suleymaniye Mosque. Excellent architecture.Beautifully design well kept and maintained even though the structure is more than 600 years old

Freshly Finished. The Suleymaniye Mosque has just gone thru a beautiful renovation that really makes the experience a lovely one. Inside find wonderful intricate decoration, some nice stained glass and a very nice quiet atmosphere. It's not famous, or extremely large, but it is historical and the garden and plaza that surrounds it is noteworthy. Stop in during your trip before or after going to the bizarre, which is right at an entrance.
Very beautiful. Very beautiful mosque , large gardens and kind of new interior , walking around the mosque is recommended , the view towards the phosphorous is magnificent.

My Visit to Istanbul. I was at at Tashkonak for 5 days. It was a pleasent stay. The room was quite spacious. The breakfast wqas quite good. The location is good as well being not far fom the Blue Mosque. The staff in the hotel was helpful. Tranfer to te airport was freee since I stayed 5 nights.
A beautiful quiet Mosque. Perhaps not as famous as the Blue Mosque but still a legend. Very quiet and peaceful mosque with great history. Very well maintained, clean, and friendly.
Enormous Structure. It looks new but this mosque got a quite history. Relaxing place without hassle even for non Muslims.

An architectural gem. The Sulemaniye is a gorgeous mosque with (in my opinion) a more spiritual feel than the touristy Blue Mosque. Don't miss the opportunity to sit at one of the restaurants just outside, some housed in the former kitchens of the mosque complex, and have a traditional lunch of Kurufasulye (a bean dish). One further comment: I am not sure why the tripadvisor entry says that the architect Sinan was also responsible for Hagia Sophia, which is roughly 1000 years older than the Sulemaniye. The older building was designed by Anthemius of Tralles and Isidorus of Miletus, under orders of the Byzantine Emperor Justinian, in 537.
Classic Mosque. Much less touristy than Blue Mosque with lovely clean lines Tea in the cloister at the back was great beautifully calm

Beautiful and peaceful mosque. I visited this mosque with my brother. We were so amazed by the beauty of the mosque that we stayed there for 3 hours, listening to the talk that was happening at the front of the mosque even though we did not understand a word :) So magnificent and beautiful it took my breath away. From the vast dome to the beautiful Islamic decorations adorning the mosque. I honestly did not want to leave! Definitely go visit and treasure the memory.
WOW!. Make the effort to visit this beautiful mosque. The architecture was stunning and in my opinion one of the best mosques that I saw on my trip to Istanbul.

Well worth a Visit. This mosque is Certainly worth a visit although a little off the beaten track the mosque was fantastic with so much light and peaceful atmosphere. It towers above the city and has so much to see both inside and outside.
So peaceful. Beautiful and peaceful mosque with lovely surrounding gardens. It's not as busy and ornate as the Blue Mosque but has a wonderful peaceful atmosphere.

Istanbul mosques. Beautiful and serene mosque. We walked from the Spice Bazar up through the narrow streets into this large mosque surrounded by peaceful gardens and a view across the city. The tiles and windows inside are stunning.

Better than the Blue Mosque. Away from the main mosque and museum area so less crowded. It has a wonderful dome and great tiles. The architectural features are similar to other mosques and very we'll preserved.

Magnificent piece of architecture. The size and exquisiteness of the architecture take your breath away. How did they build it without modern machinery? It's not just a mosque it is a compound so it is worthwhile walking around outside the mosque as well as inside. Inside you see the magnificence of the dome, the tiles, need to really sit there and soak up the atmosphere. Went during ramadan therefore there was a very good atmosphere - like a festival.

Gets overlooked and its worth the visit. It's not as fancy as some of the other mosque but it is beautiful and has a much more reverent atmosphere. Sinan built it and this is where Suleyman is buried along with Roxlana. We enjoyed.
old. great l can not tell they should lıve ın ıstanbul lıttle tıme. and they should feel it s everythıng ok
A peaceful haven. We had a lovely long walk to this mosque and ate strawberries from a local seller in the grounds- simply magnificent

Absolutely astonishing. This mosque is a very impressive work of art — more so even than the more famous Blue Mosque or the Hagia Sophia. The architect Sinan achieved an extraordinary balance between monumental majesty and openness. If you're paying attention, something magical happens when you walk into this mosque, a feeling of both grandeur and expansion, as if you are being lifted up to heaven. By comparison, the (very beautiful) Blue Mosque is just another big building.
Peaceful and serene. On top of a hill and a little removed from the bustle of the city, this serene mosque is an oasis of peace
I was impressed. As a mosque i havent seen any better one. Great harmony of art and peace. It was really difficult to imagine that its older than 500 years.

A Nice Discovery. It is my third time in Istanbul but only this time I went to Suleymaniye Mosque. The view of the Galata Tower and Galata Bridge from the back of this mosque is magnificient!It is less touristy compared with the blue mosque but very worth the visit..

Amazing!!!!. I have been in many palaces in my travels, but this one takes the cake! It is a must see for any one who travels to Istanbul. It is one of the few palaces that have not been robbed. So you can still see much of the way it was centuries ago. Just come early, as the tickets sell out and they do have max capacity of 3000 people per day.

Beautiful outside- Not great inside- Long Wait. I have to say I was a little disappointed once inside the Suleymaniye Mosque, we waited over an hour to get in and then once getting in I have to say I was a little disappointed. We wasn't in there that long, didnt feel like there was much to see and I didnt think the architecture was that spectacular, It's worth a visit, we visited about 6 mosques in our trip and I did find that they was beautiful outside but not that great once inside.
Awesome building. The scale and architecture were astounding. We should have engaged a guide to explain the full complex and the intricate details.

What a "Cami"!. Been to that mosque as I saw it from distance although I was not told that it's one of the main things I need to do in the Historic area but went there as I can not afford to miss such a huge mosque and it was really worth the visit. I can easily compare it to SultanAhmet mosque if not better, I can even say it's the best mosque I've seen in Istanbul ... Very Peaceful with majestic architecture and beautiful interiors. A Must see mosque!

Beautifully peaceful area. The Mosque and its surrounding areas were stunning. We were lucky to go to the area at midday with beautiful blue skies that truly brought out the atmosphere of the mosque and it's surrounding gardens.
Süper Camii. I Really Like This Camii Great Süleymaniye... when ı came istanbul ı alwasy visit this CaMİİ, Everyone Has To see this great CaMİİ... THANKS MİMAR SİNAN...

Peaceful and imposing. Away from tourist crowds it is possible to wander the cemetery and the grounds without the rush and bustle of some other sites. The visit inside the mosque is very peaceful and it is large and beautiful. It is worth the wander uphill to reach it and enjoy the experience.

Beautiful. This is a stop that is worth your time. The mosque was busy when we were there, but pretty to see on the inside. It is one of, if not the biggest, in Istanbul and a very popular tourist stop.

Probably most impressive Mosque!!. Massive mosque, go to Blue Mosque first or that will be ruined. We were practically alone in this Mosque as most tourists don't visit this one, which adds to its appeal. Bit of a walk to get to. We got off at University tram stop and walked through the campus to get to mosque. Watch for scamming shoeshine guys, can't believe it but got duped by the dropped brush scam near the mosque!! LOL If you are going to visit a few mosques while here, this one is a MUST
Basically the Blue Mosque. A beautiful mosque that looks like the Blue Mosque both inside and out. A few restaurants are opposite.

Tranquil and delightful. Quite a contrast to the hustle and bustle of Sultanahmet square, the Suleymaniye mosque is a delight. Not quite so spectacular or imposing an exterior as the Blue Mosque but it has arguably the most stunningly beautiful interior of all the Istanbul mosques. The courtyards are elegant and peaceful - only the sound of running water on the day of our visit - and we spent a very relaxing time just revelling in the tranquility.
Place of peace and beauty. Restoring continues in some parts of the mosque, especially in the caravanserai. Still the garden and cemetery are most beautiful and peaceful places in Istanbul.

Our favorite of All the mosques. This mosque is outstanding in its simplicity and elegance of decoration. It's not overdone and yet is totally inspiring. It is very much an active mosque and there were quite a fell of the faithful there praying during our visit. It was interesting to be able to observe without interfering.

Simple beauty. One of a series of mosques designed by Sinan, this one was our favorite in Istanbul because of its clean lines and light airiness. It had recently been restored, which probably added to its beauty.
Must visit. Beautiful architecture. You can feel the living history of the place. You do have to take your shoes off to enter, so wear socks.

The Architect's Passion. We saw this mosque before we went to the Blue Mosque and I think I appreciated it more for that reason. It is a huge mosque and very beautiful both inside and out. It is probably the greatest accomplishment of Sinan, the master architect who created this mosque and Rustem Pasha near the Spice Market, among others. It was a more solemn atmosphere and much less crowded. I hope the tombs will be open to the public again soon. We were disappointed we could not visit them or the grounds while we were there. Make sure you do take the time to visit the tomb of Sinan which is located outside of the mosque grounds on the opposite side of the street.
So big, so pretty. Lovely mosque and cemetery near a lively university. We thought we'd seen enough mosques but glad we went to this one afterall!

A lovely building. We enjoyed our visit to Suleymaniye, probably more so than the Blue Mosque, as it seemed much more a place of quiet contemplation and worship and less of a tourist zoo. Take some time to stroll the grounds, including the cemetery. The tomb buildings were still closed when we visited, but you can peer through the windows. Very clean (and free toilets) in the grounds.

Finally a calm mosque. After visiting Hagia Sophia and Sultan Ahmed Mosque which are very noisy and crowded and after seeing Kılıç Ali Paşa Cami and Rüstem Pasha Mosque which are rather small, I consider Suleymaniye Mosque the best mosque in Istanbul.It's perhaps a bit hidden from main tourist routes, but it is definitely worth it to go and see it. Not only it is one of the largest mosques in the city, it is for sure also one of the quietest ones. One can simply sit back at a carpet and admire the monumental architecture, atmosphere and after going out... the magnificent view over the city.
Beautiful mosque. This mosque is worth the visit! For women who don't have a head scarf, they have one available for you at the entrance.
Stunning............Well worth a visit. A stunning Mosque in the most amazing setting. An instant calmness about the place. A great place to visit and enjoy.

The Mosque of Suleiman the Magnificent. It's sort of impudent for mere tourists to rate the mosque of one of the greatest sultans of the Ottoman Empire. It's a huge, working mosque with various side buildings. It was built by the great architect Sinan over 400 years ago. It's certainly not in the same league as Aya Sofya from a historic perspective, but it's well worth a visit if you're into architecture and history.It's a little off the beaten track, but for less than 10 USD, you're there in a few minutes by taxi.Unfortunately, Suleiman's tomb was closed--without explanation--the day I was there.

Huge. This is one of the biggest mosques I have ever seenVery nice, architecture works are impressive.it worth to have a walk there, and it is not far from Grand bazar, both can be visited in the same time
One of the grandest mosque. Suleyamaniye mosque is Mimar Sinan's most beautiful form of art. His tomb is located next to the mosque.
Great. The best mosque by far in Istanbul unique the arquteture of the mosque the decoration simple but very bright a lot of calours

One word ...wonderful!. Totally in awe visiting this mosque today. I keep thinking.... how did they do it with just very simple instruments. Right from the design to the actually building it. What an incredible architect and project manager Sinan was. The mosque is just beautiful and so much more peaceful to visit than the blue mosque with all the hustle and bustle. The view of Istanbul from the inner court of mosque was stunning on this sunny day. From there we also could see " cafe sultan's " roof terrace on Fetva Ykş. ( street name) ..... reward yourself by going there after your visit to the mosque. It is literally a hop and a skip from the mosque. They accept you just buy coffee and tea and just enjoy the view from up there. Service super friendly and very clean bathroom.
Beautiful view. The mosque sits on top of a hill and the view of Istanbul is magnificent. The building is very interesting and the small cemetery (like all Islamic cemeteries) is beautiful.
impressive. Another must see mosque worth the small walk up to the hill from the Egyptian bazar.Less crowded than Blue Mosque

Alone in the big Mosque.. I had the fortune to be left alone in that mosque. The group of Japanese people, left without any words, and i found myself inside the mosque to take pictures and just be my self for a while.. Was a very powerful experience!!...

Worth a look. Certainly worth a visit if you have some spare time after the Grand Bazaar. Not quite as impressive as the Blue Mosque, but almost! Unlike the Blue Mosque, the Suleymaniye is not overflowing with tourists. The Suleymaniye also still possesses its full complement of auxiliary buildings (hamam, madrasa, etc). Whilst there, don't miss the Ottoman Sultan tombs, including that of the eponymous Suleyman.

Worth a visit. I felt the same way about the Suleymaniye mosque as I did about the Blue Mosque -after being inside I left feeling a little underwhelmed. The building and the grounds are huge, and the mosque dominates the Istanbul skyline. It is the mosque which one sees from the waterfront and features on most publicity about the city.It is a very inspiring building and a wonderful piece of construction, but the inside is vast and pretty empty. The domes and mosaics are really beautiful but can only be viewed from afar. It is still worth visiting as the mosque has a rich history to share and the views from the grounds over the Golden Horn are spectacular.

Lovely Dome. The Suleymaniye Mosque wasn't the most ornate mosque in the city (go to the Blue or Rustem Pasha Mosques for better tile decoration), but its sheer size and lovely yellow painted dome were impressive. It was good to see the contrast here versus the more ornate mosques, though. The mosque has a nice peaceful courtyard, and the restaurants nearby are convenient for lunch after a stop here. The gravestones behind the mosque were also interesting to see - taller and skinnier than elsewhere in Europe and North America.

A bit of a hike! :-). It takes a bit of a hike to get to the Suleymaniye Mosque and with the poor street signing in Istanbul you may well feel lost walking up, the mosque and the whole complex it is truly worth it. I loved the colour scheme in which the inside is decorated. View over the Golden Horn is also amazing.

Over-rated. Its beautiful from a distance however the actual experience wasn;t that overwhelming for me. Maybe because I am Pakistani and have been living with Mughal architecture which is way more refined. Anyways a trip to Istanbul is incomplete without a visit to Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque so yes, do visit it.

Lovely ambience. Between this one and the Blue Mosque, I enjoyed my time here much more. Its location on the hill and the beautiful surrounding grounds, together with the calming pastel colour scheme in the interior adds to the spirituality of the place. Here I got the strong sense that this was where people came to worship, a solemness that I felt lacking in the blue mosque, probably because of the throngs of tourists.
A must see. Any visitor has to see the Blue Mosque, but don't overlook this one as some would say it is even more beautiful. Not far from Grand Bazaar tram stop.

Blue Mosque Is Special But So Is Suleymaniye, Well Worth It. After visiting the Blue Mosque you may feel you're good on Mosques -- with all due respect. But, this Mosque is a totally different building and experience. Both are very special. At Suleymaniye we especially enjoyed seeing the cemetery to the side of the Mosque with the mausoleum of Suleyman the Magnificent. You can not go in but you can look in through numerous windows. The cemetery overall was a lovely spot. The Mosque itself is very tranquil, as noted. We were the only Westerners there at the time and felt very welcome. We sat on the floor in a corner, as did many local couples, and really enjoyed seeing and experiencing this monument to faith. BTW, we visited the Mosque as a stop on Rick Steve's Grand Bazaar-Suleymaniye-Spice Market Walk. It was a great day!

Excellent mosque off the main tourist trail. Beautiful mosque, very large, and not as crowded as the Blue Mosque and therefore feels more authentic. It is larger then the blue mosque but less ornate. Nice place to visit especially if you are going to the Grand Bazaar as it is walking distance from the Bazaar.

Good trip if you are around the Grand Bazaar. Finding Grand Bazaar too tourist trap-ish then it's a breath of fresh air. Took some nice photos of interesting tombstones with turbans. I was intrigued with the one star rating of this place on trip advisor- however if that review is true I agree they would not let a drunken person in the premise - is a functioning mosque with history and is to be respected.
Beautiful Mosque. 10-15 minutes walk from the Grand Bazaar. Very secluded with calm atmosphere. Beautiful carvings and great decorations. One of the popular mosques of Istanbul.
If going to the Bazaar you must stop here. When you go to the Bazaar take the time to make a stop at this beautiful mosque, it's very close to the Bazaar and well worth the visit.
Soft decor and great atmosphere.. The setting of the Mosque, the architecture, the decorations, the atmposphere, the gardens and the cemetery!

Clean and tranquil. It was easy to find and I'm glad there was time to visit. I took more pictures here than I did at Sultanahmet. I got there before the groups began arriving, and enjoyed the wide open spaces. I came here based on trip advisor, and now see why it's rated so high. It was a peaceful way to start my day in town.

Wonderful experience. We really enjoyed visiting the beautiful building and the adjoining garden where it's architect is buried. The interior is less ornately decorated than the Blue Mosque, but in some ways this simplicity added to its gravitas and emotional impact, almost as interesting an experience was walking down hill from the Mosque to the Golden Horn through a very local neighborhood that was completely untouristed.

The 'Mosque of Light' does not disappoint. This elegant and beautiful structure provides a very enjoyable visit. The views of greatAnd the architectural design fits well into the location. The interior is as elegant as the exterior And the area is located in has plenty of pleasant cafe restaurants in which to admire the mosque from different angles of view. Highly recommended.
Good to see. After visiting the Grand and Spice Bazaars go up the hill and visit this mosque. It offers a wonderful view over the Golden Horn.

deserve a visit. one of the largest mosques in turkey, you can see it far away from sultan ahmad district since it was constructed on a hill. the design is alike other mosques in istanbul. you can visit the tomb of Sultan Sulaiman the mignificent in the outside garden. Recommended
Amaizing. One word - magnificent! You do not want to miss this place, feel the history in every corner of this grand building! great architectural marvel!

Beautiful inside and out. Perhaps not as structurally impressive as the Blue Mosque, this building had a simple, peaceful beauty to it. We found it much quieter and less crowded than some of the other mosques we visited. The courtyard behind the mosque itself offers some pretty impressive views of the Galata Bridge portion of town. Of course keep in mind that during service times, visitors are not allowed in the building (30 minutes before or after the call to prayer or on Friday afternoons). We did find that getting there was a bit difficult; if you're having trouble finding it, make your way to the University and either follow the brown signs.

Most beautiful mosque in town. It's much less touristy than the Blue Mosque, which is flooded by tourists that make noises and take photos. This mosque gives me the islamic air I was hoping to see before coming to Turkey.
Outstanding architecture!. This Mosque is very impressive from the outside, inside there is not much to see...I was expecting more detail in the interior part .
Beautiful and Peaceful. A beautiful mosque, simple in design but felt peaceful the moment we entered. Less tourist as compared to Blue Mosque.
Fantastic building. Fantastic building inside and outside. There is a nice graveyard next to the mosque. This is a special experience and almost as impressive as the Blue Mosque.
Awesome mosque. As a muslim, had the chance to perform prayer inside the mosque. Love the decoration inside it, the feeling was amazing.

Easy to enter, place to sit and absorb the atmosphere. It was nice after all the crowded main sites to find that it is easy to enter this mosque and anjoy the peacfulness of it. We sat around for a while and enjoyed the atmosphere. They are not limiting the entrance of tourists.
quite impressive. well run security, beautifully maintained mosque. you must remember to bring clothing appropriate for the visits to mosques or you will be turned away.
Overwhelming. usually people visit the Blue Mosque, but this is not to be missed. A huge mosque, intricate interiors, and such a peaceful place... you will love the ambience. Don't miss it.

Just a short walk beyond the Grand Bazaar. Very elegant and beautiful mosque and grounds. The blue Iris which seem to be the mourning flower of Turkish cemeteries were just coming to bloom. Roxanne, the harem slave girl who came to rule first the heart of Suleiman the Great, and, then his empire is entombed here.
Compared to the Blue Mosque it's disappointing. Problem is we went to the Blue Mosque first. This Mosque was lovely architecturally too but not as stunning with colour.
Beautiful and a must see. An amazing feat of architecture and very grand. It has been very well maintained. As it is a mosque, there isn't much going on inside but still great.
have to see. One of the most important mosques of İstanbul, if you are on a sight seeing visit you should not miss Sulamaniye. could be very crowded better to go early

An impressive architectural wonder. This place is one of my favourites. You can feel some kind of bliss inside the Mosque...
Let the enviroment flow inside you and live this experience as an unique. I was fascinated by its decoration, architecture and lighting.

Found this to be a great mosque to visit with less crowds. Skip the massive crowds at the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sophia. This is a massive mosque that is also beautiful and quiet. You can carefully examine all the parts of this mosque without being rushed.
Amazing Architecture. Beautifully designed Mosque...loved the grounds. A true display of the master architect at work !! Gives a total picture of the greatness of Sinan !!

Peaceful setting. Having spent the morning in the Grand Bazaar and then walking in the rain to get here i felt an immediate sense of peacefulness as soon as i entered the grounds of the Mosque.There was less visitors compared to the Blue Mosque and it felt more relaxing somehow.Beautiful mosque which is well worth the short walk from the Bazaar.

Enchanting!. If you ever go to Turkey- Istanbul this place is a must visit, coming from Egypt I don't get impressed easily by ancient mosques and landmarks, but the minute i walked into the mosque i was hooked, felt peace and i couldn't help but just sit there and look around, it's really enchanting, although it wasn't an easy trip trying to find the place (got lost a little bit), it was worth the walk and the visit. highly recommended. not to mention that Al-sultan's tomb and his wife's tomb are in the backyard of the mosque. make sure you walk around the place too don't just visit the inside and leave.

Amazing. It's must to visit! Not so big que as in Aya Sophia. Very untypical for cristinas. Absolutely amazing, feel of emotions, absolutely beautifull. But be respect to religious feelings, especially in your closing.

One of my favorite places to visit!. I was introduced to this mosque on an amazing Prive Istanbul walking tour and I fell in love with the view from the back of the mosque where the grassy area is, way at the far left corner, with the mosque on your right. WOW. That's all I can say. The mosque is very beautiful as well. Check out the digital clocks that keep track of the prayer times. During prayer times e.g. lunchtime, the mosque is closed to visitors. If this happens to you, go to the nearby lokanta which is on the Mosque grounds, there are tables on a terrace, and point and choose what you'd like to try from the eight to ten steaming cauldrons in the kitchen for a delicious, authentic and very reasonable meal. If you can manage it, you can ask for some of each! Being so close to the mosque, no alcohol is served, but sparkling water(soda), soft drinks and refreshing pomegranate (nar) juice is. By the time your lunch is over, the mosque should be open to visitors. The nearest restroom might be the one by the mosque and it has one sit down and one squat toilette on the women's side.

Suleymaniye Mosque, Istanbul Turkey. Close by the Grand Bazaar is the Suleymaniye Mosque, constructed for Suleyman the Magnificent. Even though smaller than the Blue Mosque we found the Suleymaniye Mosque to be amazingand it seemed to be more of a "working mosque", we were the only tourists inside. I personally thought that it had a much more tranquil feeling than The Blue Mosque which I also feel should be on the not to be missed list.

Magnificent in its simplicity. The interior is a lot simpler than other great mosques in Istanbul, which allows the proportions and the harmony of the building to really shine.Our advice if you are visiting in winter: come close to closing time (17.00) and after the visit go for a drink in one of the cafes behind the mosque and enjoy the sun down and the lights coming on on the building. Absolutely stunning!

Worth a visit. If you have time and are in the area it's worth a visit, especially since it's free. Like most of the big historic mosques in Istanbul, the outside is impressive and the inside in beautiful. I lucked out and entered just minutes before one of the prayer services started. Even though I have no idea what anything meant or what was being done, it was very interesting to be able to witness the service while I was in there.

Worth the steep walk. We walked up to the mosque from the spice (Egyptian ) bazaar and it is very very steep with uneven pavements. Directions are painted on walls so you can't go far wrong. Check prayer times. The exterior and interior are stunningly beautiful and well worth a visit.

Grandiose. The Süleymaniye Mosque was built on the order of Sultan Süleyman in only 8 years (1550-1558) but suffered over the centuries damages because of two fires and one earthquake. The courtyard is extremely beautiful and has four minarets (only the sultan could build 4 minarets, princes and princesses could construct two minarets and others only one) The dome is very high, but still smaller than that of Hagia Sophia. The interior is very large and incredibly beautiful. I had the chance to attend the services, and I was really impressed by how beautiful the imam was preaching about the importance of helping those in need. Any tourist could attend the services, regardless of their religion with the sole condition to be dressed decently and women to cover themselves with a veil. In the garden there are two mausoleums, including the tombs of Sultan Süleyman his wife Roxelana (Haseki Hürrem), his daughter Mihrimah, his mother Dilaşub Saliha and his sister Asiye.All in all, it is a beautiful place that I wholeheartedly recommend !
Blue mosque. Really Grandiose and.... Blue. I like the Light shimmering in the air of this spacious beautiful mosque.

charming. it's not possible to write about this place you must go and see it.
I have been here before too. Just great place to be.

Great mosque to visit but try to avoid the droves of visitors. Try to avoid peak times, in order to better enjoy the beauty of the interior. One can enter only removing one's shoes, so for me it was a welcomed rest for my feet to walk the padded carpeting and even sit and rest.

Impressive and almost tourist-free. The grandest mosque in Istanbul, yet off the beaten path. It's huge, pretty and does not have any people in line to see it.
Worth the cab ride (and then walk down the hill to the Egyptian bazaar)
magnıficent. ıt was magnıfıcent everythıng tıles people are prayıng and they are so respectful to you ı dıdnt see thıs another country lıve lıke thıs more happy

Beautiful mosque without the crowds. Beautiful mosque. Although not as ornate as some of the others in the old town, there are less tourists around and there are extensive grounds to wander in. Walked from Eminonu - not difficult to find, just keep climbing!

Worth to visit it !!!. Very big Mosque, worth a visit !!! Women must cover the head( hair) and all take off the shoes ( they give you one use plastic shoes and plstic bag to put your shoes on ), very clean , and a huge chandelier in the center of mosque !! there are some souvenir Shops outside and cafes and restaurants !! Nice place for photos !!

Suleymaniye mosque. Beautiful building, amazing architecture in gracious setting. But not any major difference from many of the other mosques in the city, which seem to be loosely based on the Blue Mosque, which seems to be based on the sublime Hagia Sophia.

Beautiful mosque and we are not of muslim religion. We had to wait for one hour (?) for the service to finish before we. Beautiful mosque and we are not of Muslim religion. We had to wait for one hour (?) for the service to finish before we could go in. Had to take our shoes off and my wife had put on her scarf over her head. It was all well worth it, despite the fact that we had to walk all the way from the port and up the hill, through the light industrial area and having to ignore the funny looks we were given by the locals.

Our favourite Istanbul Mosque. Such a beautiful Mosque and appreciated that fewer tourists make the short trip there. Stunning inside and out and really interesting in terms of understanding history of Istanbul. Quieter and calmer than some of the more famous attractions.
Worth every time at the location. Lots of tourist at the location, beautiful, well connected by public transport, it is essential to dress appropriately( London dresses, but the give you scarfs

Beautifully Designed Mosque. Its a mamoth mosque with very beautiful interior. i liked the courtyard of Blue mosque better than this. Outside you will see plenty of space to walk around. A must visit when in istanbul

BEST place for photos. This mosque sits on lovely grounds, but it is SO high up that you can get amazing shots of Istanbul / the Beyoglu side. Just remember to walk around the garden after you go inside! These are some of my FAVORITE photos I took on the whole trip.

Finest Large Mosque in Istanbul. Most travelers who take the steep winding path to the Suleymaniye Mosque will be well rewarded by the impressive majesty of the building and its environs, which include various tombs and a soup kitchen. The fantastic sense of light and space in the main building sees off the competition from the slightly larger Blue Mosque. It also attracts far fewer tourists and is therefore a calmer and more spiritual experience. Highly recommended.

Serenity at its best.. It is an attraction so tourist no less. However, I found this much more appealing than Blue Mosque. I probably shouldn't compare but if you have limited time on hand and can only choose one, I strongly recommend visiting this!It was amazing, peaceful and just wow.

Labour of love. Absolutely magical. In better state than blue mosque considering its much older, must see!. As all mosques in Istanbul are almost replicas, Sulaimaniye is definately most attractive on the inside.
Amazing. I found Suleymaniye Mosque to be more beautiful and spectacular than the Blue Mosque (which is beautiful too) - make time to visit but be aware that it's a bit of a trek to get there.
Better than Blue Mosque!. Less crowded...as in not crowded! Makes experience that much nicer. Entire building complex is pretty unique. Make sure to explore inside outside, downstairs....

Great views, really inspiring mosque. From galata bridge it is a bit of a climb to reach the mosque and a bit of a maze to find the correct route... But the views from the mosque are breathtaking. The mosque is really nice and less crowded than the other ones. It is peaceful and an inspiring place, really worth the climb.
Very different mosque. Excellent location and view of the city. Great architecture in its simplicity.Harmony in everything.
wow.... its an amazing place to experience historic feel of an old building... :))Its a great place to take some splendid photos and its located next to Topkapi and Aya Sofya....
Interesting. We liked this mosque. It's big & has a commanding view. If you go to the Blue Mosque & the Kucuk Ayasofia Camii, tho', you can give this one a miss.
Incredible. The mosque was absolutely incredible. I could have stayed there all day if I didn't have other places to be.
One of the many mosque. Well kept and clean. Bigger that the blue mosque, but the interior was not as impresive as the blue mosque.

Magnificent Building by Sinan. This is the best mosque in the city, per our preference. Even not that decorative or without greatest fame, the relative quiet and calm atmosphere inside and outside provides the genuine moment, at least in February. Very impressive.
Brıllant!. In my opınıon ıt ıs nıcer than the Blue Mosque and Sofıa. It has a nıce vıew from the backyard. If you manage to vısıt ıt when there ıs a call for prayer ıt would be quıte astonıshıng.

Magnificant Mosque. This space is magnificant : the Marble more White than some of the other Mosques makes it look dreamlike. I loved this place and if I go to Istanbul again this is the Mosque I'll revisit
Great mosque!. We had the privilege of being the first ones in the door when it opened up and got amazing pictures. I love the wall to wall carpet that appears to provide individual prayer mats.
Tremendous. A very impressive mosque with beautiful exquisite mosaics. It is big and filled with light. An absolute must-see in Istanbul

Grand Architecture and Beautiful View.. This is another of the mosque's designed by the great Turkish architect, Mimar Sinan. Setting on one of the hills of Istanbul, it is the largest mosque in the city and offers magnificent views. I liked its clean lines and the subtlety of its interior. While somewhat muted when compared to the interior of the Blue Mosque, Sultan Mehmet Camii, I thought the grand open interior with less vibrant tile offered a more tranquil and contemplative atmosphere.

A calming respite after the hurly-burly of the Grand Bazaar. After attempting (and mostly failing) to do some shopping within the precincts of the Grand Bazaar, somewhere calmer and more soothing was on the agenda - the Sulemaniye Mosque was just a few steps away.My arrival coincided with the afternoon call to prayer - the first time I had been in a mosque at that moment. It was a significant and impressive sensation, regardless of belief.Away from the hustle and bustle of the Bazaar and all the tourist traps in the Hippodrome area, visiting Sulemaniye felt more of a genuine experience.Humbling.

Wonderful Architecture. We visited a number of Mosques and museums during our visit to Istanbul and each one of them has their own character, structure and architecture which reflect on the person state of mind who had them built. The Süleymaniye Mosque is one of the places you have to visit and is just as worthwhile as the Blue Mosque and Haga Sophia. . Its exterior and interior design complement each other including its very peaceful and pleasant surrounding which made it more outstanding.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque

A magnificent mosque for a magnificent sultan. Suleiman the magnificent had this fantastic structure built and is buried within its grounds with his family, while the "love of his life" Queen Roxallena (Hurrem Sultan), the woman who allegedly broke the original Ottoman blood line by having her son Selim II installed as the next Sultan after getting Sulaiman's righfull heir Mustafa executed by his father, died before him and is also buried in the grounds. But above all wonder at Sinan the Great's architectural work.
Pleasant area. Pleasant area in which to walk, see the magnificent Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. In the evening you can sit near the fountain. Be sure to try the popcorn and chestnuts!
Vivid mosque. Not as touristic as the Blue mosque which is crowded by groups in here you can became a pilgrim and have the real thing

chef d'oeuvre. it has a special architecture that deserve a stop. It is very maintain and the atmosphere is special. Also the outside is impressing. The good thing is to do the bath of Suleiman after the visit which is close by. It is the top three mosque in Istanbul.
NICE VISIT OF SULEYMANIYE MOSQUE. The Suleymaniye Mosque and its garden are magnificient. Don't try to visit it on Friday, date of pray, because you will not get inside,

Impressive, calm. This huge working mosque is a bit out of the centre of things and because of this easy to leave off the agenda, but this would be a pity as it is a unique experience. Very grand from the outside, inside it is an oasis of tranquillity which we found very calming, and finely decorated. Well worth a visit.

Good value for the price. It was very god that it was free and queues went very fast. There is some work at the entrance with the shoes and the scarfs but you can get in super fast. The interior is very unique with the carpets and the windows. Very good experience.

During the sunset the atmosphere is magical.. The Solimano Mosque is one of the most important in the city, it is located in an area with low influx of tourists and less crowded. As I did I visited during sunset, and quiet here and the mosque is open, you can visit inside but obviously you have to dress decently in order to enter due to religion restrictions. During sunset the show is exceptional, with the dusk light illuminates the mosque floor plan, the atmosphere is magical and the pictures become magnificent. Outside the mosque there is an array of traditional Turkish restaurants where you can eat with a little expense. All very nice and quaint.

Large Mosque with interesting features. Uphill walk from the Gelata area but worth the effort. I put it a good third position behind the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. If you have time, put this on your list.

beautiful interior. sulemaniye mosque is easily my favourite mosque in the city. the outside structure isnt as graceful as the Blue mosque but the interiors are breathtaking. the interiors are simple and elegant the dome's height is dizzying. the simple white walls provide a serene place to pray. as a Muslim i found great serenity here. also u will notice and are paintings of flowers on the main dome. Muslims have greater opportunity to see the mihrab if u were to pray there.tips: after visiting the inside the mosque i suggest wallking around to the gardens and see the view from the terrace. Note to muslims, the carpet here is harder compared to the other mosques
i like it. i enjoyed it from wikipedia, The interior of the mosque is almost a square.The interior decoration is subtle, with very restrained use of Iznik tiles

The most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. For me it is the most beautiful mosque of the city, located likely on a hill, besides the mosque, you should go inside, it has a wonderful garden and a fantastic view of the city
Plan your visit around prayer time. We showed up and they were just closing for prayers! It was a bit of a hike to get there, so it would have been nice to be able to stay longer!
TOP. If you have short time, if you have to choose one Mosque choose this one, pleasant garden, after this place visit the area around till the University...
Mosque. Once again the Mosques are so well looked after. To think this was all built without modern equipment blows my mind WOW

nice. beautiful mosque , up the hill , a trip that is well worthed . the mosque has been built in 7 years . is very impressive , and is recomanded to do the visit whit patience , to take the time for feeling the unique atmosphere .
