worth the trip. Even if you think you have seen enough mosques after visiting the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sofia, this one is worth the trip. It's close to the Grand Bazaar and has probably the most stunning courtyard out of all of them.

A climb worth it. We followed the uphill path and reached the Suleymaniye Mosque just as prayer time was ending. It's incredible to think that this beautiful Mosque was built in 7 years. Fewer tourists at this one, so you can really soak up the beauty of the architecture.

Impressive from the outside and from the inside. The mosque is pretty impressive from the outside and from the inside. In order to avoid the lines you may go a little before the start of the working time. Everyone have to leave their shoes outside so be prepared for the unpleasant smell inside.
Very interesting Mosque. Architecturally phenomenal. Beautiful. Skyline defining in Istanbul. Interesting history. Well worth the visit.

THE Mosque to Be Experienced. There is something very special in this mosque. It is the only Mosque that has been able to elicit in this rather non-reglious individual a sense of transcendence, if only for a fewbrief moments. There is is tranquility and solemnity embodied in the arcietecture and artwork that no other mosque possesses. The Blue Mosque is a little more spectacular and ornate, but doesn't convey the sense of spirituality one feels washing over you at the Suleymaniye. It is a sensation not experienced by me in any of the many spectacular cathedrals in Western Europe (iwth one possible exception...not the Sistene, no St. Peter's, but the more modest but still impressive Orvieto Cathedral in Umbria)
Impressive. Very impressive and stunning to look at. Unfortunately it was prayer time when we arrived so we didn't go inside. The outside is worth a visit on its own anyway!
Stunning. A monument not only to Suleyman, but also to his architect Sinan, whose tomb is just outside the walls of the mosque. The graceful lines of the mosque are inviting rather than overdone.
So beautiful. Breathtaking beauty from a distance and the interior is the same. Take the time to step in between prayers and take it all in.

The most amazing mosque of Istanbul. The Blue mosque is astonishing but there are way too many people visiting it whereas Suleymaniye is just what you need if you're looking for a quiet and peaceful place to visit and think. This mosque was built by the talented Mimar Sinan, and it is truly one of the highlights of Istanbul. It is not as big as the Blue mosque but way more beautiful. It is very light and has all the same features but is more cosy and welcoming. It's definitely worth visiting!

love ottoman mosques. very nice mosque..took us a while to get there cuz we walked from grand bazaar but very nice once we were in there..there is a restaurant by the mosque on the back side..lovely views from down there..
Suleymaniye Mosque. You should visit this mosque with its beautiful yards and gardens and the muslim cemetery. It's quite, frequented by few tourists and many locals and very beautiful.

Another majestic mosque. Perched on top of a hill, Suleymaniye Mosque commands a magnificent view that can be seen from its side garden terrace. Less visited than the Blue Mosque or Haghia Sophia, it is a more quiet place, where it is pleasant to wander for a while. It was also built by the great Ottoman architect Sinan. It is one of the largest mosques in Istanbul. The interior is absolutely magnificent. It is close to the Grand Bazaar and the University. Really worth visiting.

A wonderful place. This mosque wasn't on our agenda and was a spur of the moment decision. I'm so glad it was. This is a beautiful, peaceful mosque - none of the crowds you'll encounter at significant attractions such as the Aya Sofia and the Blue Mosque. Indeed there were no queues at all! The mosque itself is surrounded by gardens - quiet, airy, peaceful and austere. Absolutely delightful. I'm sure this was the most peaceful place we had been to in Istanbul to that moment! Do make an effort to visit this lovely place. I hope you enjoy it as much as we did.
Great views of the city. Built by Suleyman the Magnificent, this Mosque commands spectacular views over the city. It is well worth climbing the hill for!

Prachtig. Unfortunately due to our planeschedule, we couldn't get inside this mosque. (it's closed during the prayers a few times a day, so make sure you look at the openingtimes before). Still it's architecture is very beautiful, the Suleymaniye is beautiful situated on a hill, and make sure you don't miss the splendid view, if you walk to the viewpoint from the terrace around the mosque!
Breathtaking simplicity. Starkly beautiful both in and outside, it's grand without being overbearing, a space of light and lightness.
Don't miss it. Try to visit it. it is worth it. You get to see the real mosque experience plus the fact that the people who seamed to work there were nice and friendly.

Quiet and majestic. An exceptionally beautiful mosque a short walk from the Grand Bazaar...Even though visitors are restricted to the back of the mosque, if you ask nicely you will be allowed to venture into the deepest corners and spend as much time as you like...

not what i expected. After visiting Hagia Sofya it feels like visiting a copy of the Ottomans, so I guess I would recommend people to visit one of the two and I would suggest this to be Hagia Sofya as it is the original one

Majesty on the hill. Reaching the Suleymaniye Mosque is not easy... you need to climb up to the hill and get lost in the narrow streets before you reach this Majestic temple built by Suleyman the Great around 5 centuries ago. But the place is definitely worth a visit...
A must-see. So close to the Grand Bazaar, it's a must-see. From the Galata bridge there's a nice view of it. Beautiful roof. There's a public toillete just behind it.

Suleymaniye Mosque. The Suleymaniye Mosque was free to enter. You must remove your shoes and place them in a small plastic bag which is available free of charge at the entrance (recommended to wear socks). The mosque is closed during various periods throughout the day but there are signs at the entrance which show exact timings. I suggest that if you do arrive at the Mosque while it is closed for service (1200-1330 for example) go behind the Mosque and get in line. When the Mosque opens the lines can be very long. The inside is beautiful - remember to bring a camera and scarves for the ladies. I found 15 minutes was sufficient to visit the inside.
MUST SEE. both the mosque and its courtyard are extremely beautiful and definitely worth a visit. outstanding architecture

Istanbul - saleymaniye mosque. very clean, good atmosphere in and out
very peacful
enjoyable day,
decent places to eat near it,
lovely to see its amazing architecture

Unbelievebla arthitect by human. You must breath istanbul also with Suleymaniye Mosgue. The way of designingand the atmosphere inside the mosgueis really deepfull. You really feel your self to reach the oneness with this great architect.

Beautiful and tranquil place. Lovely place to visit to observe this religious place filled with history. Women need to ensure that they take a scarf to cover their hair, or they can hire a pashmina scarf for 4TL. You can take photos inside.

Great visit. There's so much history behind the Suleymanyie mosque complex. It's definitely worth a visit. If you go, you have to eat at the places selling white bean stew outside. They're great and not what you'd expect of tourist attraction food. It's a tradition!

Gorgeous Mosque Close to Grand Bazaar. I found this mosque to easily rival the Blue Mosque. It can easily be visited in conjunction with a visit to the Grand Bazaar. The ground are beautiful and the views from the back of the complex are quite stunning. The same rules apply here as they do at the Blue Mosque: no shoes for anyone and a scarf or shawl over the head for women. Don't miss this beautiful site!

Loved this. This mosque was so beautiful and majestic -- and not crowded like the Blue Mosque. HIghly recommend. It was also in a neat part of the city that was fun to explore. Not as touristy but still safe.

Exquisite Architecture. Speechless at the details of this magnificent master piece.The only annoyance is lending an ear to sales people, kids who try to convince you to buy carpets... They will try to distract you from visiting the Mosque, to make it a short cut to their shop. They are very friendly ,nice, and persuasive ...difficult to say no. Make your decision before getting there.

Pretty. Had to queue for a very long time and it's worth remembering it's an in use mosque so you don't get to see much other than the main room. Also remember that you need to remove shoes so worth wearing trainers for ease. It's a very pretty mosque but was exceptionally busy when we went.

Fascinating View into Islamic Prayer Life. It is unbelievable that this mosque was built in just 7 years! If you have the chance, read up on the history and funny anecdotes about how this wonderful structure came to have 6 minarets! You will need to remove shoes, and men must wear long pants, women must cover head and shoulders. This is a must if in Istanbul.

Great Mosque to visit. My favourite in Istanbul.Visiting any mosque in Istanbul would yield the same experience, less the Blue Mosque which has throngs of visitors. You would want to visit a mosque to soak in the atmosphere, enjoy the architecture and watch a Muslim prayer. Visited end 2011.
Totally underrated!. After visiting Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque, I just happened to visit this mosque and I found it better that any mosque in Istanbul atleast. It is totally a must see.
Peaceful. Not so many visitors here as the Blue Mosque and so a much quieter experience. A vast well preserved mosque with stunning architecture. Do not miss when in Istanbul.

The biggest mosque in Istanbul. It was the first mosque I've ever been to, but it is magnificent in size and splendor. Be aware of the praying times so you can spend the most possible time taking pictures.
Favourite!. Grand and beautifully proportioned, and yet quiet and intimate. The favourite mosque of all I saw. Acoustically perfect.
Amazing architecture. Place is amazing and a mosque that can be visited by people from any religion. The splendor of the place will keep its effect for long. 100 % recommended.
nice, quiet and clean. This mosque is nice and quiet and its next to the shopping zone. They clean the carpets and they borrow scarfs.
Stunning Mosque. A must-see sight in Istanbul. The decorations inside are so simple and lovely. The light, airy main chamber is stunning. Don't miss the grave yard "behind" the mosque.
Less crowded than the Blue Mosque. You have to trek a little ways out of the main tourists area to get here, but it is far less crowded and EVERY bit as spectacular as the Blue Mosque. Don't miss it.
Nice place. Nice place to visit and take your time to look up at the domed ceiling after that ot much else to look @

One of the big mosques. I entered early in the morning and was lucky that it wasn't crowded in comparison with the Blue mosque. It is huge and sincer there was not a lot of other visitors I could enjoy the peacefulness of the building. The tiles are amazing.
Beautiful. It takes a bit of effort to walk up but it's actually much less busy than the blue mosque and you can actually spend a quiet afternoon here.
Pretty. Very pretty place, but they are a little unfriendly with tourists if you want to get in. They rush you in and out due to services. Choose your time carefully.
A must see. A absolute must see when in Istanbul. Important to respect the clothing rules. Impressive even when it is crowded
Excellent Architecture. Sulemaniye Mosque is a classic example of Turkish Islamic architecture. The subtle use of very light pink color creates an un-matchable ambiance & grandeur.
Wonderful Architecture. Very organised and disciplined flow of tourists. I attended Friday prayers which was a wonderful experience

Hide treasure. Everybody in istanbul always focus in blue mosque and St.Sofia, but for me one of the best mosque in sultahnamet is Suleymaniye, apart from the mosque itself, similar in beauty to blue mosque but not that big, you have an old cemetery next to it and in the back one of the most beautiful views in istanbul. Viewing the galata bridge, the tower and the marmara sea.In addition, if you are travelling with your partner you have the only turkish bath for couples, one minute walking.

Sanctuary of peace. Beautiful mosque, quiet and peaceful on our visit (the blue mosque in comparison is crowded at all times). Hard to believe this structure is over 400 years old, but it looks new! Less ornate and decorated than the blue mosque but we spent a good amount of time here admiring the building and the ambience. Quite a walk up a hill but the shopping district around here is equally fascinating and bustling.

My favorite Mosque in Istanbul. This was the most magical Mosque IMO. It was much simpler than the Blue Mosque, but not as touristy and I got a much more religious feeling being in this Mosque. This is a must see anytime I go to Istanbul.
biggest mosque i ever visited. i have visited many mosques in central asia and asia but this one was biggest i saw.too many people are visiting itcrowds of people!

Don't miss it!. We could see the mosque from our hotel room. The hotel manager told us we should go there, and we did. You walk through the gate in the wall, and it's as if you have left the noisy city behind. The grounds are park-like, the Mosque truly a wonder to see. Leave a few Turkish lira after visiting the Mosque.

Must see, definitely. Not in every mosque in the world you can come if you are not a muslim. But in Istambul you can. And I recommend to visit Suleymaniye because it is not so crowded as Sultanahmet Camii but very majestic. You can combine this visit with the walk through the Grand Bazar.
:). So beautiful and comfortable! I was staying with a Muslim host family. I'm not Muslim but I felt so welcomed here! The lighting and carpeting really made the atmosphere that much more amazing.
Beautiful!. My mom and I enjoyed visiting this mosque, despite it being very touristy. The inside is breathtaking. I very much recommend this mosque to everyone.
Open Tombs. It is like other historical mosques, With Sultan süleyman and Hurram Sultan graves, but closed for visitors. On my previous visit they were open but at that time I knew little about them.

The most beautiful mosque that you'll ever see. Where else in the world can you watch the faithful Muslims pray and take pictures too?
The structure is absolutely spectacular, much larger than anything you ever imagined. And it is FREE!

Suleyman's mosque is magnificent!. Bitinya Tours' Ugur showed us this awesome, yet solemn place of prayer and through the calligraphy gave us an understanding of Islam. Sinan, the architect is the great architect of the Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent.

Much preferred over the Blue Mosque. My husband and I very much enjoyed visiting this Mosque. It is absolutely beautiful. We enjoyed this one much more than the noisy and crowded Blue Mosque. A beautiful, quiet and prayerful place.

My favorite mosque. I have to say that this mosque was my favorite to visit in Istanbul because it was quiet and quite far from hoards of tourists as opposed to the Blue Mosque. As it was a quiet space filled with an intensely calming energy compared to the rest of Sultanahmet, and the attractions around, I could have spent an entire day here.

Another magnificent Mosque.. I love the fact that all the mosques in Istanbul are so open and welcoming to everyone. With all it's domes and minarets, the Suleymaniye Mosque doesn't let you down at all. Go and look at the walls and the ceiling with wonder and awe - it deserves it! And with the entry absolutely free, why would you miss out?!
Brilliant. Somewhat similar to Blue Mosque, this mosque justifies the title given to Istanbul i.e. 'City of mosques'.

What a beautiful Mosque!. After visiting the blue mosque, we decided to find this one. It was absolutely lovely, and nowhere near as crowded or noisy as the blue mosque. The building is just beautifully maintained. If you are goung to visit a mosque in Istanbul, make sure to find this one!

An absolute must when in Istanbul. While you can see this from just about everywhere in Istanbul, finding it is slightly trickier. It is located not far from the University campus and the Grand Bazaar. Probably only about a ten minute walk from Galata Bridge. This building is a masterpiece of Sinans Work. it is absolutely magnificent. The grounds also afford a wonderful view across the Bosporous. You can also see the tombs of the Sultans in the complex. As it is a mosque there is no charge for entry . Take your time and view the incredible interior, beautiful ceilings and magnificent decor. Spellbinding
Best spot. No doubt the no#1 spot in Istanbul! During my stay went there couple of times. Must see day & night views!

Loved it. its a very nice mosque located in a nice quiet area. We almost skipped visiting it but then, we decided to check it out and we didn't regret that. The architecture is unique and different from the other mosques in Istanbul, it has a very nice surrounding garden. highly recommended, but do that early in the day as in the evening its difficult to find a cab. You pay 1 TL if you need to use the washroom

Clean, spacious lines. Of the 3 mosques I visited in Istanbul, I liked the interior of this one the most - it was bright, clean, and very spacious. Also I went while prayer was happening, which was a rather moving experience. The other two I saw were blue mosque and rustem pasha, both of which were also excellent.

out of the way but so worth the effort. Get there if at all possible. We had seen all the other major sights and are so glad we made the effort to cross town to see this mosque. It is magnificent and less over run with tourists. That means there are more faithful worshippers so be doubly respectful of their holy meditations.

"The highlight of the mosques". This is one of the most beautiful mosques of Istanbul. Are views of the city and the Golden Horn is splendid. It is located a short distance from the Grand Bazaar.We did this mosque like best, because it is not as crowded and also a beautiful architecture and equipment has. She is also surrounded by a green area and trees, which is also something special. Here you can easily spend an hour and still looks always new details.

Nice, big, beautiful mosque. I have been to this mosque a few times over the years. It is great to visit and the gardens in front provide excellent photo opportunities. Once you go in you will probably spend 5-10 minutes taking pictures. It is free to enter. It draws large tourist crowds and is also in use by the locals.

Beautiful Mosque. It is an incredibly beautiful mosque. The domes on the outside are very impressive and the work on the inside is equally so.To enter, one must take their shoes off, put them in a bag (supplied) and the women must cover their head with a scarf. There are some available there if you forget to bring your own. But definitely go inside it to appreciate the historical magnitude of it.

well worth the walk :). Amazing mosque, I believe better than the blue mosque not as crowded, with the cemetery section open to see the turbe of sultan suljeman, hurem and other family members. Well worth visiting this amazing place filled with history. We visited here then the new mosque and spice bazzar. I don't think much can compare to this place a must see!

Beautiful and peaceful. Near the Spice Bazaar, I was intrigued to see this lovely Cami. I thought it was gorgeous and so massive.It is amazing to think of how they built this. I loved the Blue Mosque, but really liked this one, too.

Certainly worth a visit. If you're planning to visit just one mosque in Istanbul let it be this one rather than the touristic Sultanahmet. It's located on the historical peninsula within walking distance from the Spice Bazaar and it's one of the most emblematic ottoman buildings after the Top Kapi palace. Plus it's a more genuine and peaceful mosque.For the ladies it's strongly suggested as in all mosques to have some scarf with you to cover your head otherwise they'll give you some cover in the entrance.
Serene. On entry which welcomes visitors, there is a feeling of tranquility, beautiful architecture and design. I would recommend all visitors to Istanbul to go there.

Awesomely Amazing. The architecture is beautiful, but looked very much inspired by Hagia Sofia across. The mosques are usually places of worship and this looked more busy with visitors rather than worshippers. The administration needs to find more balance so both can find balance, visitors could be channelled through separate path.Also you wonder why the places which serve whine exist so close or next to mosque compound across in cafes around restaurant in arasta bazar. Shame glory days of ottoman muslim empire passed but why!!

Possibly the pinnacle of Osmanli mosque architecture. Graceful interiors and capacacious gardens, cemeteries, plazas and related school and service buildings. For me, much more impressive than Aya Sophia or the Blue Mosque. It is refined, modern in feel and awe inspiring. Photos do not do it justice. After you go and for laughs read the 3 star reviews ( some of which are actually of the Blue Mosque). Sinan earned his renown on the basis of this work alone. Had it not been raining, I would have stayed at least an hour longer drink in the exterior and courtyard.
a must see mosque. The courtyard, the Inside of the mosque so serene and its cemetery: the tombstones were exceptional .
Sets the standard of Turkish mosque architecture. Hugh complex, beautiful interiors. love visiting the cementary behind the mosque.Do this with a guide for the great history of this mosque.

Agree it's a must-see. Take a guide who can tell you the finer points. I have a recommendation - university professor who is an expert on the history and architecture. Beautiful tile work which they can no longer make.
Must see in Istanbul. Fantastic impression inside. Beware that mosque is closed 1h during prayers a few times per day, so plan your visit.

the finest mosque in Istanbul. This mosque is not the most famous in Istanbul, but it is the best, and not crowded with tourists. It was designed by Sinan, the architect of Suleyman the Magnificient. This is the chosen site, where Sinan, Suleyman, and his wife are all buried.

Yes, awesome!!. This was truly fantastic! A highlight of the architect Sinan! After this, the Aya Sofia was a let down. Its grandeur and good state of preservation makes this a truly magnificent mosque. A++
Very different from the rest. Extremely well painted mosque, very different indoor from all the rest. Designed by a great architect of its time Sinan. It;s an attraction that must be seen in Istanbul

Majestic. This is not just a mosque but a "külliye" where there are also adjacent buildings which served as school (medrese), library and hospitals where both treatments and drugs were free for the public. Nowadays those adjacent buildings either serve as shops, restaurants or are empty. When compared with Blue Mosque, this one, where there are also tombs of Süleyman the Magnificent, his dear wife Roxalan (Hürrem Sultan) and many other dignitaries of the times, is less touristic but more majestic. The gardens and the graveyard are very serene and calm. The view from the back garden is breathtaking. It's forbidden to go up to the altar inside (except for locals who will pray) but still visiting inside is very impressive as well.
Unique. This mosque was incredible. It was very welcoming to tourists, with the only restrictions being during daily prayer. The scale of this mosque is incredible and certainly worth a visit.

A Less Touristy Mosque, Thus a Favorite. Far less crowded, and far less touristy than The Blue Mosque, this one was my favorite mosque in Turkey - and I'm not even a Moslem. It was quiet serene when I was there, and my travel buddies could solemnly spent some time inside for praying. The view and the weather were perfect on July. Around the mosque were great food places and small shops.

A great feat!. This Ottoman Imperial Mosque commissioned by Sulaiman the Great and executed by the famous architect Sinan is simply majestic! As you enter the large open space of the mosque you cant help but be stunned by the vastness of space and the light flooding the area through the many windows in its large dome. Interestingly the tomb of Sinan is also in the premises as are the tombs of Suliman and his wife. The Sultans tomb was closed " for security reasons" but a peak through the wooden trellis gives a good view of the several tombs inside. I was somewhat mesmerized by this sight.the visit to this can be coupled with a visit to the Grand Bazar. The little back street leading to the mosque area from the Bazar makes an interesting walk. There are several craft shops where the artisans are at work. There is also a cute little restaurant which serves an excellent and very reasonably priced turkish meal.

Not as Old, Just as Wonderful. This mosque is a bit away from the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia but is just about as dazzling. The tile work and marble alone are worth the visit to this vast and peaceful space. Awe-inspiring is the best description.

Amazing mosque, just breakthtaking.. We visited this mosque which is also called the Blue Mosque in November 2013. Ladies must wear a headscarf and you remove your shoes on entry. The mosque is just breath-taking. The ceilings are elaborately decorated. The traditional carpet is soft underfoot with a traditional pattern with lines marking out the prayer positions. The windows were beautiful stained glass. Just everywhere you looked the architecture and decorations were just stunning. A very calm atmosphere prevailed in the mosque.

Don't miss this beautiful mosque. Whilst the Blue mosque captures the tour groups and the crowds, this is a very special place of worship - the architecture, the beautiful stonework and soft colours, the mosaics and the surrounding gardens are magical - truly worth a visit or two.
The best of the best. This mosque is not necessarily on the map for those who visit Istanbul, but is the best of them all. A beautiful jewelbox.

Fantastic visit!!. The Blue Mosque should not be missed. It is an amazing building. The queues can be quite long but go either early or late in the afternoon. Also make sure you are dressed appropriately as there are certain rules you must follow out of respect. Men must wear trousers, no shorts or vest tops allowed. Women must wear trousers or long skirt, no vest tops allowed. Also women must cover their heads, you can either bring your own shawl or they will lend you one. Shoes also must be taken off before entering the mosque, they will give you a plastic bag to put them in before you enter. This is a truly magnificent place to visit both during the day and at night when it is all lit up!!
Must be seen. Do not miss this mosque - it is fantastic. Its history is equally interesting. Just remember that it is an active place of worship.

A must for anybody visiting Istanbul. A truly majestic mosque with a certain charm about it. The work into the architecture and construction of the building is truly astounding. So much beauty and history. I even loved just sitting on the steps in the court yard and just watching a whole array of life go by, very peaceful. At night it looks awesome and if you have the opportunity to dine on a roof terrace then do it! Views of the mosque and surrounding areas are stunning.
Visit. Well worth a visit. Go to see the views over the Bosphorus, the tombs and the grounds, as well as the wonderful mosque itself.

Stunning location at night. Visited this one evening and it was very pleasant as there many less people there than I can imagine during the day and no coach tours. Nice to be able to find a space to sit on the carpet and admire the building and soak up the peaceful atmosphere.

Uplifting. We had visited this mosque some 11 years ago, but decided it was a visit we should do again. We were not disappointed. If one wanted to spend some quiet time, this place is it! Just find a corner and relax and enjoy the beauty of the interior. Such vibrant and rich colours, and this can be seen in the carpets and and the domes and walls.
Overlooked treasure. Don't neglect this mosque! This is the first one I visited and it was certainly comparable to the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya

Stunning!. Vey well kept! Beautiful grounds, and interior and amazing views of Golden Horn Galata Bridge and Bosphorus. Not well signposted from Grand Bazaar but the locals were glad to help and point us in the right direction!

One of the Finest. For me, Suleymaniye mosque is the most beautiful of Turkey. With its high ceilings and colorfully placed tiles, everything was completed with execution. Compared to blue mosque which had hundreds of visitors in, Suleymaniye is much more peaceful where one can sit on the carpet flooring and lay back to admire the beauty of the mosque. For those visiting, do take note of prayer timings as they will be closed.

Outstanding piece of Art and Culture. I have visited the Mosque both, during the day and night and it was great and inspiring trip with many things which I learnt about Turkish people and Muslim religion. Spend some time sitting on the carpet and following how everybody is in the rush :)Don't forget to visit Muslim Information center, it's fun!
Impressive. You can't help but be impressed at the sheer scale of Sinan's creation and the surrounding buildings.

Architectural perfection. The calmness engendered by the clearly defined lines of the structure that did not intrude into the massive space. This fine ss of line extended into the courtyard and also the minarets which were sublime

You must not miss this!. We felt that this was the most stunning of the 3 largest mosques with a peaceful, less touristy atmosphere. Arrived just after Friday prayers but made to feel welcome by locals. This is a simply stunning place to see.

Stunning. Less busy and crowded than the Blue Mosque, and all the more stunning for it. The location was wonderful, and the views over the city from the North West corner of the garden were amazing. A shame that (as with many other Mosques at the moment) the tombs to the rear are closed for renovation, and rather surprisingly we were charged 5TYL entrance. I have absolutely no problem paying, but it was the one and only time this happened.
Worth the effort. I didn't look at my map very closely, so I wandered up the hill the mosque is on to find it. It is a steep climb, but the view from the grounds is fantastic. It is a lovely mosque.

nice place. This is a very nice and beautiful mosque in Istanbul. Less tourists than the Blue Mosque and you feel a bit more spiritual within these grounds. Another fab place within this wonderful city

Worth A Visit.. One huge advantage of this great mosque is that it's not too crowded. Architecture and style is similar to the "Blue Mosque". However, not a lot of tourists go there. So, you can have your time inside and you don't feel rushed. It's located close to the "Grand Bazaar". There's a tram station close to it as well.
Biggest Mosque in Istanbul. Well worth a visit. Close to the Grand Bazaar. Built by the greatest architect of the time Sinan. It is huge. Built in the 15 hundreds.

Suleymaniye Mosque. We discovered this mosque while exploring back streets as we do could not believe it rushed back to but a scarf to cover my head ,entered and stood in awe it is not stated as a main stream mosque by comparison with the Blue Mosque but just as moving and in a different way.

Enjoy the landscape and atmosphere of Mosque. Distinguish from Hagia Sophia, luxury and stunning, Suleymaniye Mosque has the quietness and atmosphere of Mosque. With tourists and still, you can see people really go to pray and visit Mosque in their daily life.Small Tips:1. Take a walk from Valens Aqueduct (Bozdoğan Kemeri in Turkish), you can pass and see daily life of Turkish people. 2. Walking to the back of Suleymaniye Mosque, you can have great view and landscape of Istanbul as well.

Beautiful Mosque and gardens. Not quite as grand as the Blue Mosque, but certainly breathtaking. Neat cemetery and mausoleums in the back but the interior is only visible through the windows due to security issues.

Must see mosque. I went to the mosque early and somehow got in before official opening time, so for 10 minutes was the only visitor, this emphasised the vast spaces and quiet atmosphere of this beautiful building. The interior decorations are immaculate, and well preserved. As with all the mosques in Istanbul don't rush the experience, take time to see the buildings and the locals who use them! But be respectful if taking photos. The area around the mosque has interesting architecture and history so take time and wander around.

Majestic Building. I visit the mosque very early in the morning. The environment is very soothing and calming. Very nice view & I reckon is a great place for a wedding photoshoot. At times, I even figure it is more beautiful than both Hagia Sophia & Sultanahmet Mosque!

Interesting experience. It's beautiful on the inside,but the gardens surrounding it are prettier. Make sure you're dressed appropriately,because they have a strict code. You'll have to take off your shoes. They give you plastic bags and it took us a while to figure out what exactly to do with them,I admit.
Amazing Building. Just Wow. This place is amazing. Beatifull building and architecture. Nearby are also the city walls and the spice market' so worths the walk. Must visit!

Hill of faith. One can see Suleymaniye mosque from the Metro as you ride toward the Grand Bazzar, it's on a hill but inside is elegant and simple the court yard has cafe's and people talking and resting. It's a place just to look and wonder.There are Tomb's here too.

Awesome space. This building is the triumph of the architect Sinan whose tomb is nearby. The complex of buildings and their service to the community still serve as a lesson to us today. the sense of space and calm is truly magnificent. thankfully, as it is not so easy to get to, it is not as over-run as the Blue Mosque.
Favorite mosque. Muted colors, lovely gardens, beautiful interior and lovely little things like the astronomers' window.

Amazing interior and surrounding. The area around the mosque was very pretty. It was filled with pink blossomed trees and small stands selling souvenirs and snacks (corn, watermelon..etc). Also there were cafes and shops. The mosque from the inside is really pretty but you need to be careful with what your wearing (dress conservatively) and do not go in the mosque during praying times unless you want to pray. And if you do want to pray then don't expect to be able to maintain your focus with all the beautiful architecture and design grabbing your attention. Worth a visit !

One of the most beautiful mosque's in the world. Getting off at Sultanahmet tram stop and a few moments walk to reach this magnificent mosque. No shorts or sleeveless tops are allowed and ladies need to cover their hair and unlike other countries, there are attendants there to provide necessary cover. Its a free experience, and you can sit in the mosque to admire the interior decors. After the blue mosque, you can easily walk over to HagiaSophia muesuem and Topkapi Palace.
Must-see. This mosque is in my opinion more beautiful on the outside than on the inside but is well worth visiting.
Amazing architecture. Beautiful mosque that must be seen. Dress appropriately and enjoy the architecture and beautiful recitation of the Imaam

A beautiful mosque , one must visit.. We went in Istanbul in May 2013. We stayed in Sultanahmet. During our visit to Istanbul we visited some good tourist attractions & Suleymaniye Mosque is one of them. It is beautiful mosque symbolising the pristine archtecturul heritage of the Ottoman era. It is located beside the Emononu Tram station opposite of Galata Bridge. Since the mosque is located at a very common tourist place , one must not miss the opportunity of visiting the same .
Quick visit. The "helpers" outside who insist showing you the way and expect then you to come to buy their carpets afterwards. When you decline, they become very rude.
Prettiest & largest Mosque in Istanbul. Suleymaniye Mosque is larger than the Blue Mosque and much newer built in 1558. Spectacular interior and not as crowded. Worth visiting!

Mimar Sinan's most famous. This is a beautiful, peaceful building was designed by TMimar Sinan. Sinan (c. 1489/1490 – July 17, 1588), the chief Ottoman architect (Turkish: "Mimar") and civil engineer for sultans Suleiman the Magnificent, Selim II, and Murad III. Sinan was responsible for the construction of more than three hundred major structures of which this mosque is the most famous. Relying on architectural design rather than decoration, this mosque is quite simply stunning. It is certainly worth visiting.

Magnificent. An absolute "must see" in Istanbul. Splendid architecture - outside and inside. Magnificent tiles and great cupolas. Actually a "world wonder". In order to get proper photos you need to take a super-wide angle lens along (e.g. 12 mm for the APX format). Also interesting the surroundings with simple restaurants, where you should definitely try the white bean stew, which everybody seems to consume when visiting this great mosque.

One of Sinan's masterpieces, and don't forget the visit the sultan's tomb next door. Great example of Mimar Sinan's genius of architecture. The mosque feels much more open than the Blue Mosque, and although it's not decorated as elaborate of that mosque, for me it looks nicer. Don't forget to visit the tombs of Sultan Suleyman and his favorite wife Roxalana (Hurrem Sultan) next to the mosque, they have exquisite examples of Iznik tiles.

tranquil and beautiful setting overlooking the sea.. Probably the best toilet facilities ever! The Mosque is quite spectacular and gave us an opportunity to meander around in a peaceful part of Istanbul away from the noise and heat. A coffee in the restaurants across the way finished our morning beautifully.

Suleymaniye Mosque. The Süleymaniye Mosque, built on the order of Sultan Süleyman (Süleyman the Magnificent), "was fortunate to be able to draw on the talents of the architectural genius of Mimar Sinan.This "vast religious complex called the Süleymaniye...blended Islamic and Byzantine architectural elements. It combines tall, slender minarets with large domed buildings supported by half domes in the style of the Byzantine. The Golden Horn view is magnificient.Must see.After the visit have a meal at Darüzziyafe.
This one is worth the hike.. Beautiful tiles in blues, greens, and purple. Near the university. Wonderful Turkish Bath nearby. Rich colors.

Too far out for taxi ride, not worth it. This is the first time a taxi ripped us off and we were let out at the mosque which was under construction. Had to walk towards town to get taxi back. I hear there is a much better mosque to see right by the Spice Bazaar.
Beautiful Mosque. I absolutely loved this mosque. Not as many tourists as Blue Mosque due to its location but such a beautiful mosque. Much bigger than Blue Mosque as well. Definitely worst a visit.

Beautifully renovated, feels like new. This mosque is not new although it looks that way. It has been renovated and is still partly going through that. Everything is clean and nice. Compared to the Blue Mosque this place is much more tranquil, there are hardly no tourists. Yet I found it much more pleasant than the Blue Mosque. Even the carpets are fresh and clean. Hope they stay that way. One of my favourite mosques.
A most see. This is a very beautiful mosque. I also remember thinking it smelt wonderful. The architecture is rich and captivating.

Gorgeous. but it smelled like feet. since they make you take off your shoes, but not your socks, and tourists have been walking about all day, it stands to reason. luckily we spent most of our time looking up, because if our noses had been at the carpet level...
Worth the walk. A little out of the way from the main tourist area of old Istanbul, but this wonderful mosque is much less crowded and every bit as impressive; don't miss viewing the graveyard.
a walking distance from Bazzar. a must see with a guide as a lot of details can be missed - this is a complex not just a Mosque - closed for lunch time friday

A must- see near spice market. By far, my favorite mosque in Turkey. For history and further details other reviewers have already elaborated with wonderful descriptions . I only wish to add that Suleymaniye Mosque should not be missed when visiting Sultanhemet, (Istanbul), Turkey. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

Suleiyman the Magnificent!. We had missed this on our first trip to Istanbul and were glad to have seen it on this one - I rate it better than the Blue Mosque - lighter, brighter, more uplifting and no crowds. A real stunner.
Beautiful!. This mosque is in far better state and condition than the Blue Mosque and the decoration inside is stunning!

Feel ancient Istanbul with respect. If you have watched "Muhtesem Yuzyil" (Magnificent Century) series you will double love this graceful place.It contains a very nice cemetery with tombs of Sultan Soleyman Han, Hurrem Sultan Han, Mihrimah Sultan han, Mihmit the prince, Hadice and other important persons of that slice of ottomans history.A portion of the Mosque is also open for tourists, if women's clothing is not appropriate for the mosque, a very polite security man will give them a clean pink scarf and a long skirt if needed.The atmosphere is great and architecture is amazing. If I go to istanbul again, I will visit this great cami (Mosque) again.
Beautiful structure. This is a really huge mosque built on huge grounds. Very few tourists made this a lovely venue to enjoy
Istanbul Mosque. The grounds of this mosque are lovely, as is the setting. The interior is not as spectacular as the Blue Mosque or the New Mosque, but be sure to not to miss this one.

Escape from the cruise ship tourists!. We had this mosque almost to ourselves - it's too far for the tour ship tourists to walk. A beautiful and serene mosque. When we visited, we weren't able to see the tombs in the graveyard outside - renovations.

really lovely. I loved the oil lamps and the tiles, so much to see here but I thought it was a bit small compared to some of the mosques however this doesn't take away from the beauty and understated splendour of this mosque.
one my fav in istanbul. it is a master piece of the talented Mimar Sinan . you will have the chance to enjoy the details and the peaceful environment in a less touristic destination mosque .
Lea Adelaide. Loved it. Certainly a must for Istanbul. We were on a Bunniks Tour and our guide was excellent in explaining all aspects.

Majestic. The largest mosque in Istanbul and the second largest in all of Turkey is a must. Built by one of Turkey's most famous architects, Sinan,I actually loved it from the inside even more than the Blue Mosque. Maybe I was impressed by the little boxes outlined on the carpet where men were to pray or perhaps it was just its tremendous size, either way I was in awe.

Peaceful and beautiful. Thus mosque is so peaceful and tranquil that it was tempting to simply stay there. Although we are not Muslim, there was a deep sense of peace and spirituality, and we did not feel like unwelcome or intrusive. The architecture is amazing and sensitive, and he space is so vast that the rich embellishments do nit become overwhelming, I would have liked to back a second time.

Steep climb to an impressive mosque. The downsid of this mosque that unless you are in a guided driven tour, no matter from where you come. You will have to climb some hills and the signs are not extremely helpful. A good map will help but as big as the mosque is, most funnily, you have to be either far away or very close by to really see it. The outside as well as the inside is spectacular, very bright and colourful so even not so expensive cameras will make nice pictures. Very nicely ornamented tiles all over. Oh, and a nice view over the golden horn.As always the rules for entering a mosque are to be applied, no shoes inside and decent dresscode. Next to it is the burial place of Sinan, worth a short stop for the guy who built such places.

Mimar Sinan Jewel. The simplicity of design and construction of this grand mosque is a architectural pleasure. We came at prayer time and waited to enter. The staff were very friendly and understanding of our non-Turkish friends. The mosque looks simple in design when compared with the Sultanahmet mosque because of the minimal use of tiles but the intricacies of construction make up for this. It is a marvel to visit.

Truly wonderful building. Compared with other famous sites in the city this was virtually empty and it is surely among the most beautiful buildings of any epoch anywhere in the world - certainly in my experience it merits the highest praise. Sublime and awe inspiring.
Calm . A beautiful mosque with a calm feel. It is not as crowded as the other mosques but special in its own way. I'd highly recommend seeing it while in Istanbul
Excellent Mosque,not so crowded. This was quieter than the blue mosque and a very good area to explore.Mosque itself was beautiful.Downside was it was a distance from our hotel -gulhane-we walked.

One of the place to visit in İstanbul. I went there more than 3 times and everytime i was there i had different feelings about the place and made me to think twice how people in that era were so rich in architecture. The mosque is so beautiful that you wont forget it in your istanbul memories...if you are muslim i recommend for you to get inside and pray your 2 rakat of sunnah.

Beautiful !!. Loved this mosque. Not as elaborate and grand as the Blue Mosque, but beautiful in its own way. Best part is, it's not as crowded. Spent an hour sitting inside peacefully and admiring the architecture, and enjoying the serenity. Must visit !

The mosque of all mosques. Designed by Sinan himself, it was made as a counterpoint to the Haghia Sophia, in order to show that the Ottoman empire could build as well as the 5th century Romans. Unfortunately, the skilled workers or the knowledge of stonework had disapeared in Constantinople by then.Never fear, Sinan had other options, and constructed a heavily domed mosque with an amazing sense of earthiness and sacredness, a very large open space for worship, and some of the best tilemakers in the empire were recruited for the project. The result is what is called the Blue Mosque, the most magnificent mosque in Istanbul, and one to match almost any in any part of the world. It features high ceilings, low oil lamps on very long ropes, and tree like columns to support the dome and demi domes that make up the ceiling. Did I mention the beautiful tiles, both calligraphic and graphic, or the sight of thousands of square feet of floor covered in beautiful turkish rugs? It is best to visit during prayer time, and participate. it;s not hard to take off ones shoes, and do what the Muslims do, leaving out the singing. it gives you an idea of the PURPOSE of the building, and it is still very much used. It is a key to Learning about Istanbul.

BEST TIME TO VISIT. I visited this beautiful mosque at least 3 times ,,twice during the day time and once in the evening If you want to see and appreciate the architect of this fabulous mosque go,in the evening It is open till 9 pm nobody to disturb you if you want to take photographs Also in the evening it gets illuminated the lighting effect is simply from out of this world Also very peaceful and tranquil in the evening

Well Worth A Visit. This beautiful mosque is far less crowded that the Blue Mosque and in many ways is nicer. The grounds are peaceful and lovely and the architecture is wonderful. It lacks the extensive tile work of the Blue Mosque but makes up for that with excellently restored and preserved woodwork and ceilings.This has a far less touristy feel than the Blue Mosque and is well worth visiting.

Quick Stop. The devil is in the details, and boy does this place have details! The line-up went really quick, which was great. If you don't have something to cover yourself with, don't fret, they have everything you need. They won't let you in with a skirt (knee length or shorter), no sleeves or head covering. They offer all these at the entrance. There isn't overly much to do if you're not going for the prayer, but you can definitely spend 5-10 minutes just gawking at the beauty. Take lots of photos!

A good walk. A beautiful mosque, with a good hike to get to it. Timber houses are also in this area. Not quite as good as other mosques we visited. BTW, make sure you bring a scarf (or buy one) because you have to wear a scarf into all the mosques.

Serene splendor. This was the first mosque we discovered on our wanderings about Istanbul and what an architectural masterpiece it was! Without the crowds from the ships you can actually enjoy the spaciousness and beauty of this building of worship. Don't miss this
So peaceful. This mosque is less spectacular thatn the Blue Mosque and Hagir Sofia but so peaceful. It is worth a visit.
Mosque. Amazing work of architecture n history. Crazy crowds inside and outside too busy to enjoy any spiritual ambience
Beautiful Mosque. Although this mosque is less visited, it was very beautiful and should not be missed. It is in very good condition and has elegant tile work and vaulted ceilings.

My favourite mosque. Wonderful atmosphere here, with much of the mosque having been renovated and cleaned. The carpet was a pleasure to walk on in stocking soles. The stained-glass windows are so beautiful giving a very light air to this very large building.

Look for the Turbans. This is the type of place where you want to pick up a guide or take a good guide book as there are many symbols that need translating. For example, all the turbans on the tombs.....

Beautiful mosque. It is huge inside, very ornately decorated, really beautiful. You have to remember though it is a mosque and that women have to wear a headscarf and either long skirt or trousers and that men have to wear trousers not shorts
Visit to Mosque. Fantastic experience ,really wonderful and historic. Clean and precious and very helpful people. We walked to the mosque and it was a pleasant walk.

A spiritual masterpiece.. I am not a follower of any religion but I think that this building is one of the greatest attempts by mankind to put ordinary people in touch with a sense of spirituality. It is definitely worth finding if you are in Istanbul. A simple lunch of beans and rice at one of the open air restaurants outside the mosque is very pleasant as well.

Well worth a visit, and not too crowded. Very impressive both outside and inside, and only a fairly short walk from the Grand Bazaar (a little further from the historic centre). It had many fewer people in it than the Blue Mosque and so had much more of a sense of being a place of worship. Good cheap cafe just outside it too.

Certainly worth visiting. Guide recommended going here because the Blue Mosque was very busy. Not many people here and really enjoyed it. Was also recommended to go here by another guide we met at the hotel.
Nice. good experience! we came around 8pm and there was no line! mind it, because in a day time you ll have to queue for long time!

Quiet and peaceful, but nothing much to see. If you've spent time in the main Sultanahmet area and visited the Blue Mosque, I'd say it isn't worth the effort walking all the way to the Suleymaniye Mosque. It's a bit of a walk from the tram line (this is to the north west of Grand Bazaar) and there really isn't much to see. It's a large, calm and peaceful place, with some nice paintings and ceramic work. You might just wanna peek in and out for a few minutes if you're around that area.
Amazing location. Beautiful inside and out with great views of the city. Sample some turkish tea across from the mosque and admire the tranquil area and beauty of the mosque
blue tiles. its blue china tiles are very beautiful. so beautiful interior. you need to close your head and wear long clothes.
peaceful.... Amazing how they could built such a monument in those days, a nice peaceful stop after our walk up the hill from the spice bazaar!
Fewer crowds but just as wonderous. Off the beaten path but certainly worth finding. Definitely less crowded than the bigger attraction mosques in the city. Beautiful. Not far from the Grand Bazaar.

Probably the most beautiful Mosque we saw. When one says Istanbul one thinks Blue Mosque but the Suleymane Mosque is absolutely beautiful. We happened to see a TV program about Suleyman a few weeks before our trip and decided to put the Mosque on our "to see" list. We did not regret it.

authentic. less crowded than sultanahmet mosque,and the surrounding buildings give you a pretty good idea about medieval islam, some of the buildings have been converted into a nice restaurant and terraces, and from the mosque garden you have a nice view over the golden horn
More Beautiful than the Blue Mosque. Not as easy to get to as the Blue Mosque which means it is far less crowded. Far and away the most most beautiful mosque in Istanbul.
Serene oasis. Quite a contrast to the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. Definitely a mosque to include in your Istanbul "to see" list.

Not quite as grand as the Blue mosque but beautiful all the same. Worth taking a detour to see the Suleymaniye Mosque (it is north of the Bazaar) , it is simpler than the more famous Blue Mosque but beautiful all the same.

The place in Istanbul I remember best. After nearly one year in Istanbul I remeber the Suleymaniye mosque best of all attractions. It is magnificent, calm, beatifully simple and serene. Few tourists (in contrast to the Blue mosque).Outside:impressive view over the Golden Horn and parts of Istanbul. There is also a cementary and the tombs of Suleyman and his wife Roxelana (closed for renovation when we were there, nov -12)After the visit to the mosque we had coffe in a small eatery opposite the main entrance. They also served cheap lunch of beans and rice.

Interesting. Interesting.You need to cover your arms and head, so women need scarf etcthey will give you a blue cloth if you don't have any of your own.Lovely mosaics.There was a man vacuuming the huge carpet the whole time we were there, this took away any religious reverence that you could have had.The overwhelming smell of sweaty feet was revolting .Who knows what it smells like in the afternoons.Worth a visit.

Avoid the crowds. Although there are only 4 minarets (vice 6), the interior decoration is every bit as spectacular as the Blue Mosque and you can actually relax and enjoy it. No line to stand in to enter the mosque and no crowds inside pushing and shoving and getting in the way of your pictures.

holy. Suleymaniye Mosque is more like the sultanahmet mosque in design but less tourists so it feels nice just praying at the mosque.the imam has a good voice when reciting.i was here for hours without realizing. time just flies in this old calm masjid

A real oasis of peace. Something really appealed to me about this magnificent piece of architecture that I cannot put my finger on. Whether it was the openness of the grounds in which it stands or the beautiful pink inlaid stonework, the light cascading in through the ornate stained windows it exuded a peace,tranquility and cool which countered the hectic hustle and bustle going on in the surrounding streets. Recommended
The tiles are lovely. It is worth the scarf and the shoe covers. I loved just standing and soaking up the atmosphere. I felt a bit rude being a tourist inA place of worship.

Suleyman outclasses Solomon. The largest Mosque in Istanbul celebrates the great Sultan under whose 46-year rule the Ottoman Empire reached its zenith. He has often been compared with the biblical King Solomon, and this mosque with the 1st Temple of Jerusalem that the latter constructed. It is an enormous complex sitting prominently on one of the 7 hills of the city. The Mosque is of course the main edifice, and it is approached through a splendid large courtyard containing a central fountain (that rarely operates) and some fine blue ceramic tiles. Four towering Minarets testify to his being the 4th ruler of the conquered city, and each has 10 external galleries signifying that he was the 10th Sultan of the Ottoman dynasty.As in all Mosques, you must take off your shoes before entering, and women must wear a head scarf. Once inside, the enormity of the interior is overwhelming. The magnificent dome is supported by 4 enormous pillars referred to as "elephants legs" and by 4 half-domes. The decoration is sparse and understated, comprising calligraphy panels, some sparkling stained glass windows, a pulpit for the Imam, and a section known as the "monastery" that is separated from the rest of the interior by a beautifully wrought grille covered in gold. The interior, that was dark and dull during our last visit 26 years ago, is now bright and shining after a renovation during which the original historic carpet were removed to a museum, and replaced by a single uniform carpet of uninteresting design and no artistic merit.We next saw briefly the cemetery and the Mausoleums in which Suleyman and Roxane (his favourite wife) are buried. We had a quick glance at the exteriors of the Koranic School, the Hospital, and the huge Kitchen that was the city's "food bank." It is remarkable what a civilizing force Islam proved to be in those times.
amazing.... is intresting and very beautiful mosque.aww....need a deep breath when you see this magnificant Mosque.....

Powerful and serene. This tranquil mosque is a functioning mosque (women cover heads and shoulders and knees and all remove shoes) and it is the opposite of the Blue Mosque in every respect. Powerful architecture utilizing straight lines greet the visitr in the court yard. Also the absence of a riot of colors is striking; the colors here are more muted and subdued. The inside is more painted than tiled (again a contrast to the Blue Mosque) and its simplistic but strong lines evoke understated power.If you are fortunate to have a Muslim guide, you will also learn much about the Islamic faith and the variety of ways the population finds to practice it. The cleansing ritual includes readying the individual for the spiritual experience.

Amazing. Every piece and centimeter of it is a real jewel .. love it to the max .. the colors, the cieling which is a masterpiece .. the whole atmosphere it's so wonderful and gives you peace of mind!

spectacular place. Beautiful structure both outside and in - great place to people watch in the inside square. Try to time your visit so it's not prayer time, in which case it closes for maybe an hour.

The Best. Our guide Lale from SRM Travel took us here instead of the Blue Mosque. Much better. Less crowded, more exquisite. Got to experience some of the serenity one would hope in such a holy place,

A haven of peace. This was a real bonus, after going to the very crowded Blue Mosque and Haghia Sophia. It's not quite as big as the Blue Mosque, but it made up for that with its sheer atmosphere. Quiet, peaceful and serene, with just a handful of tourists there. I'd advise anyone visiting Istanbul to see the outside of the Blue Mosque and then go to this place to see the interior
Magnificent. To me it was more lovely inside than the Blue Mosque. The tile work, the plan and the details were indeed magnificent

Beautiful mosque for all to enjoy. Fantastic to visit, regardless of whether you are muslim. Beautiful building and grounds. Visitors are segregated from the area for believers to pray in, but have a large area to get multiple views of the inside of the building.Visitor entrance is a well-oiled machine, providing bags for shoes and covers for lady's hair and shoulders. Wear socks if you can. Both men and women are allowed to access the visitor's area - no gender segregation concerns.

Istanbul. The Suleymaniye Mosque is a must. It is exquisit and you will nver experience another mosque like it, not even the Blue Mosque. It is in perfect condition and is massive. It's right up the hill from the Grand Bizar and the Spice Market so perfectly located if you are planning to visit either of these two "must see's"

Our first time in a Mosque. We waited until it opened after prayers, and then visited with our shoes off, and enjoyed the intricacy of the tile work, and the sense of genuine religious belief. Wearing a scarf around ones legs below the knee seems to be a bit over the top, but, it's the style of the mosque and it's members, so we did it. A Must see, for us.

Less crowds just as impressive and peaceful. Our group of 6 stopped here after the Blue Mosque and the New Mosque. Compare to the queues, this is relatively calm and peace. There were no lines, just a few people at the entrance removing shoes. As like the other mosques, women have to cover the head with scarf. No bare shoulders and legs.Beautiful interior. Gives a sense of peace and serenity.

Wonderful Mosque to visit in Istanbul. Whereas everyone visits the Blue Mosque in Sultanahmet, also see the Suleymaniye Mosque. It's not so crowded, has a defined history of a great ruler of the city, and beautifully maintained. The arches, frescos and paintings are worth a detailed look, and you get a great opportunity here, as compared to the Blue Mosque, which also has astonishingly wonderful stuff, but you can't concentrate hard due to the crowds.Do ask for the prayer schedule before going, as visitors are not allowed at the prayer times.

Big Blue & Beautiful. The inside of this mosque is just as amazing as it's wonderful exterior. Well worth lining up for. Just beware of friendly locals who will get you in the side door, they probably have a cousin with a carpet shop.

Impressive. Every photo of Turkey shows the Suleymanie Mosque and it is indeed very impressive. The inside is beautiful, especially the domes and the arches and the fresco's and paintings. However I would say that the mosque has a simplicity about it. I was amazed at how clean and luxurious the carpet was. Naturally you have to remove your shoes before entering AND women have to cover their heads but with thousands and thousands of people walking over that carpet is is in immaculate condition. A lovely experience.

A big active mosque. Check the prayer schedule as viewing is closed to non-worshippers. It has beautiful blue tiles which is why Westerners call it the Blue Mosque. An easy walk from the Hagia Sophia and continue on to the Grand Bazaar.

Suleymaniye Mosque. Loved it and loved all of the mosques there. Good proximity to the Grand Bazaar. People in Istanbul think everything is a 10 minute walk away when in fact it is 20-30 minutes walk. I made the mistake of walking from there to Sultanahmet - best to use the tram.

Exquisite!. Built by the great Suleiman the Magnificient, the Suleymaniye Mosque must be one of the most beautiful mosques in the world. Tourists in Istanbul often see only the Blue Mosque, which is a shame. It's just beyond the Grand Bazaar - ask and people will point it out.

"Blue" mosque is gorgeous. This is a must see attraction when in Istanbul. Ladies, be sure to have ankles and shoulders covered as well as a head scarf. If you forget, they have some at the door to borrow, but I do not know if they are cleaned after each use so it is your call! The tile work is beautiful, and a rare chance to see the inside of a mosque for those that are not Muslim.
Suleyman Mosq. You will have to climb a little through the small and crowded streets,but it is worth!Dimensions,the beauty of it ,the courtyard,very,very impressive.
simply beautiful. a must see in Istanbul - absolutely stunning. It really is blue inside! Remember to take your shoes off when you step onto the raised platform
Peaceful. THis mosque was peaceful and inviting and a beautiful, wonderful architectural feat! Felt much calmer than the famed blue mosque and it has great views from the grounds of the city.
Beautiful Blue Mosque. This is a must see venue during any visit to Istanbul. The architecture is stunning.There is no entry fee and non Muslims are free to visit the mosque
Must see pearl. It is a little out of the way but we were glad that we made the trip. Not very busy and great interior. A lot simpler than other more well known mosques.
Stunning. A must-go on your stay in Istanbul. Beautiful courtyard, fabulous from the inside. Because of the religious respect you should be clothed properly.

The most beautiful mosque ever!. This mosque is huge! and a visit is a must!
It is absolutely gorgeous from inside! The architecture, paintings, etc. is a delight to see! Much more beautiful than the Blue Mosque!

So huge and extraordinary. Called blue mosque because of its interior blue tile decorations, it is a wonderful place to visit. It is free of charge and that makes it so busy. There is a long long queue outside the mosque in the yard. It goes around the yard. But it moves quickly. Ladies should cover their head when entering the mosque. You can find a lot of information on this site through different apps n websites. But no body can tell you how your visit can be more enjoyable when walking through a handicraft bazzar around the mosque. It is quite an experience. Then walk through the narrow stones carpeted lanes towards the sea.

Tranquility and grandeur combined. As the Mosque is situated on a hill there is an uphill walk. Feeling lazy that day we took a cab which dropped us right outside the gate. There are two entrances, one for those worshipping and the other for visitors. Entrance is free.When we visited (just before noon) the Mosque wasn't too busy. Like the Blue Mosque a lot of the inside area was partitioned off for those praying.There was a calmness within the building which we didn't feel in Blue Mosque and this continued to the outside courtyard.This didn't feel so much like a tourist trap but more of a 'working' mosque which welcomed visitors.

Beautiful and not crowded. Our family of five walked to this mosque on a Sunday morning. We followed our map and the directional signs, but it was still a little tricky to find and my husband wasn't too comfortable with the area. The entrance we found was in a little alcove and would have been missed had it not been for our 10 year old who always walks slower than the rest of us. Once in the courtyard the building is safe and beautiful. There were only four or five other families there so we got a really good look. It is definitely worth visiting. It is not far from the Grand Bazaar so you can work it in on the same day as it won't take too long to see.
Good thing to visit. Not so crowded and much more beautiful than the more famous Blue Mosque.Very nice view of Galata bridge and the city from its north-east corner..

An impressive Mosque. This is on one of the seven hills around the Golden Horn and dominates the landscape with a good view looking towards the Horn. The Mosque is very grand and impressive inside in terms of size with great stained glass windows.

The prince of believers. When entering the Sulaymaniyah Cami u will feel the presence of the prince of believers sultan Suleyman ( may god rest his soul). The grand of the place is breath taking and the interior shows the excellence of craftsmen's ship during his Ryan . We tried to enter his turba alas it was under reconstruction,so we read the Al- Fatyah for him and his family form the Cami . U can reach the Sulaymaniyah Cami by taking a taxi from the spice bazaar . It will cost u around 14 TL for a round trip . Hope you visit it for it is a grand Cami for a grand prince of believers.

worth of your attention. The Süleymaniye Mosque is an Ottoman imperial mosque located on the Third Hill of Istanbul. It is the largest mosque in the city, and one of the best-known sights of Istanbul. The construction work began in 1550 and the mosque was finished in 1558. several times suffered a fire and even an earthquake once.it seems to be indestructible, and that is your reason for visiting it!

Peaceful and worth a visit. Beautiful Mosque, not quite rivalling the Blue Mosque in terms of grandeur inside but so beautiful and peaceful with far fewer crowds trying to get in that I preferred it. Combine with a trip to the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar for a good day trip.
Stunning. Loved this mosque. A bit of a queue to get in but definitely worth visiting. Make sure you are adequately covered to visit the mosque. They have scarves available for tourists.
Massive. This is just a massive, amazing mosque. Worth visiting.The provide coverups for folks not dressed appropriately.

WOW. The Blue Mosque is unreal... make sure to wear appropriate clothing, as this is a functioning mosque. They do have some things that you can put on in order to enter if you don't have the right clothing. It's very close to Aya Sophia as well so I would do both in the same day.

Very impressive mosque.. C1 ( 2013.08.09 ) There was very big and magnificent mosque. Many Islam prayed inside, and many tourist took a break in there. I was overwhelmed to see magnificent mosque. I went in mosque and talked with my friends comfortably about mosque. There was a good attraction to visit.
Beautiful Masjid. The view is beautiful as well as the size of this mosque. It is in the tourist area so you won't miss it. It's a manifestation of the Ottoman style in architecture

What to say.... I have visited a lot of mosques. I have visited a lot of beautiful places in Turkey that impressed me so much like Cappadocia, Pamukkale, Ephesus and more. All of them were very beautiful.But nothing impressed me like the interior, the dome of this mosque. I watched it for hours, i did not want to go out, i did not want to leave, i wanted to live and die there. I sit, watched and watched. For me, under this dome is the most beautiful place on earth.Now i want to see Selimiye mosque in Edirne, too.

Competition to the Blue Mosque. Equally as important to see as the Blue Mosque. It has been recently restored, and is in beautiful condition. Unfortunately, the tombs in the courtyard always seem to be closed `for security reasons`.

I like this airy and cheerful mosque !. A visit to Istanbul is not complete without a courtsey to this old venerable Mosque of Sulaiman (The Magnificent). I like this airy mosque with big windows and magnificent arches. One of the great works of Sinan.The tomb of this great king is hidden away in a little garden to the East of the mosque.Later we treated ourselves to a glorious lunch in a local kebabgi just accross the street to the east of Mosque compound. It is a family run business which served also lentil soup and fresh backed Meat covered bread (lahmacin).
The real mosque.. Agia Sofia is nice but this is a real Mosque and you can visit it.The ceiling and the carpet is amazing. The inner courtyard is typical of Moorish influence.

Magnificent building. Make sure you take a panoramic picture when inside the building. It used to be one of the 7 wonders of the world. Allow at least 2 hours to fully appreciate the architecture and observe the praying rituals. The mosque is closed to visitors during the praying times.

Most beautiful mosque of Istanbul. This is, by my opinion, most beautiful mosque of Istanbul. It is more beautiful than Blue Mosque, and there are much less visitors, so you can enjoy it in peace. And the courtyard is just magnificent.

Beautiful Building. Went in early evening - probably one of the prettiest buildings you will see. The courtyard is so relaxing and lovely place to sit outside and people watch. Nice cafes outside too.
Suleymaniye Mosque up to expectations. Not to be missed. A spectacular interior space and very attracive exterior. Go late in the day for smaller crowds.
NICE MOSQUE. the building & its style are fantastic, the arrangements around are well doneaccessible, views around are pretty

Must See. Recently cleaned, the mosque is splendid. Take a taxi, since the sight is very much an uphill climb. However, there were not many taxis around for the trip back to the hotel. But the walk is downhill. Serene courtyard, spacious with arched loggias. Evocative interior with graceful tilework. The Sultan's tomb in the cemetary area was unfortunately closed to visitors "for security reasons" when we were there in August 2013. This is the mosque one sees from everywhere in the city, on top of the highest hill. Definitely worth a visit to see the inside and the grounds.

Underwhelming and not much to see inside. After reading all of the five star reviews, I had high expectations. Upon entering the mosque, there is not much to see. The carpet is colorful but i was surprised to find out it is machine made. Five minutes inside is all you need. Not sure what the five star reviewers are looking at? It actually takes longer to pull your shoes on and off than to tour the inside. The Blue Mosque is similar - impressive from the outside but underwhelming on the inside. This is my overall conclusion on Istanbul - impressive from a distance but up close it is dirty and full of hard selling salesman trying to prey on tourists. I do not recommend Istanbul - it needs to be cleaned up - both the trash and the salesman!

Beautiful and historical. We really enjoyed our visit to the blue Mosque as this is called. We had a wonderful guide who gave us lots of acts and historical perspective on the mosque. It's right across from the Hayia Sophia Church and they can easily be seen together. Be prepared to take off your shoes and rent a long scarf head covering if you're female. You can't go in wearing shorts, whether male or female.
superb. what can I say? lots of history, magnificent lights, a man singing from the distance...a must see for everyone

Quiet and Colourful. Without the decadence so to speak of the Sultanahment Mosque but with more colour and character,unfortunatly Suleymaniye tomb was closed but the mosque itself is wort a look, even if just to sample another area of Istanbul.

Home of the Sufis- whirling dervishes. Very interesting inside, lots of bright blue and gold. There is a casket with the a main adherent of the religion on an altar that has in intricate large hat on top of it. The hat is probably about 30 inches high and I found it fascinating. Wish we had been able to take pictures there

Most beautiful mosk of Istanbul. The most beautiful mosque of Istanbul is from the Ottomanian architect Sinan. His tomb is just outside the mosque. It is build in only 7 years (1550 - 1557). It is a little bit smaller then the Hagia Sofia, but high on the hill, it looks bigger. When you in there, look for the ostrich eggs, between the lamps. They are there to prevent spiders to make a web.Because of the many windows, it is much lighter then in the Hagia Sofia.When you walk around the mosque, you will see a traditional restaurant and a very quiet and pleasant tea house
Not just another mosque. Beautiful and historic, an icon to the people of the city. Not to be missed. And easily walkable in the city.
Splendid Mosque. Splendid Mosque with historical construction. It's a huge mosque remaining for many years since Ottoman's rules.
Beautiful. Be careful when you visit, after a long walk to get there it was prayer time and we couldn't go in...the views from the grounds are worth the visit though
Walk to the Sulymaniye Mosque. Just a 20 - 30 minute walk from the Grand Bazaar. Well worth the walk. It is beautiful inside. The tombs behind the mosque are interesting to see as well
Awe inspiring!. Magnificent architectural structure. Hard to imagine that it has stood for millennium! Beautiful experience.

Even more stunning in reality. Seen this so many time on TV in various documentaries and was not disappointed. It is absolutely awe inspiring. The sheer magnitude of the inside is sometimes over whelming. This is a must see when in Istanbul. Plan for at least 2 hours if you are on a tight time schedule. Really words can do this any real justice.
Over-rated. I had heard it was a beautiful mosque. It may be architecturally perfect but nothing special. A bit secluded so it is easier to pray here.

Beautiful. The most beautiful masjid I visited in Istanbul. It's not as impresisve on the outside as the blue mosque. But definitely worth a visit as it is much more beautiful on the inside in my opinion and is less crowded too than the blue mosque. Less tourists :)

Sinan, the great Mosque architect. Im obsessed with any mosque designed by Sinan. h was the grea Suleyman the Magnificent wanted a mosque qppropriate to his title. He commissioned architect Mimar Sinan to build the Suleymaniye Mosque which was completed in 1557. The mosque had a madrasa, houses, infirmaries, caravansarais, a medical school, hamams, a Hadeth school, a hospital and shops. It is the largest mosque in Istanbul. The Suleymaniye Mosque is a beautiful example of Ottoman Islāmic architecture. There is a wonderful light spiritual feeling inside. (inner courtyard, recycled columns, interior, exterior view)t architect of Istanbul.
Very worthwhile. History and architecture are very interesting. Not as good as the Blue Mosque, but definately one of the top 10 attractions.

Very nice indeed!. The grounds were very quiet when we visited the mosque making it that more impressive. This is a very good example of Ottoman architecture and great place for photos. Though, this is not the most impressive in town, it should be on your list if you want to see awesome mosque examples.

Probably the most stunning mosque I have ever seen. Probably the most stunning mosque I have ever seen. Not the most famous, but the biggest in Istanbul, and its beaty makes it one of the top places in Istanbul.Moreover it is not as crowded as other MUST SEE in the city.

peaceful graceful and away from the crowd. Like you, I read about Suleymaniye Mosque, on the web. I was not prepared for such a beautiful and peaceful site. We went first thing in the morning. The courtyard was empty and very few people inside. It was grandiose.
A must see !. Amazing place the art work and the colors are is outstanding and the impressive hight of the domes are impressive. An absolute must see .
Amazing. Beautiful architecture and the interior is even better than the blue mosque! It has been restored well.

Impressive and living. Arrive well before closing time. Foreign ladies don't forget your head scarf and long dress (or be prepared to don a generic garb). A stroll in the environs may be well worth your time and you may even be able to catch a glimpse of the city from high up there.
The interior is very impressive.

Must visit when going to Bosporus. It was on our list of mosques to visit, close to eminue, and defenetly something to see.
Beautiful inside and out...well organized, free, historical... What else to wish for..
Many pictures taken. Don't forget to visit spice bazaar at the end!

Just going to say it, liked it more than the Blue mosque.. Suleymaniye mosque is gorgeous, the colours are unique and the dome is spectacular.
