Having lived in Istanbul for four years and now returning as a tourist I can honestly say the beautiful blue mosque loses its appeal when packed full and smelling offensively of sweaty feet. Walked to Sulemaniye (up the hill through the real Turkish shopping district from eminonu- do it if you want to feel your legs burn or alternatively just across from sultanahmet) and felt like I'd walked into an oasis - spent a good hour relaxing in the mosque and and in the gardens outside. Bring a book. There is plenty of cheap food around if you wander a few mins from the mosque. Loved it.

i don't want to offend anyone, but...... am i missing something? architecturally interesting. interior, not so much. it was the first attraction on the map we encountered. i was hoping it would be grand inside but it wasn't. it was very lackluster and smelled of feet. not what i wanted to deal with that early in the morning, jet-lagged and hungry, and in the heat.
Nice. Great site. Not as crowded ax the Blue Mosque and not as magnificent as Hagia Sophia. If you are close by drop in. Nice grounds too.

A part of history. Enjoyed again seeing the Suleymaniye which a part of Turkyie heritage. Although we came late and the mausoleums were closed, we still had a good view through the windows. Visit the mosque and walk around the old hospital and various accommodations, kitchen and mess halls. Part of the complex is under renovation

Very impressive Mosque design. Although most of the reviews showing that Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque are the best attractions in istanbul, I think Sulymaniya Mosque is equal to Blue mosque as an important attraction in Istanbul and must visited specially the cemety beside the mosque.
A beautiful mosque. Lovely mosque in typical Turkish architecture. So much history over five hundred years old. Amazing!
Excellent. The mosque is very well maintained, a true lesson of history. The view is excellent, a nice and relaxing location.

Beautiful and so peaceful. This mosque was not on my visiting list a first, but I was just find out on the last day of my stay, so I decide to pay a visit. This mosque was so beautiful and very peaceful. It wasn't that hard to get to the place. Very recommended!

master piece. every detail is satisfied ;for Muslims a must place to visit ,do prayer,sit and meditate ,feel the great architeche of the Universe
with the help of big arhitech Sinan :-)

we found this the loveliest of the three main mosques in Istanbul. very deightful interior, lovely call to prayers,... with charming square outside....great ophoto opportunity.. don't forget to be covered up for entry

Beautiful Mosque. Its a beautiful Mosque, you can view the inner courtyard prior to going inside the Mosque (they will ask you to take off your shoes and wear a head scarf, show bags and head scarves are available), its beautiful from the inside, Must Visit for anyone going to Istanbul!

Another great mosque in the city. This mosque had a newer feel to it inside than the others we visited in the city. It was not nearly as crowded. Again, there were restorations going on around the masjid so it made it a little trickier to get in and out of, but it was still a great experience.

Outstanding architecture. Went initially during the tail end of the Eid festival and the crowds were horendous as well as being excluded due to prayers (need to ensure the visit doesn't coincide with religious holidays). Definitely a must to visit but remember the suitability of clothing being worn and the need to remove shoes. Be prepared for long queues exposed to the sun but afterwards recollect the splendour of its construction, amazing glass windows, devotion of the worshippers and the many local people anxious to alert you to opening times and standards of dress.

The largest mosque in Istanbul.. Süleymaniye Mosque is the largest mosque in Istanbul. Pictures are amazing. It’s probably one of the best-known sights for tourists visiting Istanbul. You just need to find out about pray time to organize your visit. Men need to wear pants. They provide scarves for women, though it is probably more interesting (e.g. cleaner) to have your own. Easy to go in and out, though. We took lots of pictures.
A big Mosque!. If you are into Mosque viewing this is one of the best - and there are many in Istanbul. Again - watch out for queues; go later in the day.

worth to visit. around 15 min walk from Grand bazaar..but after seeing the blue mosque with all the crowd and too many chains hanging from its ceiling...this mosque is so different it is peaceful and so beautiful it just look new from inside,, its free closed during praying time..code of dress apply.Don't forget to visit the graves of Sultan Suleyman and his hareem next to the mosque. a must to visit for ppl who are watching Sultan Suleyman soap-opera on TV
amazing architecture. amazing architecture by architect sinaneddin yusuf. also wonderful view for istanbul and bosphorus :D
Sinan's masterpiece. The absolute apex of Ottoman architectural achievement and a Sinan masterpiece. Only bettered by his final mosque in Edirne. Forget the Blue one!
Breathtaking. We loved the experience from dressing up properly to go in to just walking about the outside and seeing it from all angles, day and night.
Suleymaniye mosque. well worth the uphill walk in temps over 35 degrees! beautiful architecture and a cool peaceful courtyard.

Very special and under-rated. Whereas the Blue Mosque is always crowded and feels too much like just another tourist attraction, the Suleymaniye Mosque is a serene and dignified place. To my mind, although it is somewhat less ornate than the Blue Mosque, it is much more beautiful. And no matter what your religion, or even if you are completely non-religious as I am, you will feel that it is a sacred place. Highly recommended! If you are staying in Sultanahmet, the walk to Suleymaniye Mosque is an experience in itself, and we thoroughly enjoyed continuing the walk down the hill to Galata Bridge.
the second best. Another mosque that you as muslim observer has to go. I love to see the people, the turist and the faithful people assist to the prayers.

Very Beautiful Mosque. I think this mosque is a beautiful mosque with many decorations that fulfill all over the places. This mosque is very quiet and cool atmosphere in it that makes a calm feeling when I was inside.

See this one first. If you have limited time for mosques, choose this one over the Blue Mosque. Architect Mimar Sinan's work is beautiful. The Blue Mosque is beautiful too, but you don't want to miss this one.

Need help to appreciate it. I visited this mosque after Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque on a Sunday afternoon. It is obviously of a much smaller scale, much less elaborately decorated. But it is a functioning mosque and are less crowded for tourist to feel the sacred religion. It also gives tourists a peek into local's life spending quality time with families. Outside of the mosque on the grass patch, there are many local families having picnic, and kids running around. Yet, from a non-Muslim tourist view point, I cannot fully appreciate the decorations and symbolism. There is no explanations and no audio guide.

This is the one Mosque that trums the Blue Mosque.. Our tour guide, Sinan Sokman of Istanbulite Tours suggested this, and he was right. It was a spectacular example of Ottoman architecture and much more interesting than the highly touted Blue Mosque. I loved it for its scale and simplicity. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful views impressive. Bit of a walk to get to it, but probably the best moqsue. The grounds are nice to relax in and a bit quieter than the other busy mosques. The views are also very impressive and it is then a short walk down to the Golden horn.
Amazing. Very nice!!! Definitely the most beautiful mosque in Istambul. The view from Eminunu boat station up to the hill and the mosque is amazing. For me it's really Istambul.
Courtyard lovely. This isn't the most gorgeous mosque inside, but the grounds and cemetery are beautiful. Certainly pop in if you are near it.
Much love. The views alone from the grounds are worth the trip, but the grandeur and peace of this place are what I most enjoyed. So glad I went!

The best. The.Best.Mosque.Ever!!!
I have visited all the major mosques in Istanbul and I've seen many others around the world. And here it is: Suleymaniye Mosque is the most beautiful and impressive piece of Muslim architecture I have ever layed eyes on. Bellissimo!

Beautiful mosque and a must when in Istanbul. This is a must when visiting Istanbul. Men must cover their knees (jeans or long bermuda shorts) and women must cover their legs, shoulders and hair. No need to worry as they provide you with the appropriate garment before entering. Really take the time to enjoy it and respect that there are people praying at times (although the mosque is closed to the public during regular prayer times).

Spiritual place. Suleymaniye Mosque has a very spiritual aura. It is constructed at the third hill (of the 7 hills of Istanbul). So the view is amazing from the mosque.We've seen the place night time, so with all the lights, the whole ambiance was very spiritual to me. It was more quite than the Blue Mosque (probably because many people don't like to walk the uphill). But the outcome is really rewarding, so wear your sneakers and walk. The mosque's name belongs to one of the greatest sultans of the Ottoman Empire. And I liked the symbolism used by the architect. For instance there are 4 minarets because Suleyman the magnificent is the 4th sultan to rule since they've took the city, we've been told. Or there are 10 minaret balconies because Suleyman the Magnificent is the 10th sultan to rule the Ottoman Empire.We've been told that Sultan was madly in love with his wife and both of their tombs are in the special garden, side by side.There are many details that makes this architecture interesting and more meaningful so I would advise a little bit of reading before the visit.Wear comfy, walking shoes and remember that this place is still a "praying" location so be considerate choosing your outfit for the day.

Tranquility. An awesome mosque! The beautiful gardens overlook the Golden Horn and the Bosphorus - fabulous views. Inside is tranquil and the coral marble is divine. The mosque complex is surrounded by the University of Istanbul and the shops adjoining the Grand Bazaar.

The best.. In my opinion, the Suleymaniye mosque was the best mosque we visited in Istanbul... more stately, relaxed and tranquil than the Blue Mosque. If there was one mosque to go to in Istanbul, this is the one I'd go to.Its not a very long walk from the Sultanahmet area (maybe 15-20 min)...but feels longer because of the uphill walk. Nevertheless, you will pass through some very interesting neighborhoods...There's an orange juice vendor right outside the mosque...for 1 TL, there is no better thirst quencher!We got to the mosque at around 5 PM...close to prayer time. This worked out very well for us. It gave us time to walk around the mosque complex and gardens. There were a bunch of kids playing soccer in the mosque grounds...all in all, made for a very interesting half hour before they opened the mosque to visitors. Bright insides... the lovely red and white/ silver border to the arches, the intricate calligraphy, the overall lack of crowds made the Suleymaniye Mosque my #1 attraction of Istanbul (The Chora Church comes a close second).
Beautiful. Awesome architecture and very quite. Actually preferred this to the Blue Mosque. Nice eateries just outside the compound and good to combine this with spice bazaar visit.
a Jewel of architecture. Nice mosque, an arichtecture jewel, in the vening it is amaizing to watch the light and to pray inside, very nice

best mosque from the inside. We went to the Blue Mosque the previous day and then came to Suleymaniye and were much more charmed by the exquisite interior. The area around the mosque is less touristy and has all types of stores including a district of fabric and tailoring stores so it was a long but fun walk uphill to get to the mosque. Sit on the floor in the visitor area and gaze up at the ceiling and then from one domed ceiling to the next and one wall to the next and one pillar to the next. Take your time, truly taking it all in. It is a feast for the eyes. At night during Ramadan (the month of fasting), they hang a message in lights between the minarets that we could see from our hotel room which added to our bias for this mosque over the Blue Mosque. Don't miss this one. It is a little bit off the Sultanahmet tourist circuit but still not that far away.
Absolutly Stunning. This place outdoes the Blue Mosque. Excellent views of the city. Tranquil setting. Only a short walk from the Grand Bazaar.
Fine, if you have the time. This Mosque is fine. It's really the graveyard that is interesting. I personally liked the Blue Mosque better. This is one is a bit difficult to get to.

Peaceful Mosque. This mosque is a little bit out of the way. We arrived during prayer time so waited in the beautiful gardens which was a nice break. There was no line to enter even though it was the middle of the day. The mosque itself is peaceful and we spend some time taking pictures and enjoying the peaceful atmosphere inside the mosque.I left my camera case somewhere inside the mosque by mistake, it contained my hotel room card and 100 lira. After back tracking and coming up empty handed, I approached the guard at the door because I felt sure that any tourist would have handed it in to a guard (as I would do). The guard at the door was very unhelpful. I went to check again and returned to the same guard to ask him again. He had been joined by another guard who I think must have been somewhere inside the mosque. I persisted and asked again and again describing my camera case over and over. Eventually the second guard pulled it out of his pants pocket! This left a sour taste for a lovely attraction. I agree with the other reviewer, I would not visit this attraction on foot after dark, the area surrounding the mosque seems a bit dodgy.
Worth a visit. It was brilliant. The architecture was fabulous. Worth a visit while visiting Istanbul. Every traveler should visit the Mosque

Beautiful and peaceful mosque. This was my favorite of several mosques visited in Turkey. There is a feeling of harmony, peace and serenity in the mosque and in the outer courtyards. It is well worth a visit.

A little oasis in the middle of Istanbul.. This mosque (and its grounds) is a little piece of tranquility in the middle of bustling Istanbul. Set up a little hill away from the madness below, it is less crowded, less maddening and less touristy than the Blue Mosque. Lots of places to sit all around inside the mosque and in the beautifully shaded gardens outside. What is unusual is that part of the ceiling is painted with a Trompe-l'œi effect and blends beautifully with the rest of the architecture. If you're looking for a bit of mid-afternoon peace, do yourself a favour and visit this place. The shops around this mosque and on-route to the Grand bazaar are also the cheapest (for a touristy area) in Istanbul for scarves, painted pottery and other souvenirs.

Suleymaniye. The Mosque is beautiful, but the area sourrounding it is a bit sketchy. My wife and I made it here on a couple of occasion, but both times we were a little unnerved by the seamingly empty streets and closed stores. We had no problems in the area, but neither of us felt entirely comfortable.

A less crowded Istanbul gem. This mosque is uphill and slightly further away from the more centrally located sights. As a result it is quieter and has a more tranquil ambience giving you more peace to enjoy it. Both the interior and exterior have recently been extensively renovated and as such is in beautiful condition. Photography is permitted without flash. Lovely views can be enjoyed from the grounds over Istanbul and the Bosphorus towards the suspension bridge.

Glad We Visited. A breathtaking wonder, the detail in its construction was truly incredible. While we were there we were able to watch a prayer service and a family celebrating their young son's circumcision. The hanging lighting in many of the mosques in Istanbul is very interesting, and this mosque was no different. The outer courtyard is also very large and impressive. The columns around the perimeter make a great setting for pictures. I found the Camii very fascinating and well worth the visit.

A better experience than the Blue Mosque. A number of reviewers have somehow confused the Blue Mosque (Sultanahmet) with Suleymaniye Mosque. This is too bad as Suleymaniye is, in my opinion, a much better experience.While not necessarily as dramatic as the Blue Mosque with its blue tiles, Suleymaniye more than makes up for this with it's tranquil setting and it's immense size. Nestled in behind Istanbul University this mosque draws only a fraction of the people that the Blue Mosque so it makes for a much more peaceful visit. Make sure to wander the grounds - large trees provide shade from the summer sun. There are also some nice cafes nearby to grab a bite to eat nearby including Darizziyafe Restaurant which you can easily reach by heading straight out of what would be the front door of the mosque courtyard, walking through the garden and out the gates then turning left on the street. Is is located on the right just a little bit of the way down.

Suleymaniye Mosque. Always confused with Blue mosque (Sultan Ahmed Mosque) is an Ottoman imperial. It is the largest mosque in the city, and one of the best-known sights of Istanbul. I loved this mosque as it wasn’t as crowed as blue mosque. The Spice bazaar (also less crowded than Grand Bazaar) is also closed by so make sure you take advantage of both and check them out.

Visiting the Blue Mosque. Visiting the Suleymaniye (known widely as the Blue Mosque) was amazing. There was no entrance fee. The expansive interior was beautiful, with thousands of Iznik tiles in blue dominating the interior. It was a peaceful place to visit.

Incredible. On my recent trip over seas I fell deep deep deep in love with mosques. My family and I saw the Blue Mosque the day before and it was absolutely stunning but it was so hard to enjoy because of the amount of tourists. If you are looking for a breath-taking mosque off the beaten path than look no further! There's so shopping to the side and I had one the best meals in Istanbul there too. It's a place that serves beans. Go there. It's delicious!
Magic place. Doesn't matter if you believe or not... You must enter! The atmosphere is fantastic for meditation...

Huge!. This one is definitely in competiton with the blue Mosque for the title of the biggest. You can see it from everywhere from the Bosphorus or from the Golden horn. A great Hammam is just beside and you can go with your spouse!

Beautifully Restored. The grounds and interior of this Mosque were lovely and much less crowded than some of the other sights we visited. Alongside the tombs, there's a great view of the Golden Horn from the grounds of this mosque.

My favorite mosque!. I've been to other popular mosques in Istanbul and outside of Istanbul, but Suleymaniye Mosque has got to be my favorite. It's spacious, and clean and just beautiful. Words cannot describe how much I adore this mosque. Definitely recommend you to visit and take a look inside.
magnificient. Magnificient architectureMakes you wonder how such a structure could be built hundreds of years ago without todays technology.Mimar Sinan must have been an extraordinary architect
DO NOT MISS THIS. This is one of the most beautiful mosques for many reasons and WELL worth taking the short tip to see it.
Beautiful Mosque. A beautiful mosque built by Mimar Sinan. Tranquil, open spaces on top of a hill with beautiful views of the Golden Horn.
Beautiful. Go there. Spend time. Pray. Take your shoes off when you enter. Enter with your right foot first. Do not take pictures of people praying.

Less Crowded, Just as Beautiful. Everyone tries to make it through Blue Mosque, but this one is just as amazing (in a different way) and much less crowded. Note the "windows" on the carpet--each is an indicated spot for one person to pray when the Friday noon prayer is in session. I found that intriguing.

Nice experience . Eventhough we're not muslim, we visited this mosque. It might be not as famous and big as some others, but the atmosphere was friendly and open. At some point we were joined by a friendly muslim who wanted to talk about our believes. He didn't try to convert us, but he told us about his way of life and we could ask anything about islam and its habbits. A true nice experience.

Beautiful. A beautiful, classic example of the architect sinan's mosques. There s a cemetery with interesting tombs and tombstones, and a Big garden surrounding the mosque. Sinan's tomb is just down the street.

Magnificent Building. One of most beautiful mosques in the world I must say. Awesome structure. They renovated it recently and looked pretty neat & clean. A bit difficult to locate although not too far from the grand bazaar. We took a taxi to reach there. A must see for anyone going to Istanbul.

Sublime Architecture. A sublime Sinan creation (16 th Century) atop one of Istanbul's seven hills. Restored to its former glory in the 1950s it retains ll of its outbuildings. The interior is relatively simple but has stunning stained glass and four MASSIVE pillars, two from the Byzantium period, and two from reaches of the Ottoman empire. Stunning!

Better than the Blue Mosque. Less touristy, more authentic than the famous Blue Mosque. About similar in size, but without the famous tiles it appears more peaceful and serene. The gift shops outside of it are slightly more expensive than other areas
Not only beautiful from afar. This active mosque is beautiful and imposing. Clothing provided for those dressed "inappropritely". Beware of "tourist guides" outside though.
Suleymaniye Mosque. This mosque is really beautiful and not as crowded as Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque. Great atmosphere.
One of the most beautiful buildings I have ever been in. A lot quieter than the Blue Mosque so it is more peaceful and atmospheric. beautifully proportioned;

One of the best Mosques in the world. Simply Awesome. But don't forget to check out the entire complex including tomb of Suleiman the Magnificent and the graves of his family members and other notables. Also nearby is the tomb of the master architect Mimar Sinan.

Grand mosque. The structure is really imposing.People still come to pray there.
You can view it from any angle and it will always be imposing.
Really beautiful.

Colossal. For me it is the nicest mosque of all the Istambul monumental mosques. The proportions, the inside decoration, the light and the colours. For me it is by far my favourite one and I love to rest sitting on its red carpets.
The greatest osque in Istanbul. Was there last December. I was little bit impressed because the mosque was under renovation and i could not find it easy as I expect

worth pay a visit. My feeling is better than Hagia Sophia and less touristic. You can go through from the Istanbul University (Now open to the public). There are many souvenir shops and restaurants around with lower prices than the Grand Bazaar and Sultanamet.

One of the masterpieces of world architecture. This is the finest mosque in Istanbul and Sinan's second masterpiece after his mosque at Edirne. The arrangement of the interior space is wonderful. Unfortunately Suleyman's mausoleum was closed for refurbishment. The architect's tomb is across the street and worth a visit too. This attaction does not have enough visitors and is obviously not included in tours. Tourists flock to the Blue Mosque which is inspired by this and much inferior.
The most beautiful mosque. Well worth the walk. This mosque is absolutely beautiful inside and out and as it is not in the middle of the tourist area, it is quiet and not full of tourists.

Beautiful Mosque. The mosque is very nice inside and outside. The architecture is great. Not as busy as the Blue Mosque. Lots of restaurant right outside the mosque. A must see place when visiting Istanbul.
very nice mosque. istanbul has so many mosques. this one is quite special. eco ssystem is outstanding. very clean. the speaker is too loud. I didnt like it
vancouver tourist. i think the way this is built it mesmerized me more than the Blue Mosque with unbelievable structure and incredible writings as well

One of the Great Sights of Istanbul. There is a lovely serenity, despite crowds, in this gorgeous structure. Take the time to carefully look at everything from the lighting to the the architectural lines of the structure itself. It is impressive and fitting for such a wonderful old city.
Superb. Quieter than the Blue Mosque in visitor numbers, this is a grand and historic structure that you should not miss

Serene - harmonious - beautiful. A grand complex with the magnificent mosque at its centre. Lovely setting with wide views from the grounds. The mosque is outstanding for the simplicity of its decoration. Not to be missed.
The most beautiful. For me the most beaitiful moskee in town. Little walk but after visit you will say: waauw. Very, very nice.
Best Ottoman Mosgue. very similar to Sultanahmet, thi8s huge Mosque is amazing and majestic. close to Grand Bazaar a must place to visit in istanbul

The biggest in Istanbul. It was made by Süleymaniye architect Sina, whom built more than a hundred mosques in Istanbul and Turkey. It was built on the top of an elevation and beautiful landscapes from Golden horn are possible

Clean and open. Unlike his son-in-law Rüstem Pasha, Süleyman was sure of his place in the world and the interior of his mosque is very open, clean, white, and calming. The tombs of the Sultan and his wife are outside, but when I visited they were being restored.
Biggest Mosque in Istanbul. We visited this great mosque in June, we were amazed by the size if the mosque which is the largest mosque in Istanbul. Interior design and decorations were all fantastic.

Probably the most important mosque in Istanbul. One of the largest mosques in Istanbul with excellent courtyard, fantastic interior decors inside with Islamic texts. Nice garden back end of the mosque and ablution facilities available outside of the mosque. THis is probably one of my fav mosques in Istanbul - this place is a must-see fro every traveller who visit the city
Must see. Beautiful mosque. It isn't as noisy and crowded as the Blue mosque. The peacefulness and serenity allows you to really appreciate the site and leaves you feeling thoughtful.

A real gem, better than the Blue Mosque. We had the impression that the Suleymaniye Mosque was sort of a poor version of the Blue Mosque. But, that is entirely wrong. It is beautiful, with a lot of unique features and absolutely gorgeous inside. Many fewer people pushing and shoving, in comparison with the Blue Mosque and other frequently mentioned sights. Sorry that we don't have any pictures. But, this is definitely not to be overlooked.

Better than the Sultanahmet?. Walking straight from the Sultanhamet (blue) mosque to the Suleymaniye, i was surprised to realise that i much preferred the more feminine feel of the Suleymaniye.It was more peaceful as there were far less tourists and the space had a far lighter and graceful air.Walking down towards the bosphorous towards Emininou be sure to stop off in the Rustem Pasha mosque which is above some shops: we were the only people there when we visited!

The most magnificent mosque in Istanbul. Although not on most tourist tour routes, this mosque is really the most beautiful large mosque in the city. It is not crowded like the Blue Mosque, is surrounded by quiet gardens, lots of coffee shops and small restaurants in the vicinity. It is only about 20 minutes by foot from the Grand Bazaar -

If you liked the Blue mosque (2) .... This is another great place to visit if you like the architecture of the Blue Mosque. The Suleymaniye Mosque is exquisite and quite well known but just far enough off the main tourist track that there are almost no crowds.

Its a really lovely place. A peaceful place to enjoy the evening. The quietness, the beauty of the architecture and the lighting are simply amazing. The Courtyard and the garden are lovely. You must try the bean and rice dinner, which is available in near by restaurant, its very Good. I would recommend this place highly to the fellow travelers. It is at walking distance from Spice bazaar.

Worth a visit. We preferred this to the Blue Mosque. It was quieter and we were allowed to stay during prayer time. Had a great meal nearby - the restaurant on the corner cooked a traditional rice and bean dish - delicious.

Great example of Ottoman architecture. Visited the mosque late June 2013.We had seen the Blue Mosque before, so wasn't all that sure about visiting another similar mosque. But the Suleymaniye mosque, we felt, was much better.Compared to the blue mosque, the interior feels simpler, calmer and more restrained, but so much more magnificent. The architectural genius of Mimar Sinan in full display here. The overall feeling one gets is that this is amazing architecture, but a working mosque at the same time.Awesome ..

Old is Gold. This mosque is one of the older mosque but one of the most beautiful in Istanbul. Lovely courtyard and a small garden at the back and the inside is huge and simply incredible.In the middle of the courtyard is a cubed box-house and if you see through it, you will view water gushing out and mixing with some soap. There are wudu facilities outside the mosque as well.

very red mosque. This mosque is really magnificant. It was much older than blue mosque. The carpet is very red throughout the whole mosque. It is for men to kneel on it to pray. It is not too far from the Egyptien spice market. So you may plan them one after another.

The most beautiful Mosque in Istanbul. This mosque is beautiful! It is a must see and it is not as busy as The Blue Mosque. It has undergone a recent renovation so it looks brand new. It is closed during prayer times so plan your visit accordingly.
huge. the artwork was unbelievable with the roof being a standout feature. the whole complex was fantastic with the views to the Galata bridge and tower unbelievable

Rainy day. Starkly beautiful. Make sure to look up into all the corners to study the art work/sculptures. Courtyard was flooded when we arrived (a first our guide said) and the reflections in the water were lovely.

For a true experience of Mosque grandness. The Süleymaniye Mosque is one of the two largest mosques in Istanbul and crowns Istanbul’s highest hill. It is a masterpiece of the famous architect Mimar Sinan, though it is less famous than the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet), and hence doesn’t have the huge flow of visitors and tourists. The mosque was commissioned by the greatest and richest of all Ottoman sultans, Süleyman the Magnificent and took seven years to build.As we entered the mosque precinct, we noticed the four minarets, a number only allowed for mosques commissioned by a sultan. The minarets have a total of 10 galleries or balconies, which we understood signified that Süleyman the Magnificent was the 10th Ottoman sultan. The mosque design seems to draw inspiration in style from the Hagia Sophia. The interior is simple but do check out the spectacular coloured stained glass windows, the baroque decoration on its domes and the beautiful Arabic calligraphy reciting verses from the Koran on the Mosque’s walls.Just outside of the mosque walls, do care to see the small, understated, humble tomb of architect Mimar Sinan, which he had designed himself. So in Istanbul, if you wish to see a mosque for the ‘experience’, then Süleymaniye Mosque is a must visit.
Peaceful place of worship. An enormous piece of architecture that took some considerable time to take in. It is a peaceful place of worship. It is so well maintained that it has a modern appearance.

Mosque. Brilliant, wonderful history, very moving. You need to make sure you are adequately covered if you are female. You can borrow from the mosque a "covering " outfit but you do also need to cover your head
The best interior. In my opinion this mosque has the best interior out of the top 5 mosques on trip adviser. the courtyard is also up there with the blue mosques. A must see.

Our favorite mosque in Istanbul!. Out of every mosque in Istanbul, thought Suleymaniye was without a doubt the very best. We got some great pictures both inside and out. The facility is in excellent shape and the grounds beautiful. If you have limited time during your stay in Istanbul, be sure to put this as a must see.

Awesome, Scintillating, and Highly Spiritual. This is a great magnanimous structure, which has a special spiritual feel. The attention to detail is just mesmerizing in every aspect of the architecture. One has to spend a lot of time both inside and outside in the courtyard. Spend some time outside during the night near the fountains and get immersed in the beautiful lighting, and see the sea-gulls fly over there shining in the floodlights above the mosque. Try and pray to the Almighty God while you are there, with sincere heartfelt thoughts. Its spiritually overwhelming. It was for me!!
Suleymaniye Mosque. Easy to get to, the location is amazing, and breathtaking, do some of your shopping around here, the stores are not overly priced. A 5 min walk and you're by the sea

The best Mosque in Istanbul. Built by Sulaiman the Magnificent, this mosque represents the Ottoman Empire. It is amazingly built with beautiful architecture and stones and paintings. You MUST visit this mosque and appreciate what they managed to achieve in them days!there is a relaxing garden and restaurants nearby

A True Treasure. Somewhat off the beaten touristic path. But well worth visiting. It is the largest Mosque in Istanbul. Can be seen from the Gallata Bridge. Just follow the pigeons....they will lead you to the Mosque.
Worth the walk. A 10 minute walk from the tramway but worth it. Fewer minarets than the Blue Mosque but inside the mosque itself, they are very similar
Outstanding. Spectacular (as are all of the major mosques of Istanbul). Making your approach from the Golden Horn allows for some spectacular photos.

Wow factor with this one. A stunning setting with lovely views over Istanbul. Well worth a long haul up the hill. We missed the Cemetery which appeared to be locked which looked as if it had some intereting graves it was lunchtime so that may be the reason.

Highly Recommended. The exterior isn't anything special, but the interior is absolutely stunning.Entrance is free, but keep in mind that no shoes are allowed and also of the dress code (i.e., men must cover legs and shoulders; women must cover the same plus their head). Make sure you plan around prayer times, as the mosque is closed during these times.The courtyard in the back of the mosque has great views of the Eminonu District and Golden Horn waterway.Highly recommended!
Beautiful. This is a real gem and worth a visit. Make sure you take something to cover your head with and wear a long skirt/trousers. Lovely place with impressive architecture.

The best mosque in Istanbul. I wasn't expecting much as I had not heard of this mosque before. It was far better than the Hagia Sohpia and more interesting than the Blue Mosque. A definite must when you go to Istanbul.

The most beutiful of all the Istanbul mosques.. It is the largest and the most beautiful of all Istanbul mosques. The entire building appears to be better preserved than the blue mosque. It is appears to be less crowded than the popular Blue Mosque. And I am glad to say, it is also less foot odor. Around 850 meter apart, it is within walking distance of the Grand Bazaar. The walk is mostly downhill and lined up with merchants that cater more towards the locals instead of tourist. Follow the eventual wall on your left. Turn left continue to follow the wall. The mosque will be on the right. As any active mosque, admission is free; however, there is a small fee for the use of their toilets. If the first toilet you encountered is a squat version, don’t panic, the next one might looks more familiar.

LOVELY PLACE TO SEE. This Mosque is beautiful inside and out. The grounds are beautiful with large shade trees, grassy areas, a lovely cemetery with roses blooming. Many other mosques in Istanbul feel crowded into the city but this one stands on a hilltop overlooking the Bosporous and has quite a bit of open space surrounding it.
Near the Spice Bazaar.. If you are going to the Spice Bazaar (which I recommend you do), then this mosque is a short walk away and well worth the trip. Beautiful surroundings as well.
one of the nicest mosques. if you could only visit one mosque this one should be it. Dont know what the fuss is about the blue mosque.

Best mosque in Istanbul. This is the largest mosque in Istanbul and one of the most beautiful. A working mosque but you can enter to see architect Sinan's magnificent structure from the inside as well as wander through the enclosed courtyard - look at the central fountain hidden behind a fret work casing. Less busy than the Blue Mosque which makes for a very relaxed visit. This mosque is at the top of one of Istanbul's seven hills - just walk up and up from the bus station a bit of a climb but very worthwhile. There are several small cafes and restaurants just outside the mosque's garden walls patronised by locals and very reasonable so visit in the morning and enjoy lunch here.The very best external view of this mosque is from the Galata Tower you can really appreciate its beauty from this vantage point.

Amazing. This was the first mosque I had visited. It is well worht visiting. There was no charge. You have to remove your shoes to go inside but they do provide plastic bags to carry them in. A must see when in Istanbul.

My favorite mosque in all of Istanbul. Not the largest, but the most beautiful. at least to my eye. My wife gives that accolade to the Blue Mosque, but this one lacks the huge columns which makes it look like the huge ceiling is almost floating with very little support. The pastels are refreshing!!
Classic Muslim architecture.. Often overlooked this enormous structure is impressive both inside and out with it's huge dome and with classic tiled designs and well worth a visit.
Also called as Blue mosque. Because of its blue exterior it is named blue by western tourists. A grand mosque with lavish carvings depicts amazing aesthetic sense of the builders.

Beautiful & feels more like a practising mosque than the Blue Mosque. We arrived during prayer time and were alowed in to watch which was a great experience! You really get a feel of what a mosque is like here, unlike the overcrowded blue mosque.It is also very beautiful from the inside and out.Sweets were being handed out to worshipers and tourists were given some too, which was lovely.Headscarfs/knee coverings provided if you do not meet dress code. The area around the cemetry is currently closed for renovations.

a poor way to prove the ego of I can do better. lovely place if you skipp comparison, it screams though i am golder and better not that it is but if i saw it in another area i would say wow very nice mosque. The one i like is behind kapali carsi and ofcourse the one in ortakoy !
Blue Mosque. truly beautiful. The fountain next to it makes it amazing at night. The colors are amazing. Liked everything
East meets West.. You will need to be respectful since this is a working mosque. It was lovely to see but very crowded.
Bigger than Hagia Sophia. Largest mosque in the city and less visited than Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. Makes for a calmer and more satisfying visit.

nicest mosque of Isanbul. I have enjoyed this mosque the most, when I visited Istanbul. it has been renovated recently, so the colour are bright and pretty. It has a lovely garden and is less crawded than the Blue Mosque. It is a bit away of the other touristical attracktions, but it is worth taking the detour.
Peaceful and majestic. Hit in the morning -- before the crowd -- serene, majestic, breathtaking. One of Sinan's masterpieces!

If you have to miss one major sight in Istanbul, this might be the one. I know the architecture of the building is praised, but I found this mosque cold-feeling compared to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and others. It feels imposing rather than warm and embracing. My favorite thing about visiting it was eating lunch at the little place across the street that serves local food at great prices with no menu -- beans, dolmas, etc. -- yum.

Prettier than the Blue Mosque. Impressive building and a lot more colourful than the Blue Mosque. Some nice restaurants on the side for a lunch. At Ali baba the waiter took us into the kitchen and let us point out what we'd like to eat. All tasty and for reasonable prices.

If you only visit one mosque then make it this one. While the Blue Mosque is more convenient for tourists visiting Hagia Sophia it can be a bit of a zoo. A much nicer, quieter, more contemplative experience is achieved by visiting Süleymaniye Mosque.

Beautiful place to visit. I had never been inside a mosque before and thought this was a very special experienceBeautiful place to sit and admire the majesty of the architectureCall to prayer - superb

Most beautiful Mosque in Istanbul. We enjoyed this mosque more than Sultanahmet. Hardly any tourists, peaceful, beautiful inside and out. Has a large courtyard and outer park-like grounds. Worth the 5 minute walk from the Bazaar.

Nice place to visit. Saying the islamic design in the mosque is impressive for everyone. You will take lots of pictures and you will wish to have the same designs in your house and garden.The artitcure is unique!
Beautiful mosque in a nice area. A bit less visited than the Blue Mosque. Beautiful building and garden. Sit down on one of the cafes outside and just enjoy the great architecture.

Best Mosque in Istanbul. I was thinking that Hagia Sophia or Blue Mosque are the best, but I was wrong. Suleymaniye is not so crowd like Blue Mosque, you can stay there how much you like, is nice and quiet and in the top of the hill with nice view over Istanbul. Blue Mosque is nice on the exterior, but inside is very crowd and the visit is mechanical.

Great Mosque, Awesome Area. If you follow the map they give you at the hotel, you can't miss it. The best part is that it is actually behind Istanbul University's campus and many young people around that part. Also, it is surprisingly clean and peaceful. There are small restaurants and shops, you can sip your tea while admiring the majestic construction. I went their twice during my 5-day stay, b/c I simply loved it. It was an oasis of silence in the middle of noisy crazy Istanbul (it's actually very close to the grand bazaar, so you can visit it before or after the shopping).Another thing: In front of Istanbul University, there's Beyazit Square. In the evening it's full of people selling stuff on blanckets on the ground and street venders that squeeze fresh orange juice in front of you at 1 TL a glass. Also, look for the turkish icecream vendor outside Suleymaniye Mosque.

Mosque masterpiece. This is one of the great mosques in Istanbul. It's not far from the Grand Bazaar and Istanbul University. You can get there by the metro. The streets around the mosque are very interesting too.
Awesome. I liked everything about Suleymaniye Mosque. It was beautiful and amazing experience, especially because I was there during Ramadan. Amazing experience :)

Magnificent architecture, active house of prayer. The design of this Mosque is outstanding, with natural lighting and large spaces for prayer. While tourists do visit, it felt more a part of the community with many of the faithful walking the grounds and engaged in religious activity. Absolutely worth a visit. One note on directions- it is quite walkable from the Spice Bazaar and New Mosque, but the ancient narrow streets are not always labeled- have a good map or approach from the Beyazil Tram stop.

exquisite. This exquisite mosque must be among the world's most magnificent buildings. The interior is full of light and colour, the exterior is breath-takingly beautiful. At night, when floodlit with ghostly white birds circling above the dome, it is truly magical

The most majestic mosque of Istanbul. Suleymaniye mosque is a really majestic place with a beautiful garden and nice restaurants.If you go there, do not forget to do two other things:1st, Ask for the "Mimar Cinan" tomb. it's just in about 2 minute walking distance from the mosque.2nd, Order a menu from those little restaurants just in front of the main door of the mosque.

Stunning Mosque in a beautiful park like setting. We actually came across this wonderful mosque in it's refreshing park like setting just as they had the call to prayer. We waited outside in the cool shade enjoying the gentle breeze and also took lots of pictures. It is probably not an exggeration to say that 1000's of faithful attended the Friday mid day service - and afterward, the gates were opened to allow visitors ( visitors are not allowed in during prayers) There is a huge inner court which creates a sense of calm nd reverence, of course you have to remove your shoes ( they do have plastic bags available to put them in) and you should be appropriately modestly dressed - no shorts, bare shoulders - head covering required) Some suggest that it is comparable to the Blue Mosque - I would say no but it is very impressive and beautiful and not as crowded as the Blue Mosque. There are also a lot of very nice places to eat around the Mosque.
One of the best mosques in Istanbul. Dont miss out on this one. We preferred it to the Blue Mosque. Much more quiet, beautiful architecture by Mimas Sinan. Nice walk up from Eminonu.

Its a must see wonder. This is one place yo can't get enough off on repeatedly seeing again & again. The architecture inside & outside is spectacular. The landscaping, location & overall view is amazing
Really Noble. The colousr of the tiles on her walls are so mild and brief that it stands there with serenity without any imposing effect.

A Mosque in Use is better than the Blue Mosque. This mosque is much superior to the Blue Mosque for its interior atmosphere. It does not have as many wires and supporting structures as in the Blue Mosque. Lighting is also better inside. Pictures come out better here than in the Blue Mosque.
Beautiful. Another beautiful mosque in Istanbul. Far less crowded than the Blue Mosque - definitely worth a visit.

do it.. i dont mention suleymaniye. it is an unique and awesome place to visit.i wanna give an extra info.next to suleymaniye mosque ,find the mimar sinan tomb.the one build mosque.30 meters away from tomb u will see 'mimar sinan cafe'it is in a very old building.dont hesitate.go upstairs..up .up..go to terrace...andddddd...ohh god...an awesome view of istanbul,golden horn,bosphours ,suleymaniye topkapı palace..ıt is so unique.it is very regular cafe and prices.

A special Place. We've got there in a sunny day and we were amaized how beautiful are its colour. You can find there even scarfs It's .better organised then other mosqs Near by there is a little bazar where we bought excelent shirt.

Best mosque to visit. Gorgeous! The History of Suleymaniye The Magnificent is enthralling and there are significantly less crowds in this area as well as at the mosque. We enjoyed a nice walk to get there, clean and safe areas.

great views from this mosque. Another large mosque but this one has a great view of the Golden Horn. It's impressive to see the size of this mosque; not as large as AyaSophia but impressive none the less.

Feels like you've travelled back in time. All around you see historical bazaars and huge beautiful structures. Feels like you have travelled back in time.You can also get a tram which connects this district to the rest of the city.Food at the nearby restaurants is not great though and beware of getting scammed from taxi drivers who are on the lookout of unsuspecting tourists who arent aware of the normal fare rates

Beautiful interior. This was a bit out of our way, but we were SO glad we went to see it. The interior is different than the Blue or Hagia or other mosques, much lighter, delicately tiled and painted, it feels like it is reaching up to spiritual heights. It is something to behold at sunset, even from as far away as the Taksim district across the Golden Horn.
It was amazing. I was fascinated by the size, and the mosque itself. The inside was as interesting as the outside! A must when visiting Istanbul.

A Vast Quiet. This huge mosque and associated buildings is very impressive. I am always awed by the vast space under the dome and the beautiful decorations. It humbles you. You feel the presence of God.

Great Views and Huge Mosque. Huge mosque with lovely painted domes and walls. If you go around the back, you will be able to peek over the wall and get a lovely panorama of Istanbul and the water. Very cheap eats just outside of the wall. Try the beans!

Unmissable. Better than the blue mosque. Maybe we got lucky but there were no crowds at all when we visited (early afternoon). Disappointed that the tombs were closed for renovation but still a fabulous building.

Beautiful!!!. Nice to see the atmosfphere of people washing themselves and then entering the mosque to pray.
After that take a was around and have a traditional lunch in one of the cafes behind the mosque.
Ottoman Magnificence.... Amazing landmatk that showcases the peak of the Islamic Architectural Arts. Designed by the great Mimar Sinan himself, .

Wonderful. We visited this mosque on the advice of the reception staff in our hotel and were so pleased we did. It is magical and gives a total sense of calm the minute you walk through the door, not to be missed.

Impressive and fairly quiet. Definitely a must see as its just as stunning as other mosques in the city but much quieter.
Nice grounds that are worth a quick walk round aswell.

Elegant mosque in superb setting.. I preferred this to the Blue Mosque, it is elegant, spacious and beautifully located with a splendid forecourt containing a central fountain building. Set on the top of one of Istanbul's hills we approached from the Spice Market. This is a reasonable climb but not over strenuous and allows appreciation of the associated buildings designed by the great Mimar Sinan at the same time as the mosque including a hamam, hospital, library, medreses, caravansaray and imaret or public kitchen to feed the poor where you can now buy food and drinks and enjoy a marvellous cool, shaded setting. For those who wish this can reward considerable time studying the whole site, it represents a remarkable planned community with the up-keep of the mosque paid for in part from the rental income from the associated facilities including rows of shops. Don't miss it, this is a jewel.

A gem. If I had to pick a mosque in Istanbul this is the one. Beautiful, serene and calm. No queues unlike the blue mosque and I think it rivals the Blue Mosque in beauty and splendour. The whole setting - with the university, kulliye was great too. The only negative for us was that the tombs were closed for renovation when we visited. Also it's a short walk to beyazit square and the bazar.
Beautiful and peaceful place. Suleymaniye is one of the most beautiful places in Istanbul. Besides the mosque, you can admire a very beautiful image of the city.

Best mosque in Istanbul. Everyone wants to see the Blue Mosque and the Aya Sofya but I have to say that Suleymaniye is my favourite of the lot (that I say this after spending three weeks looking at mosques in Turkey). All the other mosques Sinan designed were just practice runs. This one is his best, I think. I saw it on a Sunday in late April and there was almost no one else there. I loved how simple it was on the inside with only the minimum of decor so you could really focus on the stunning architecture and the giant medallions. Go see all the other mosques and then come to this one last so you can really appreciate it.
Awesome. I would say that this is by far the most impressive building I have visited ( and my wife has dragged through quite a few ). I would recomment it to all, especially at night.

Spectacular Example of Mosque Architecture. A rich history located in this religious icon. Worth seeing if you can get in before the massive crowds. Timing is everything for this visit. Too many people crammed in, or long lines, can really take away from the experience. Please also note that there are no photos to be taken during prayer times. We went late afternoon (after most cruise ship busses had headed back to the ship's buffet) and the line up was only 20 minutes long.Make sure you get a written guide as there is so much history in this building that if you don't know it, you can easily miss some fascinating sites and stories.Check the dress code before you go (no bare shoulders or legs for men and women and women must wear a head covering).
BEAUTIFUL MOSQUE! take a scarf and wear sleeves and long trousers/skirt.. Within easy walking distance. Located near Galata Bridge and Egyptian spice market. Lots of places to eat nearby.

Nice, especially outside. Nice place to visit, but you need to know their schedule, otherwise, you can waist more than an hour of you precious vacation time. A good thing that the spice market is not far from this Mosque.
Beautiful,go in the evening.. Go in the evening,and stay for sometime. This is the finest mosque in IStanbul, and without any tourists,mostly locals,so a good place for photo ops.

The most beautiful one in Istanbul. Much more beautiful than the Blu mosque. And much less people. Not only the Mosque is Beautiful, also the little park amongst it. and the area is fantastic, with some nice teagardens
Awe inspiring. What a beautiful building. I am not religious but this has it all; history, location, architecture and its free!

A beautiful and tone down mosque but in no way less memorable than its main rival The Blue Mosque.. A must see.. It was a difficult "climb" for me as there is no direct transport. You have to walk from the Beysit tram stop , behind the Istanbul University and go up and up on the steer small street but at the end it was so worth it.. It is a pity that Suleyman's tomb was under repair..

Fewer crowds, just as beautiful. We liked this mosque better than the crowded Blue Mosque. The architecture is stunning. We didn't feel as rushed as we lingered because there weren't as many tour groups at this one. The garden with the mausoleums was not open and we were sorry to miss this attraction since our tour book had recommended it. Next time...
Elegant, world heritage site mosque. We didn't intend to visit, but the cheating cab driver dropped us off there instead of the Blue Mosque. Still architecturally a clean elegant place.

Impressive Architecture. The Blue Mosque is an impressive piece of architecture, to say the least. That it is still an active sight of worship while maitaing its history is fantastic. As in working historic churches, I felt a bit odd snapping pictures and wandering while faithful were praying. The interior tile work is masterful. It is a bit obscured by all the wiring hanging electric lights from the ceiling. I guess that is the price of modernization.
One of our favorites!. No crowds here and different than the opulent Rustem Pasha tiled mosque. No tiles here, just elegant architectural lines and calm.
Better than Sultanahmet (Blue) Mosque.. Prayed my afternoon prayers here.. I think it is better than the blue mosque very quiet for a large mosque. Inside is breathtaking. Absolutely magnificent!
our favorite mosque. Absolutely beautiful. Not that many people. Nice and peaceful area, with lots of green. Our favorite mosque.

Blue mosque a must-see. The so-called blue mosque opposite the Aya Sofia is a wonderful place to visit. Entrance is free, just make sure you dont go around prayer times. Men to wear long trousers, and women to be fully covered with a head scarf and long pants / skirts (my skirt was mid-calf, and it was fine).
The most beautiful mosque!!!!. Wonderful, the most beautiful and peaceful mosque we visited in Istanbul! It was the best surprise of the trip.

Nice and quiet. This place is as big as the blue mosque, but so much more easy going...there is no crowd, no waiting lines, no herds of tourists. But the mosque is as nice, and the surroundings are very peacefull. It s a steep way to the entrance, but it is worth the efforts!

Iconic image of Istanbul. While its a must for any tourist visit to Istanbul, the image from the outside is more striking than the vast interior which is very sparse and uninteresting as it's a muslim mosque.

Worth the walk. Once again, we were not on a tour- and there are many who visit this site as well. It is not difficult to locate if you go through the Grand Bazaar and exit on the north side and follow the road until you see signs for the mosque. The interior is plainer than Hagia Sofia but striking nonetheless for its intricate design and complex variety of elements, from carved pillars to a paisley-like trim.

Inspiring place for all faiths. Perhaps because it is off of the standard beaten path, this Mosque has a different aura one more contemplative than more frequently visited Cathedrals and Mosques that come with their own souvenir shop and 7-language guidebooks. It is also one of the most impressive buildings I've ever encountered in my travels. We were shown around by an experienced guide (Tolga from Tours by Locals) who added to the experience by explaining the Mosque's history, architectural features (including a brilliant ventilation system) and the other accomplishments of its architect, Sinan (whose relatively modest tomb is across the street. In my view, the Suleymaniye Mosque is even more impressive than the "Blue Mosque" and a close second to Hagia Sophia.
Masterpiece by Mimar Sinan. This is the masterpiece of Ottoman architect Mimar Sinan. It is beautifully proportioned and detailed. If you have any interest in architecture, this is a must see.

Beautiful building. Beautiful building and worth a visit. Do not wear shorts and ensure your top is adequately covering your shoulders and arms. Ladies take your own scarf if you don't want to wear the mosque's own scarf. I would suggest you take socks if you don't want to go in barefoot.
Thank You Sinan. Thanks to Sinan for its beautiful work,i find myself in a peacefull place in Suleymaniye Camii,meanwhile if you go there you may also try Suleymaniye Bath

Worth a Visit. Not the usual Mosque that is on visitors must do list but this is a stunning building and mosque to visit once the obvious attractions are completed. Easily accessible and worth the visit.

Beautiful Mosque adjacent to Istanbul University has charm. This is a beautiful Mosque, recently renovated, and adjacent to the university, it offers a studen environment. Take some time to visit this mosque and the surrounding family style restaurants. Stop and have some tea and a narghila in the Leelai cafe, in the downstairs courtyard behind the mosque. Try a 500 year old Turkish Bath at the Suleymaniye Baths also behind the mosque.

Truly fulfilling experience.. Stunning mosque. Real feeling of spirituality. Dome is quite spectacular and exterior equally as impressive. Lush green courtyard area outside with stunning views over the city. Suggest bringing your own headscarf, though borrowing is an option, but shoulders and ladies heads must be covered. Really awe inspiring - favourite building of the Ottoman Empire.
A stunning combination of grand scale and simplicity. Enormous structure that is beautiful in it's simplicity. It gives a deep sense of devotion to the warshippers and the faith.

As good or better than the Blue Mosque. Just as good or perhaps better than the Blue Mosque - and much shorter queues! It's a little way out of the main city, but definitely walk-able. It is so beautiful inside.
mosque. stained glass winds were beautiful. The whole mosque was worth seeing.This is a functioning mosque so please observe the rules.

Awe Inspiring. The mosque is truly magnificent. While the line can be long and hard given the heat and humidity, it is well worth it. Try to take your time and soak it all in. The best time may be right after the dawn prayer as it is quietest then.

Astounding. Be prepared for long lines to get in, but it is worth the wait. Unlike many such sites, organized tours didn't get quicker access than the solo tourist since the entrance for organized groups is undergoing renovations. Four cruise ships added to the long lines, but what a beautiful piece of history to visit.

Beautiful. A fantastic example of Ottoman architecture with a dome greater than the Blue Mosque. We just could not get enough of visiting the different Masjids and this was certainly worth the walk through the grand bazaar and past the university - does not have the same views on approach as it is in a built up area but once inside it takes your breath away - the arches, the chandeliers and the sheer scale of the interior is stunning.

Beautiful Mosque. Honestly thought this was more beautiful inside than the Blue Mosque. This was also a lot quieter so you can really appreciate the architecture and beauty a lot better. Not only was the interior breath taking, but the groundd were beautiful as well. On a nice day would even suggest relaxing in the plentiful grass and shade within the walls and just enjoying the peace in the middle of a bustling city. Watch the time, they do close to visitors for prayer. Also reminder for women to bring a head covering.

One of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul. It is one of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul builded by infamous Sinan. It is not only a mosque but a Kulliye which has more around like hospital, library, resaturants, medresah, etc,

The best monument around. Much more impressive than Blue Mosque, with a lot more craft work and very well positioned on hilltop with stunning views on the back side. The walk around is interesting and there is few souvenir shops and cafes along for a nice and quiet break. Unfortunately the Suleiman tomb was under restauration.

Breathtaking. The mosque buildings and facades are stunning enough, and then you go inside. It is absolutely breathtaking, and worth a visit. We walked up from the Spice market, not anticipating the steep climb, its not for the faint hearted, but was well worth the wait.

Beautiful architecture. Suleymaniye mosque, located near the Grand Bazaar is a beautiful mosque that one must visit, if visiting Istanbul. Entry is free. It is quite similar to the Blue Mosque in terms of architecture, being equally beautiful. Also requirements of clothes covering the knees and head scarf for women are similar to those of all other mosques in Istanbul. Check out the cafes behind the Suleymaniye Mosque. They are reasonably priced with interesting food. Shops selling souvenirs near the mosque are also quite reasonably priced.

A must visit location. No entrance fee required. This amazing building sits in a beautifull garden. Inside the dome and ambience is filled with amazing colours from textile tiles and carpets. An added bonus is to be inside the mosque during pray times.

Beutiful building. This is a 'must-see'. Possibly the nicest religious building from an architectural and decorative perspective. Good cafe's outside in a nice setting.Close to both the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar (the Egyptian Market) and if you time things well, good for a cruise on the Bosphorus, too.
The best Mosque to visit. I prefered to visit this mosque than the Blue Mosque. It has less visitors and it´s been very well restaured.

Is this Istanbul's greatest mosque?. It would be painful to have to choose between such a richness of wonderful buildings, but I think the Suleymaniye would just edge it over the Blue Mosque, etc if I had to select my favourite. It is architect Sinan's finest creation (and he was astonishingly fertile in imagination and skilled in execution) and it is appropriate that he is buried here along with Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent.The splendidly restrained and subtle purity of decoration in this 'White' mosque does show that sometimes 'less can be more'. Furthermore, it is the only complete ancient mosque complex to survive in Istanbul. There is a fine courtyard - the sahn - with a covered fountain. The former soup kitchen is now a pleasantly flower-bedded shaded courtyard restaurant. The menu, which is intended to present traditional Ottoman cuisine, was pleasingly varied and moderately price, but the tyranny of the clock prevented us staying for lunch, alas. Next time!
Awesome liked it better than the blue mosque.. No where near the crowds of the blue mosque, the mosiacs were prettier and they let us in during a prayer service which was ethereal. A big thumbs up!
Astonishingly beautiful mosque. A beautiful place for anyone to see, whether it is about religion, architechture or just simply finding a peaceful moment admiring the building details.

If you see one mosque in Istanbul, see this one. This was the last mosque we visited, and it was absolutely the best. Truly beautiful in every way. Don't know what more to say other than you should make your way up there - and then wander the streets back towards the Grand Bazaar to be utterly fleeced by anyone and everyone.

Hike a huge hill to see another mosque. We visited this mosque after seeing the more famous Haiga Sofia and the Blue Mosque. The Suleymaniye Mosque is pretty much identical to the Blue Mosque. You have to hike a huge hill in the sun with few sidewalks to get to it. I will say that it is cleaner with nice bathrooms and pleasant grounds as well as lovely views of the city.

Not so Blue. Didn't really look blue on the day we went but magnificent all the same stands up too any other wonder. We went on a Friday so was busy but not annoyingly so. If your there on a Friday remember you can't visit until 2pm
Beautiful. You should take the time to see this. It was so amazing and a little less crowded than The Blue Mosque.

second time visiting istanbul, have been most of tourist highlights. visited blue mosque too, decided to visit suleymaniye mosque. not disappointing, amazing place, not many people-around 30 the most. we need to take off our shoes-provided thin plastic bag, ladies need to wear scarfs-provided too, even i got my own. met a group of young students with writing pad in hands, seems doing some studies. at backyard, we sat down for a while enjoying the view of the city, as we were on the hill, and had our picnic lunch too, another 5 people were doing the same. after here, took about 15 slow walk to spice bazaar.
Nice as a museum. But you will not find retirement or absorption, it' s full of people. The place is incredible nice, as I said as a museum.
Beautiful, peaceful mosque. A lovely mosque that is quiet and peaceful since it's not packed full of tourists. It's on top of a hill so it seems removed from the hustle and bustle of city life.

Excellent place to visit. More interesting and much less crowded than Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque. Beautiful masterpiece of Islamic architecture and definitely worth visiting. Mosque is closed for visitors during praying time. After visit there are some cheap restaurants nearby to eat some snack.

Bigger and nicer than Blue Mosque. See if you can get a look at it from top of a nearby building. Not only is mosque interesting, grounds are very nice too. Note tour buses often can't park close and have to walk narrow street uphill to get there

Watch you shoes!. Magnificent mosque but didnt carry shoes with us. The kids shoes were stolen so had to go buy more before we could move on. Very inconvenient and annoying. The mosque is located on the edge of the bospherous and is magnificent inside, a Silan masterpiece.

I highly recommend waiting for the sunset (maghreb) or Isha prayer. To listen to the Quran and watch people pray. It was a unique experience even for me as a Muslim. The beautiful voice of the imam when reciting Quran made tourists tear up.

One of the most beautiful mosques in Instanbul. Better to visit in spring season, when there is nice view on the Bosporus also, another thing is the interest to this place increased due to the movie about Sultan Suleyman

Working mosque - remember to dress appropriately. This is a working mosque and you need to dress appropriately; you are given a plastic bag to carry your shoes around. Impressive inside and beautiful light. While it's free entry, you can contribute on the way out. You are given a receipt for your donation.
go to the hammam. Very historic. Families OK. Men and women mixed, no singles. Great historic place - baths and scrubs and tea afterward. No more hookahs in the lobby like 16 years ago. Worth trying!
Breathtaking. This is a comparatively small mosque, but one of the most beautiful ones. It is one of the masterpieces of Sinan. It is very touristic, easy to visit.
suleymanie. Huge and beautiful. Unfortunately Suleyman tomb was still closed for renovation, though it doesn't seem to me that it needs and renovation.

Beutiful. This was one of the top 3 mosques I saw in istanbul including blue mosque and fatih mosque. It's closed to visitors at prayer times but if you get in before the prayer starts and just sit in a corner quietly, I'm sure you'd be okay I saw a few people doing this while we prayed. I think definetly worth doing this as you will get a much richer experience. I think the best time to do this is when you have a lot of ppl coming to pray as you will get a better experience. I noticed Fatih to have more ppl attend congregational prayers and I found the afternoon prayers to be the busiest. Women's areas are more empty and if your a woman and can get to the top (via stairwells at the back and some stairwells are accessible from outside towards the side and back) to watch the prayers I'd recommend that (just make sure your hair and body are completely covered and no shoes).
A touch to the Islam. If you are a Chtistian сш gives you the opportunity to walk out into a new world. And if you are a Muslim - it's Mimar Sinan's work.
A Mosque to visit. We visited shortly after Friday Prayers - watching worshippers leave and then going in to this breathtakingly beautiful space was a great experience.

Amazing. Fascinating and very beautiful. I recommend going to the free talk on Islam held around 5.00pm in the small building in the grounds (any of the English-speaking volunteer helpers will point you in the right direction) before going into the mosque. I was nervous they might try converting us, but it was relaxed and informative with no pressure at all (mind you, we didn't stay for the juice and biscuits afterwards!).

Worth a detour. This was built in the 1550s for Suleyman the Magnificent. It is a fully functioning mosque (remove shoes before entry; women wear a head scarf). The interior is vast with a real sense of massive soaring space and light. The mosque complex includes an outer marble-paved courtyard and gardens (toilet facilities available in garden). The surrounding building include a former hospital, shool, and bath house (most not open at the time of writing).The are a number of cafes/restaurants in the former "Addicts Alley" outside the walls.

Don't miss this graceful mosque !. Simply stunning , don't miss it , but be careful it is a functioning mosque that CLOSES to visitors for prayer. It is near the Istanbul university . It is on a bit of a hill, so you have a nice view and its near to the Grand Bazaar as well.
Wonderful decorations. It's a nice looking place, filled with other tourists, and with long queues to get in at times. Worth a visit, but it's not a terribly important stop.
majestic. great mosque,located in a dominating place ,visible from any point of the city.esquisite calligraphy in the interior ,very interesting also the cemetery and the garden.

Escape the crowds at this beautiful mosque. I'd highly recommend a visit to the Suleymaniye Mosque, its an imperial mosque built by architecture Mimar Sinan for Suleyman the Magnificent, so its similar in many ways to the Blue mosque (though it can't match the stunning tiles in the Blue Mosque). But you really get to appreciate the mosque without the throngs of people and queueing. There are great views here too.Don't just go to the Blu Mosque come here too!

Visit this mosque!. We would recommend a trip to this mosque above The Blue Mosque/Sofia Hagia if you have limited time or money. A peaceful place to visit, much quieter and an interesting walk and surrounds.

FANTASTIC. Amazing mosque steeped in history. Open to anyone which is great and there are guided tours to understand the history.
If you are not a practicing muslim, avoid during prayer times.

Fatastic Place. As it is not as full as the Bue Mosque or Hagia Shofia, you can spend more time there, sit on the floor, and admire the beauty of the mosque. Very interesting how it can be so big and at the same time so cozy.

Almost as good as the Aya Sophia. Once you see this, you won't think so highly of the overdecorated Blue Mosque. They just finished restoring it, and it's well done. The building looks pristine and much more elegant than the gaudy Blue Mosque. It also has a lot fewer visitors. Word of advice: ignore the sign that tells you not to cross the barrier. As my guide told me, it's only a suggestion. If you are not shy, just walk in and look around like I did.
Unforgettable. Make sure you get there before the tourbuses arrive. Inside is incredible, the size of the dome, 43 mtr high and a diameter of 23 mtr is incredibel.

Relatively peaceful mosque set in lovely grounds. The Suleymaniye was our favourite of the mosques we visited in Istanbul. On the day we visited, it seemed quieter than others in the main city centre. Also the walk up the hill and back via the Spice Bazaar (Misir Carsisi) was one of our more colourful and enduring memories of our trip.The relative peace and quiet of the mosque, its grounds and the surrounding area gave us an opportunity to reflect on the building, and get a breather from the hectic buzz of Istanbul. It’s not the most intricately decorated, but there’s much beauty in its simplicity. There isn't much information available about the mosque on site, so take a guide book with you if you want to learn more about this wonderful building.
one worth visiting. good view of city from up there. If your worried about going Mosque or church crazy, you may want to keep this one on your list. Well designed.

Stunning. We visited several mosques during our stay, but this was the most beautiful. Stunning interiors and the gardens surrounding it are beautiful as well. There are lokantas near the entrance - do remember to try the bean soup there, absolutely delicious!

Beautiful mosque and surrounding buildings. Having visited the Blue Mosque you may feel this could not be topped but I urge you to visit this other gem of Islam. Beautifully decorated inside and visually stunning outside, this mosque has the ability to take your breath away and feels more like an insight into the real Istanbul than its more famous brother.
Beautiful. The size and beauty of this Mosque is breathtaking. Given the location, this should be part of your visit to the Old City.

Don't miss the graveyard. Beautiful mosque built in 1550 by the great Sinan architect who built something like 250 other monuments, mosques, etc. The graveyard can be viewed thru the fence and the tombstones have hats, or turbans depending on the status of the person. The women's tombs have a flower etched into the gravestone for the number of children she had. Beautiful and peaceful place up a long hill!

Beautiful and impressive Mosque. Do not forget to go inside if you visit. It is very beautiful and impressive. The park around it is also quite nice to relax in (nice student café nearby). Read about the mosque in a guidebook for more information that makes the visit more worthwhile.

A haven of calm in the frenetic city. It is worth walking to this mosque as a contrast to the Blue Mosque -more austere and spiritual and imposing. The streets around the mosque are also really interesting with some traditional Turkish houses

Beautiful!. We were amazed at the architecture and detail in this mosque. Just don't forget to dress appropriately...thankfully they provided scarves for women's heads and skirts should your knees be showing. Men, wear trousers!

Quiet Mosque off the tourist trap trail. This is a great mosque both in terms of architecture and scale and in terms of what it offers. You get a mosque in the grand sense of the word while not having hordes of visitors to fight through.We went in the middle of the day and were the only people here, with such surroundings it is easy to feel very small.Well worth a visit and only a few minutes walk from the Grand Bazar

Simple, yet beautiful.. This was one of my favorite place to visit in Istanbul. Though a tad crowded, the mosque felt very spacious. The domes are masterpieces of simplicity, yet they hold the eye. Very much worth the visit.
Wonderful. It's so easy to assume that the Blue Mosque which features on every visitor's itinerary to Istanbul is the place to visit. The Suleymaniye is a magnificent and beautiful building.
interesting. Look for the tulip tiles as well as the dome. we had a guide t tell us the history which otherwise one would miss some of the significance. not as grand as other mosques.

The Sulemaniye Camii (Mosque) of Suleman the Magnificent. The Sulemaniye Camii (Mosque) built during the rule and on the order of Sultan Suleyman ( Suleyman the Magnificent), construction finished in 1558, is the largest mosque in the City of Istanbul. The architect (Mimar) of this mosque was Sinan who had built 300+ mosques, colleges, palaces, bath houses and other Ottoman institutions during the rule of Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent and other Ottoman Rulers.We have visited The Suleymaniya several times during our visits to Istanbul (between1990 and 2012) but we were, more than ever thrilled, to see it cleaned and restored, looking fresh and very brilliant colors. This resulted in my taking lots of pictures of the exterior as well as the interior including nearby Daruzziyafe (part of the Social Complex), just outside the Mosque across the small lane, first time I photographed in 1994. It has been termed "Ottoman Soup Kitcten" which the Ottomans had established throughout the country. During our 1994 visit there was an excellent restaurant and we saw lots of historical items.I strongly recommend that you first cover from outside, take picture if you wish, stop by the Tomb of Suleyman the Magnificent and then enter the Mosque to really enjoy its interior, stop by Daruzziyafe before heading to nearby restaurants for a lunch or afternoon tea or ice cream.
Jummah. Beautiful mosque. Read Jummah (Friday prayers) with my husband. Interior is the same as the other mosque

Breathtaking building!. One of the landmarks of Istanbul, needless to say how grandious and beautiful. One of the main attractions, there is always a line to get in but it moves quickly.
