They do not require women to cover their heads but they do expect you dress modestly. You have remove your shoes and placed in the plastic bag that they provide you. They also provide you plastic socks to put on your feet.

Don't get Mosqued out before seeing this one. After doing the Blue Mosque, resist the urge to dive into every Mosque that drones out its prayer call and keep some Mosque time for this one. It's a bit of a walk from which ever way you approach it, and they keep building the best ones at the top of hills!!!! Worth the walk though, its up there on the "dam big Mosque" scale and the gardens around it make it a nice place to sit and just look at the devoted entering and leaving, especially as I have made a habit of arriving at Mosques just at prayer time. Paint work inside probably wasn't done by the slap happy chappy who painted my ceiling.Now the details. Its free (you are still allowed to make a donation for all the time and effort that goes into upkeeping a place like this, so you can visit it). Shoes off, no shorts, ladies - head and shoulders covered. Closed for 45mins-1 hour at prayer time. Respect the people in the Mosque, it is their's and we are just tourists. Toilets(1L) in the grounds.
Easter 2013 Istanbul Break. Excellent architecture and level of detail in the decor. Absolutely awe inspiring with great acoustics when the imam prays.
A wonderful place. The decoration of the mosque is wonderful. It is a must see if you are in Istanbul and it is free. The access to the mosque is easy, there is a tramway and bus stop not far.

impresive!. This was the first mosque I visited, and also the one that impressed me the most. Not only because of the beautiful building, but also of the feeling you get inside. I believe there you really get to see a little bit of the local people and their daily routine. Not like in the Blue Mosque, that as it just too touristy.

Massive. Please do not miss this mosque. Read the plaque that explains who Suleymaniye was. This mosque was breath taking. It is very close to one of the gates to the Grand Bazaar and Istanbul University. The trolly/tram will take you to it.

Happy we "happened " upon this. We were out walking about and came upon this quite by accident. As there is o cost to visit and no lineups we went in. It is truly one of the nicer mosques we have seen. The decorations are very well restored and the overall appearance is actually nicer than the Blue Mosque. The only downside is the strong smell of dirty feet which I have noticed in many of the mosques we have visited.

Magnifique. Beautiful mosque. Architecture more controlled and better designed than the Blue Mosque. Study the tiles they are pretty awesome and finely detailed. Excellent view of the sea as well. Do visit ali baba restaurant just outside the mosque- they do yummy kidney beans

Worth a visit. The Suleymaniye Mosque is very impressive on the outside as well as on the inside. We were allowed inside during prayers and it was awesome to be there. The mosque is located on top of a hill. Take a cab if you feel unfit. As in all mosques, as a female you have to cover your hair. I carried my own scarf but they provide the head scarves, skirt wraps and plastic bags for shoes. More authentic than the Blue Mosque although from the architectural point of view I prefer the latter.

Stunning!. The most important mosque in Istanbul, a fantastic example of the architectural work of Sinan.When I visited, the tombs were still being restored, I will return when that work has finished, it will be a pleasure to revisit the mosque too.

A Good Views !. There is a beautiful view from surrounding of this mosque. It is on the hill and you will see Golden Horn and Galata tower. Surrounding of a mosque is very nice. You have to take off your shoes before you entrance a mosque. I liked a carpet there. It was so fluffy (like a padding). Inside a mosque is it nice too, but I liked a Blue Mosque more :)...
worth the walk. Definitely worth the walk' combine with a visit to the spice market. The interior is interesting, but the exterior is more aesthetic. Should be possible to do in less than an hour.

A Mosque worth to visit. When you have seen Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque the Suleymaniye Mosque is worth a visit. Placed so high that you have a good view over the Bospherus, - also with a nice area around
Beautiful and quite quiet, bit out of the way. Exterior is more beautiful than the Blue Mosque. Bit out of the way of the other attractions, but worth the walk.

In my opinion better then The Blue Mosque!. Even though The Blue Mosque is more famous, in my opinion, Süleymaniye Mosque is more impressive. A must see if you are in Istanbul. Make sure to walk outside and enjoy the view from it's garden. As in the other mosques, if you are a female, make sure you cover your hair and have a long enough skirt covering your knees. Since we were there in the hot summer, I wore a sleeveless summer dress, and packed a really light long sleeve shirt and a super light head scarf that I used when entering the mosques. They do provide a "skirt" (a piece of cloth with Velcro on it) and a scarf if you need one, but I preferred to have my own, which was really easy to pack in our little backpack that we carried around.

Great mosque, glad I was able to see it. I wasn't able to see this mosque on my first trip to Istanbul in 2009 - I was actually frustrated because I made the long walk uphill and out of my way to see it, and then found out it was closed. My fault for not knowing in advance, but frustrated nonetheless. A 2nd trip came up in September 2012 and this time we were able to go in; I'm so glad we did because its quite beautiful inside. Totally different from the Blue Mosque and other mosques that I've been in - this one is bright and cheery on the inside. Its worth a detour and you don't have to spend much time in here. Its still not as stunning as the Hagia Sofia interior, but its worth a visit.
If you have some extra time. Not as grand as the Blue Mosque, but worth seeing if you have a little extra time. Less crowded than the Blue Mosque, so you can walk around a little more.

Worth Going Our of Your Way. Not quite as impressive as the Blue Mosque, but definately worth the time to visit. We enjoyed walking the grounds and seeing the Mosque. Some of the sights we under renovation. It was not crowded and we were able to really enjoy the architecture and decor.

One need to visit this mousque. Although it is a small challenge to find this mosque but when we made it it was excellent. The place is huge and you can walk around in a small park. There is not so many people in it and not so touristy place like Hagia Sohia and Blue Mosque.

Wonderful atmosphere. Surrounding by beautiful stone gates, the mosque has a belt of manicured gardens that serve as a calming respite from the bustle of Istanbul. Inside, the plush carpets and airy architecture reinforce a feeling of relaxation. Although it's the largest mosque in the city, and was finished in the late 16th century, Suleymaniye maintains the feel of a working and living place of worship. Well worth a visit.
Must see!!. It's a bit of a challenge to find the Mosque, but its impressive,beautiful and you have a great view from there.
Beautiful. Peaceful and beautifully done. Not as big as blue mosque but nothing less . Oh yea leas crowded too . Calm and serene if u spend sometime after prayers here
Impressive!. The best of SINAN, the Chief imperial architect in 1538. Sinan died aged 97, having built 131 mosques and 200 other buildings.

CANT COMPARE THIS WITH HAGIA SOPHIA. This mosque is very ornamental in terms of the works done both inside and outside. It is very symmetrical. But in terms of complexity of structure, it is no match for the Hagia Sophia, even if it is one of the most unstable structures of its kind in the world!

The most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. In my opinion it is the most beautiful mosque in the city. For sure it is worth the visit. I loved the gardens, the location (uphill) and the whole set of construction in its surroundings. Also it is less crowded than Sultanahmet Mosque. Dont miss: It is magic to observe Sulemaniye from the Galata Bridge in the sunset. It is on the top of the hill and very imponent.

Beautiful, but pales in comparison with the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque. Don't get me wrong, its definitely worth a stop and a few photos, but if you have limited time in Istanbul this is something you could pass on.

The mosque to end all mosques. We saved this one for last....and it is breathtaking. Located "behind" Istanbul University, a bit of a walk from the Beyazit tram stop, near the Grand Bazaar, it will instill you with a sense of awe.

The same as othe mosques. Its nice but all Istanbul mosques are quite alike. So if you visit one of them you will see nothing new in others. Please note that Suleyman and Rocsolane tombs are under renovation now.
Second Mosque. Prepared for tourists they provide the head scarves, skirt wraps and plastic bags for shoes. Pretty.
Not just any mosque. Stunning, plan your visit between prayer times and preferably not on a Friday. It's a long walk up the hill to this district, take a cab if unfit!
Beautiful. It's free to get in and it's just simply gorgeous. Women should dress modestly in entering the mosque.

Worth the visit. We felt this mosque was well worth a visit, not least because of the surrounding grounds, the associated buildings and the views. We also visited a small cafe set in a deep recess in the ground. It seemed very Turkish and served excellent apple tea for a very modest outlay.

A treasure that many do not visit. Unlike the blue mosque this mosque is not overcrowded. You will not feel rushed to enter and leave as quickly as possible. There is plenty of time to walk through out and take pictures. The grounds outside are also very pretty and it is surrounded by an entire complex created at the same time for the hospital, library and school. A must see if in the area just remember not to go when prayer times as it will be closed to tourists.

Better than the Blue Mosque to me!!. We really liked this mosque....no crowds, gorgeous tiles, good lighting.....it was better than the Blue Mosque to me. Not the crowds, not the ugly hanging lights that obscure everything. It was beautiful.....

More authentic than the Blue Mosque. Not as impressive as the Blue Mosque from an architectural standpoint, but equally beautiful and more authentic. We actually saw some people praying in it... For ladies, covering your hair is imperative - they'll lend you a scarf if you don't have your own.

Better than the Blue Mosque. The Blue Mosque may be the best known, but that also means it is the most busy, and the one with less locals and more tourists. The Suleymaniye Mosque is still pretty central and you get to experience a bit of the Muslim life, if you spend some time inside the mosque. It is also very impressive on the inside. Do not miss out!
Absolutely stunning!. My favorite of all the religious sites we visited in Istanbul. Beautiful architecture, gardens, artwork. Very awe-inspiring surroundings. Worth the trek it took to find it.

Off the main trek, but still a good visit. Suleymaniye Mosque is bigger than the Blue Mosque and has less visitors since it's not right in the main tourist spot. A good visit overall. Same rules apply for clothing restrictions.
Biggest and Best. If you only go into one working mosque, this should probably be the one. If you have time though, since the blue mosque is in the main tourist area and this one is a bit of a trek.

the Ottoman imperial mosque. located on the 3rd hill of Istanbul, the largest and stunning mosque in the city and one of the best known sights of Istanbul. the vast religious complex calle the Suleymaniye blended islamic and byzantine architectural elements. the courtyard is of exceptional grandeur..
unforgettable!. truly amazing! simply awesome... looove the colors inside...huuuuge mosque..a true wonder! as you go in, there's this feeling of peacefulness and happiness..it touches your soul!
Fantastic. Make sure this is on your list, I actually preferred this to the blue mosque, more interesting architecture.
One of the must see's when in Istanbul. Amazing building and great views of the city. The architecture and paintings are to be seen to be apreciated , avoid going during Friday afternoon prayers.

great heavenous beauty. It is placed in the historic part of Istanbul, so you can visit other places near to it after visiting this great beautiful mosque.
its Islamic - Turkish architecture is not negligible.

Breathtaking. After reading reviews on trip advisor I decided to visit. I'm so glad I did. It was dusk when we arrived but the views from outside were amazing and the stillness within the grounds was wonderful.

A 20 minute walk from the Grand Bazaar, worth the detour. Although not as striking as the Blue Mosque or the little Rustem Pasha mosque, the Suleymaniye mosque has been nicely restored and is less touristed than the others. When leaving, head down the hill to the Rustem Pasha mosque, then along the market street to the Spice Market in Eminonu.

Better than the Blue Mosque. Although many people may disagree, I liked Suleymaniye more than I liked the Blue Mosque. It is perhaps because the Blue Mosque was so crowded it was almost impossible to appreciate the size of the place. At Suleymaniye, it was possible to sit down and really soak in the atmosphere and marvel at the artwork in silence. It hasn't quite lost itself to the mass of tourists (not yet, anyway). I also liked the interior of this mosque more than the Blue Mosque because it was elaborate without being too over-the-top. Visit this mosque then head over the Grand Bazaar for sight-seeing (and sightseeing only - read my review on the bazaar), as they are within walkable distance.
Most Beautiful mosque. Blue mosque is good, but this is more beautiful and not as busy with tourists in my opinion. When visiting the grand bazaar this is a short walk away

Peaceful and quite. It`s a wonderful place for visiting.There are not so many tourists inside the mosque, which makes it possible to learn almost every detail in the mosque. Very-very nice and worth visiting.

You can Feel God. It does seem that He has blessed this outpost of His Kingdom..... Mimar Sinan was really a master.... it is so peaceful even with all the tourists..... the architecture is beautiful and soothing.... just what a place of worship should be (and people still worship there)...... the views from the terrace at the back are worth the hours you can spend there just looking out......although the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet) is more dazzling this feels more serene and regal.....this should be a must see for every tourist to Istanbul
Good. It is nice place to visit for your first time in Istanbul, but to be visited again .Different pic from the nights of Ramadan , but everywhere in that time atmosphere are different...

Amazing amalgam of location, architecture and serenity. The mosque is located on top of a hill which gives very good views of the city. In addition to this the architecture and the design of the building is a delight to view and study. Very serene location atop a hill away from the bustle of the city.

One of the Most Impressive. After a day in Istanbul you will realize there are enough mosques to make both McDonald's and Burger King jealous. This mosque is one of the most impressive with its park-like setting and views of the Golden Horn lying below. If you want to visit the top five mosque's in this city, this is one of them.

Scale amazing. Beautiful from the outside particularly at night and with tiled interior.. Do respect Muslim sensibilities - take off your shoes and ladies do cover your head - we saw many tourists - US and Japanese particularly who were disregarding this second rule - you are in a place of w0rship and are invited in as a guest so respect please! PS also do leave a donation -in the UK you would pay to enter a cathedral or be asked for a donation - again not many people were offering anything - shame on you.............

Worth the walk. This mosque is a little bit of a walk from the main sights, but it's worth going to see. I thought it was more magnificent than the blue mosque. It also houses the only "couples" hamami in town!
Nice. A nice mosque - totally worth the walk there...do not miss the street market on sunday next to the university.

My favorite mosque in Istanbul!. We visited this mosque with a walking tour, and had the wonderful experience of arriving during prayer time. What a fantastic moment! Be prepared to remove your shoes, and (ladies) cover your head, out of respect for the Muslim practices. The pictures simply do not do this place justice!
worth a visit. This is a gem , not as busy as the Blue mosque, but also well worth a visit. The surrounding area is also quite something.

Skip the Blue Mosque, and come here!. Although outside this mosque bears a striking similarity to the Blue Mosque and other large mosques, inside it is far more richly and beautifully decorated.I would highly recommend this mosque, definitely over the Blue Mosque. It really took my breath away.(Oh and as a tip, don't eat at the cheap restaurants opposite - it's not worth it)
Lovely.. This is a very beautiful mosque, built under Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent in the early 1500s. It is not very large but it is worth seeing if you have the time!

Beautiful mosque in a very calm area. We visited at the same time as praying time, so we also joined the pray. After the praying, while we admiring the beautiful interior, there was an Al Qur'an reading which we really appreciated the moment in the mosque.

Very peaceful. Gorgeous sight. In my opinion, much better for a traveler to visit than the Blue Mosque (although I would actually recommend visiting both). When I went, it was much less crowded and very peaceful inside. I went here with a girl who did have to cover her head before entering, unlike the Blue Mosque, which I personally feel makes it a little more unique and specific to the culture. We were able to sit on the ground and lay back looking up at the ornate structure of the ceiling. Not only was the inside beautiful and not crowded, but the Mosque was surrounded by a perimeter of lawn. It feels a little more secluded this way and makes wandering around the outside much easier and really enhances the visit. Like I said, I would advise visiting both the Blue Mosque and the Suleymaniye Mosque, but I take preference over this trip.

Nicer inside than the blue mosque. Everyone in our group felt that this mosque was more impressive and more beautiful on the inside than the possibly more famous Blue mosque. Both attractions are free and are fairly close together and can easily be done on the same day along with other attractions. I think the location of the blue mosque is more impressive, but the inside of this mosque is quite beautiful and the Islamic calligraphy plates that appear incongruous at the Hagia Sophia feel very much at home here. The ladies in our group covered their heads and everyone inside was quiet and respectful. They provide plastic bags for your shoes.

Beautiful setting. Recently renovated the mosque is larger than the blue mosque and much ore modestly decorated. It's monumental dome, understated ornamentation, serene, pastel interior with gorgeous stained glass windows, are calming. Although the grounds are still under construction, the setting is beautiful, perched on a hill, surrounded by gardens and a cemetery with turbes (unfortunately closed on our trip).
Nice place, healthy walk. Its a nice place to see and walk around, normal restrictions when it comes to a mosque. At one of the higher points in the city, good walk up.

Quieter and more subdued than Blue Mosque. I thoroughly enjoyed my trip through the Suleymaniye Mosque. It is a much quieter (and toned down) Mosque than the tourist jammed Blue Mosque, but still excellent. The views from the Golden Horn side across the Galata Bridge into the new section of Istanbul were quite nice.The Mosque is between the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar, making it a logical place to stop on a trip between those two sites.
Better go to Aya Sophia and Blue Mosque. It is worth a visit but no up to other atractions. Excepting the inner architecture there is nothing else to see and the area is in poor condition.

liked it better than the blue mosque. The Suleymaniye Mosque is a little out of the way but I think it's worth it. We went to see it because Rick Steves rated it so high and I'm glad we did. At one point we had the place virtually to ourselves on a Wednesday morning. Not as many good photo opportunities on the outside, but the inside is beautiful and it was nice not dealing with a huge crowd like at the Blue Mosque.
Hugely impressive mosque. A living mosque on a huge scale, but lacking atmosphere of smaller mosques. Exceptionally tidy and clean.

its nice. i liked it generally but they were fixing it the time i was there i couldnt see much...but generally its a nice place to walk around beside the teram and bus station is not far and from there u can see where to walk to the sea..its nice place generally

Fantastic place!. It's one of the most beautiful mosques I've ever seen! It is very big, really blue and you could make a plenty of great pictures from different points. It has free entrance (except praying time) and you could feel it's spirit from inside.
Impressive beauty. The mosque is spectacular, very beautiful ornament inside but the worst thing about the place is the smell from the feet. I could stand being there only for 5 minutes.

Simply beautiful. Not to be missed. This Mosque is stunning in its presence. Females should remember to bring a scarf to cover their heads, and everyone must remove their shoes. Small bags are provided for this.

Wonderful. I visited this mosque earlier in the morning before the place became crowded. There were not many people there and I felt like I had the place to myself. It's a wonderful building and very peaceful inside. I highly recommend taking the time to visit.

Magnificente. The mosque covers a vast amount of area and without a doubt is a fabulous view. The structure and beauty of the mosque is one of my favourite attractions.
Inside the mosque is fesh as the day it was built with lighting that glows the mosque into its original feature and for the purpose it was built for.
Beautifully Serene. It is a lovely mosque set on top of the hill. Very picturesque. Suleymaniye complex also has a mixed Hamam which was very nice!
Blue Mosque. WOW... what an awewome structure. It was very cool to see how Mulsims pray, what the faciity is like, and how masive this mosque actually is

Sense of calm and serenity. There is something especially alluring about the Suleymaniye Mosque. It's the calm and quiet confidence it exudes to visitors. Designed by the famous Ottoman architect Sinan, the Suleymaniye Mosque reflects fine Ottoman architecture and is known as the most striking and beautiful mosque in Istanbul. The Suleymaniye Mosque is away from the other historical attractions in the Old City that many visitors come to see in Istanbul so it is very much less crowded (and we hope it stays this way). The Suleymaniye Mosque is an excellent reprieve to anyone who visits anytime, worshipper or non-worshipper.Calmness and serenity were what I felt once inside the Suleymaniye Mosque. Standing there, all I wanted was to continue staring as long as possible at the beautiful ceiling while absorbing the peace and quiet of it all. Several visitors/non-worshippers sat on the carpeted floor while taking their time to appreciate just being there. Time stood still, that was what it felt like.On a relative note, the more popular Sultanahmet Mosque is an absolutely gorgeous mosque, though with the large crowd of visitors it draws also comes with a sense of rush. Go to both mosques for the architecture but experience the peace and quiet at the Suleymaniye Mosque.
A Must See. The Blue Mosque probably attracts more travelers / tourists but make an effort to get to Suleymaniye Mosque for great views over the Bosphorus Srtait and New Istanbul
Have to see this Mosque. We have been at the Blue Mosque, the Aya Sofia and this one and have to say that the Suleymaniye mosque was the most extra-ordinary. Impressive interior.

If you only have time for one mosque, make it this one.. The Suleymaniye Mosque is not on the tram line, and outside the Sultanahmet area, so a bus or taxi is the way to go. On this quiet February day, the mosque was solemn, not full of tourists, and seemed to be an oasis of peace. From what I understand, it has been renovated recently and it shows. My favorite mosque of the trip. Notice the numerous ostrich eggs in the chandeliers for bug repellent! Also, if it's pleasant weather, time it to have a lunch at the lovely courtyard restaurant out the back of the mosque that was built to feed the hungry and poor ages ago.

Less visted but woth finding. A beautiful Mosque located on an interesting walk from the Hagia Sofia, through the University. The graveyard has the gravestones of some famous Sultans and the whole experience is a very peaceful one. If you call during prayers, go for a coffee nearby to a local cafe and its worth the wait & return after prayers. David
beautiful. we decided to walk to the mosque in the evening thinking it would be closed but it wasn't. it has been restored and it is worth a visit.

Less is more. Simpler than the Blue Mosque yet somehow more grand. Its hilltop location is part of its charm, as is the beautiful yet understated interior. Not nearly as crowded as the Blue Mosque, so you can meditate and soak up the ambience without as many distractions. An easy walk from the Sultanahmet district. We visited this mosque as well as the Blue and Rüstem Pasha mosques on the same day. Each one is special and mesmerizing in their own way.
beautiful. Like almost you can see in the historic area, it's very very nice. It's a huge construction that worth the visit
Quiet. Unlike the Blue Mosque it was quiet and didn't have hundredsof people taking photographs and so made it feel very special.

Beautiful grounds and mosque. This mosque is very nicely situated and has a lot to offer in the way of history, views, and picture taking ability. If open, check out the mausoleums of Suleyman and Roxelanna.

Glamorous after restoration. I have visited Suleymaniye Mosque few times after restoration. It looks brighter, cleaner and all the ornaments are visible. Suleymaniye is my favourite mosque in Istanbul and I fill with joy and peace every time I visit.
Full of history!. Once you read about the reason why the mosque and the surrounding buildings where erected you can appreciate it and admire the builders even better.

Understated elegance. This is a beautiful mosque that people should make the effort to find. slightly off the beaten track but worth the extra walking. It is built from a beautiful white stone and really stunning to look at. The toilets were also the best I've been to in Istanbul!

Beautiful and grandiose mosque. Although probably not the first choice of mosque to visit for most people, I would say you shouldn't miss it. It is in my view as beautiful and grandiose as the Blue Mosque. On a high point of the city close to the University you can enjoy a nice walk around, visit the mosque and then .... a massage and bath in the Suleymaniye Hamam :-)
As good as the BLUE. It's off the beaten path, but put it on your list. For me, it equalled the Blue Mosque because of its relatively unadorned splender.
peaceful place. Tranquil and calm amidst the chaos of the city. Great views of the Bosphorus.Huge restoration project in progress so some areas not open but still worth a visit.
Worth a look. Nice attraction spoiled only be the touts out front - be careful they are selling carpets and are VERY aggressive with the sales patter.

Massive and a must see. The sheer expanse of the ceiling is amazing. The colors are just so sharp. As with all Mosques, you need to take your shoes off. The area where this is done is exposed to the elements. It was wet the day we went and our socks got wet. Bring an extra pair if you get a wet day. Because we had a feaky windy, snowy day, we did not get to walk around the outside so we missed the tombs.

one of the most beautiful Mosques in the city. This place is not so famouse as a Blue Mosques, but it is not worth. The most wonderful part of this place - is the yard. Here is a tombs of Sultan Suleiman and Hürrem Sultan - so it is one more cause to visit Suleymaniye Mosque
Beautiful!. Interesting experience. Make sure you pick up a leaflet that tells you about Islam if you don't already know anything. Remember you have to take off your shoes!
The pink ceiling is amazing!. Worth a walk up the hill, this is a beautiful inside, the pink granite and the decoration are incredible. Another must see whilst in Istanbul.

wow. I visited here as an after thought not expecting much. This mosque is to a grand scale and splendor, with lovlely gardens fantastic views. Sultan Suleiman and his wife Hurrem are burried here, but on my visit the area was being restored so couldnt visit. But will visit again on my next visit

A tranquil, sublime, alternative to the Blue Mosque. Everybody goes to the Blue Mosque, and so it's crowded, buzzing, surrounded by touts asking you to visit their gift-shop, and far from the sublime experience that visiting these great mosques should be.Suleymaniye gets maybe 10% of the visitors, is equally magnificent architecturally (in fact, I preferred its less-cluttered lines and decor), and provides a peaceful and deeply-satisfying experience, a respite from the bustle of the city. While by no means a believer, this extraordinary building had a profound effect on me and made spirituality easier to comprehend.And nobody tried to sell me anything.
top attraction. on top of the hill overlooking Istanbul. It is close to the bazaar and spice market and has some very lovely views.
Must See. The Blue Mosque isn't the only mosque in town. This one is fascinating and a must see in my book. Ladies, be sure to cover. This is a working mosque.

Greatest mosque of them all. Before I went to Istanbul, everybody told me about the blue mosque and hagia sophia, so I went to check them out, and they were great. But at least in my experience, I found Suleymaniye to be the greatest of them : It is bigger than the others and was built in a higher location, so the view from up there is great. I recommend everyone to visit this first, or if you got to choose one mosque to visit, this is definitely the one!

The blue mosque - a great way to lift your spirits!. Don't miss it if you're in Istanbul. This free attraction is a fascinating building even for those with no or different religious beliefs. I've been twice and will go again.. lots to see and a wonderful atmosphere

Beautiful!. This mosque is quite a walk away and is situated on top of a very steep hill, some may find the walk quite difficult. However, the walk was TOTALLY worth it! The mosque is just absoloutely beautiful, inside and out! The views are also spectacular from the garden as you can see across Istanbul.The mosque itself was very peaceful and very different to the Blue Mosque, There weren't as many tourists when we visited so it was lovely to sit and have a good look around. Another plus point is that on the walk up to the mosque, you end up walking through more local areas and you will pass some lovely (and also cheap!) shops!Something to remember- when you visit a mosque, make sure you are covered up. They do have spare scarves and fabric piece to put around your legs if you are wearing something shorter. Also, you will have to take your shoes off, however, they do provide plastic bags to put them in.

Architectural wonder!. It is built by Mimar Sinan and opened at 1558. It is an imperial mosque. It is just cross Hagia Sophia and has an amazing ceiling and tiles. This mosque is must see in this region to experience the Islamist architecture,
Just go. Then go to the hammam. The exterior is more spectacular than that of the blue mosque. Then go to the hammam! Very clean, free toilets.

Serene. The decor is much simpler than, say, the Blue Mosque. And the crowds are a tiny fraction of what you find elsewhere. And very serene - you want to just sit and absorb, even though visitors are not supposed to sit down in any mosque unless invited to do so - or so I was told. This is a beautiful mosque - worth the visit - with lovely grounds. Take the tram on Cemberlitas two or three stops and walk from there - with a map, it's easy to find. Afterwards, walk down the steep north side of the hill through a fascinating neighborhood. You'll end up near the Spice Market. I took the tram back to the Cemberlitas area where I was staying.
Beautiful and respectful. The blue mosque was easy to walk in and out of as we had to stop more than once to grasp the size and beauty. The entire place was filled with reverence and beauty

Magnificent. For me this was the best mosque in the city, with a beautiful exterior, changing in different lights, delicately carved minarets, luminous interior with beautiful tiles and stained glass. Set in walled gardens with an interesting cemetery. The souvenir stalls outside are less frenetic and better value than in other parts of the city.

calm beauty. This is a wonderful calm Mosque, very different from the blue mosque. The setting is picturesque and the granite work is worth a thousand pictures. There are bathrooms around the side of the building where the grave yard is, if you are looking for western style toilets, it was very clean

Not very welcome if you are a woman. 'Poor' in average, 'Terrible' if you are a female: you are parked at the back, behind hiding fences in a very small place while the men are sitting confortably in the middle of the large place, sleeping or praying.There was a clear smell of shoes despite the plastic bags given at the entry.The building is nice (just big) but I couldn't experience any special atmosphere, even when staying a rather long time. Maybe the fact that you see security guards walking inside the main building is not helping.A guard at the entrace was roughly rejecting some visitors (tourists clearly not Turkish). It was Friday but coudl have been better organised / explained ...Interesting to experience once in your life a Friday in Istanbul's largest (old) Mosque. I hope that people will never be forced to experience it weekly.

Less visited by tourists than the other mosques in the area. We saw the Suleymaniye Mosque from our restaurant window. We decided to hike up to the Mosques with our Turkish friends and it was well worth the visit. It's a bit of an uphill hike, but you can also take a taxi to get to it. It is one of the huge Mosques in the region, but less traveled to. It is worth the visit if you have the time.

that dome!. Beautiful architecture, wonderful ambience and a place where I spent a long time trying to get the proper shot of the dome with my wide angle lens.A must visit if you are in Istanbul old town.
WOOOOW. What a great big wonderful mosque?!!! I can't believe how did they built this mosque at that time The mosque is built upon a hill and they took about 7 years building it

A jewel of Sinan work. It is located behind the grand bazaar on little hill over looking Bosporos Sea, Galata Bridge, and all the way to Topkapi palace. It was one of the greatest interior design and title work. it is as wonderful as the Bule mosque. you must not miss seeing it up close. The small shops on the back side of the mosque are very cheap and full hand made antiques.
Best mosque in Istanbul. This is totally worth the climb up the hill to see it. It's a bit out of the way, but is absolutely gorgeous.

My favourite mosque in Istanbul. A nice hike from Galata bridge through the spice market to reach Suleymaniye Mosque. Very beautiful mosque and less crowded than Blue Mosque, making it really peaceful and tranquil. It also has a nice garden that overlooks the city of Istanbul. Personally this is my favourite mosque in Istanbul.Likes: Tranquil, good view of Istanbul from the garden, courtyard is spaciousDislikes: None
MUST VISIT. dont visit during prayer times as it will e closed for prayers. Visit it on the day you are visiting the spice bazaar as it is very close to it. Take a scarf.
great mosque. Great mosque. Inspite of the fact that there was a lot of tourists i liked atmopshere in this mosque. It's my favourite mosque. Very beautiful tiles
Observe a service and enjoy. Gorgeous architecture within and withou. Fantastic acoustics during an Arabic service from the viewing dock
Super. very beautiful. if you are plan to buy pashmina, buy here because it's very cheap (10 lira) compared to other place (Grand Bazaar 20 lira or other shop (15 lira)

Worth going out of your way for. You can get rather mosqued out in Istanbul, but this one is worth the visit and has a really good view. It's a nice place for a quiet rest as well and afterward you can wander the area below and see some good shops.

MAGNIFICENT SULEYMANIYE. The beautiful mosque, reminds you the Magnificent Architect and the Magnificent Sultan..Outside the restaurants which sell the traditional Turkish bean and rice then you will enter the building from the huge courtyard..Sulaymaniye is the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul..So great, so royal..Not many tiles were used here so you can fell the architecture, not many tourist so you can take photos without hurrying up..After visiting the mosque you can go to the garden to look at the most inspiring city in the World..

Best masjid experience ever. I have been to many mosques throughout the world and this was not only one of the most beautiful in terms of architecture and decor, but it is also very, very clean. A beautiful experience and a must visit.
Most beautiful of the Istanbul Mosques.. Simply stunning and I love its location perched on a hill. Blue Mosque is beautiful but this is my favourite. Also features in the latest Bond film!!

Beautiful and breathtaking. Worth the visit, and really great art inside. Sort of overwhelming because the designs are so 'rich', though, so you feel desensitized to all of it after a while (and it's free, which really helps).
So Beautiful. This was my favorite mosque in Istanbul. I liked it even better than the Blue Mosque. The interior was beautiful, and the exterior is impressive, as well. Don't miss it!

Just relax and spend some time watching around. One of the nicest mosques in Istambul, easy to see devoted people praying and ignoring the tourists, so it is worth to stay calmly and relax and get some of the atmosphere.

a refuge in a busy city. a little bit of a walk from the tourist center, but well worth it. An architectural gem, with surrounding gardens, built on an overlook of the Golden Horn. Lots of benches in gardens to sit an contemplate, and the interior of the mosque is beautifully proportioned. Go beyond the hordes at the Blue Mosque (also lovely but crowded) and see a functioning house of worship that is welcoming and inspiring.

Nice to see. it has very big area built at the top of the hill you can visit it and go inside the mosque take tour ,photos for the nice ceiling, lights ..etc .they closed it during prayer time for non-Muslim so you can spend time at the big garden around the mosque and take photos till they finish pray.

Blue Mosque. Just amazing - super large. But plan ahead as its closed during prayer times. You can't believe the size and scope.
Michael
If you have a lot of time. If you have a lot of time to spend and have done all the major sights, take the Bosporus cruise. The views of all the mosques in the skyline are amazing!
Mimar sinan build it. One of the wonderful mosque build at top of the hill. make sure go to the garden, wonderful view to the sea.

Must see mosque in Istanbul. Nice design and peaceful to pray inside. From a distance also looks equally stunning. The courtyards are very peaceful although there is still some restoration work going on.

Another Amazing Mosque. There are so many in Istanbul, that you begin to experience mosque fatigue. But this one is worth a quick detour. Less crowded, I felt more free to explore the place thoroughly.

beautiful spiritual experience. One of the highlights of a visit to Istanbul, this mosque is (in my opinion) the most beautiful of Istanbul's large mosques. Its simplicity is its strength, the beautiful of the archecture and the gorgeous tile work is almost overwhelming. This is the kind of place that inspires awe and you should not be able to just walk in, look and leave. Sit down and soak in the beautiful energy here. Simply stunning!

harmony of tradition and culture of cleanliness. God, how is this part, the area neatly bound Historisk area of ​​Bayezid Mosque and Süleymaniye through university,In all of the religious establishment such tiština mosques and crowded with visitors, such purity, and full of visitors. My Allah.Saja Ćorić
Impressive. Women will be given a scarf to put over their head. Overall it is impressive and beautiful. Look out for hawkers looking to help you and take you to their cousins rug shop.

must see. it was a wet and rainy day and after a stroll through the grand bazaar and the bylanes surrounding the bazaar i decided to keep at my pace and brave the drizzle and cloudy skies!it was worth it....the sulamaneya mosque on the inside is similar to the blue mosque. the outer coutryard was cold with the rain but the inside was warm and dry. the midday prayer had just been completed and the devout were just leaving. a huge leather curtain on a wooden frame kept the cold wind out.lovely architecture, ceilings and the humbling experience of being in a beautifully made old place of worship!a must see when you are in istanbul.

Dont miss this one. This mosque is decorated with attractive tiles and has a wonderful sense of peace and serenity inside. Well worth the visit. Its a good idea to visit the Grand Bazaar, continue by foot to the Suleymaniye and then descend on foot through a street bazaar, which brings you out by the waterfront.
Another must see. The guide was very thorough in his description of history. Beautiful architecture and minarets are so thin and long The whole place comes alight at night

The best mosque. Quiet and not very touristy, it has amazing views back out over the city and is well worth the 20 minute walk to find. Do it if you can! You will prefer this to Aya Sofya - and it's free!

Lovely Mosque and View. Take the time and hike up the hill to this lovely Mosque. The dome is impressive and so is the view. Also if the cemetery is open check out the resting places of Suleymaniye and his wife.

Impressive. One of the few massive mosques that non-Muslims can visit. Impressive size and tile work. Make sure to check prayer times. We were there over a holiday, so entrances were even more limited. It is worth it to join a tour for the day to see the top sights and know that the schedule will work.

Great Architecture. A mosque that is big and indimidating. Has been captivating people for centuries. The largest and most imposing Mosque in the city. For a lover of architecture the proportions of its interiors and exterior are perfect.

Is it worth the climb up the hill to see Sinan's mosque? Maybe, maybe not.. I know this is the one that everyone raves about...the unseen masterpiece, but I really didn't think it was that big much of a big deal after finally viewing it. This being my second trip to Istanbul, and visiting mosques in many areas of Western and Central Turkey, this one didn't really make it into my top 5. Pretty grounds, nice area, good views, and photographically rewarding to a degree, it just didn't do it for me. Not that much of a wow factor in my opinion. If your short on time, I'd skip this one, but if you have an extended time frame in Istanbul, maybe it's worth a look for you. Admission is free, restrooms are 1 tl.
A Sinan treat. This is perhaps Sinan's greatest work and worth the hike up above Istanbul University if approaching from Grand Bizaar.
An interesting mosque to visit. I liked the whole area that this mosque occupies - it is situated in spacious grounds and there are great views over the city.

Biggest Istanbul Mosque.. After the crowds and mayhem of Sultanahmet and The Blue Mosque make an effort to visit Sulimaniye Camii. Dedicated to Suliman the Magnificent and built by the same architect, Mimar Sinan who built The Blue Mosque "Sultan Ahmed Camii". Sulimaniye is larger than Sultan Ahmed but equally as impressive, the real advantage is the fact that there are fewer tourists and it is therefore less crowded and it is possible to take your time to enjoy it without being jostled, also no carpet sellers here.It is within walking distance of The Grand Bazaar (800 Mtrs) and worth the effort. Restaurants and gardens surround the Mosque.

Bueatiful place of worship. This mosque is stunning. There were no crowds or lines, unlike the Blue Mosque. Without the crowds this mosque feels like the place of worship that it was meant to be. When we visited the mausoleums were being refurbished and were not open to visitors.
Magnificent. I am really thankful I got to see and visit this mosque. I am not religious but this is a beautiful, peaceful and remarkable place. Don't miss it.

Listen to the locals: Go!. We didn't plan on visiting, but upon speaking with a few locals, we took their advice to go. Glad we did. It was far less crowded than the Blue Mosque, and although 600 years old was in impeccable condition. It's closed during prayers, but we roamed the grounds until it re-opened and spent lovely and quiet time inside. The views over the Bosphorus and Galata are gorgeous from here. As we walked out of the mosque, local members handed out sweets for everyone to partake, no cost. We sat and ate with other worshipers. Turkish hospitality at its best.

Amazing architecture. I loved this place. Calligraphy, patterns on walls, and mosaics are amazing. There is no entry fee. You are not allowed during the prayer times to ensure that people can pray silently without any disturbance. Prayers (5 times a day) don't last long unless you end up in a mosque during ramadan nights or Friday around noon (12-2:30 pm depending upon season). There is an information center with great information and they are very friendly and cooperative. Please feel free to direct your questions to them.
Worth the hike.. Beatiful architecture and worth visiting. Not far from the Grand Bazaar. Great views towards the New District.

Pretty but after seeing so many they all blend together. Pretty but after seeing so many they all blend together. They provide bags for your shoes and scarves for the women's head but its cleaner to bring your own.
Worth a visit. Bit resrticted from an access point of view when you're inside but great gardens and courtyard and lovely views over Bosphorous. Much less busy than Blue Mosque etc.

Peaceful. so welcoming! the mosque is so beautiful and huge.Its near the bazaar,the view you get is wow!.When you hear the call for prayer and see all the people rushing to pray you want to join them.
Tranquil. The Blue Mosque had the splendor and the crowds, this mosque, you could feel the tranquility radiating from the walls. A bit of a walk but worth the trek!

An awe inspiring space. Historically and architecturally interesting and aesthetically pleasing. This was an uncrowded place where you could read a guide book while observing the architecture and history.
Save time to look inside. When you are visiting the Spice Bazaar and the Grand Bazaar, try to save time to look inside, it's worth the look. The courtyard has wonderful architecture.

this impressive mosque.... ok not the hagia sophia or the blue mosque (sultanhemet camii) but well worth visiting...
the other two are more impressive, but this one def is worth the visit...as well as the panoramic video,camera that is essential
Must to see in Istanbul. I like the 6 minarets, the blue tiles, the sorrounding area etc. I like also the castanes you may eat in front of building.

Wonderful inside and out - great views. This is comparatively little visited but I don't know why. it is beautiful inside and out - with great tiles and lovely ceilings and windows. Not crowded at all when we were there, which makes the visit so much more worthwhile. The grounds include a terrace with sensational views of the city.
absoloutley beautiful. beautiful the amazing architecture of this fantastic mosque it was stunning and beautiful to pray in !

Of course.. Yes, make the trip here. Beauty of a Mosque; great courtyards. Try to visit about noon on Friday; the mosque will be in use for a weekly imam discourse (along with the call), but while in use, you can check out the courtyard, the great views of Galata Tower and when over, you can step inside.
One of the best. Must-see in Istanbul, which is full of beautiful mosques. This one is spectacular and so peaceful. Cover for your head is provided if needed.

glad we didn't miss this. liked - fantastic example of the great architect, Sinan's, work. free WC nearby on the grounds, complexes nearby that was built for charity work and hospitality for travellers, a great legacy.
best, after the restoration/refurbishment.... in istanbul, one of the 3 places, to be visited!.. better than blue mosque. may be a little bit offset.
Superb. This mosque to me was better than the Blue Mosque, It was no where near as crowded and the architecture and decoration were overwhelming. A wonderful place and a must see.

a gem of Islamic architecture. taxis do not like to go up there, probably because of the narrow traffic. Only touristy drivers with hefty charges are ready to help, but it is not a very difficult climb. walking up there from galata bridge was a nice experienceThe mosque is nothing short of grand, spectacular...spend the time you want inside absorbing the spirituality. The outer gardens are ideal for a stroll and relaxation after your visit.
Great reception to visitors!. This historic mosque was very impressive - beautiful on the inside and really nice views on the north side of the Bosporus and Istanbul!

Beautiful renovation. It was closed for renovation when I first visted in 2009. They did a great job to restore the interior, though I was more impressed with the artistic beauty of the Blue Mosque. Structurally this was very impressive and the views out to the rest of the city and the Bosphorus were beautiful.

Probably the greatest architectural masterpiece in Istanbul. Wonderful! The crowning glory of Mimar Sian's works (he's responsible for close to 500 structures in the city). He's buried in the precincts. Truly beautiful. Wonderfully light. Less crowded than the Blue Mosque etc. Closed at prayer times, so avoid these.
great place to visit.. guys you should be there. amazing view, not far from other historical places. it is better to read somthing abut before.

Very beautiful and peaceful!. It is a nice and walk to get to this mosque: through old narrow streets and up to one of Istanbul historic centre's hills. The Suleymaniye Mosque is not crowded as most of the other popular sites, like Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia. There is no admission fee to enter this site. The interior is beautiful, decorated in a simpler style that the Blue Mosque's. There you can see the tombs of Sultan Suleyman The Magnificent and his beloved wife Roksalana.
An architectural gem. One of the masterpieces of the architect Sinan. The space is serene, due in part to the colors, and the dome is to behold.
Calm and Lovely. We loved the mosaics, the red carpet and the amazing lights. Don't forget to go to the terrace to see the sultan's view of the Bosphorus Strait.

Second visit site. Fabulous view from the back of the mosque; go through the inner courtyard and out the other side. Very impressive building and complex. The interior is simple, tranquil and harmonious. The cemetery was closed when we were there (early Nov., 2012) but the graves were fascinating (looking thru the fence). We will have to return on another visit to see the mausoleums of Suleyman and Roxelana.
Good places. Was awesome and amazingand near to shopping area and to sea and ferybots in good condationsits better to reach it by public transportion
Beautiful Interior and View. The interior of this mosque is wonderful with its tile work and painted dome. There's a great view of Istanbul and the Golden Horn from its balcony.

The grandest of the mosques. It is a walk uphilll to reach this mosque from the ferry point. Although very much like the blue mosque and the new mosque this mosque is very well maintained. It recently underwent a renovation and the it looks magnificent.

Majestic Mosque. This mosque is owes its name to Sultan Süleyman the Magnificent (1557) is one of the Istanbul's largest and grandest.It was designed by the greatest architect of the Ottoman Empire's, Mimar Sinan. the Süleymaniye dominates the city's Third Hill, it is near of Istanbul University. It overlooking the Golden Horn.Is really beatifull. Unlike the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosquethis mosque it is more calm, not so crowded of people. It is free o charge, however it is polite to give something at the end. If you do not bring you veil they have it to lend.
Another beautiful and huge mosque. Worth the visit. The grounds and building are impressive. Visit the Sultanamet area as a priority before this site
Impressive, and welcoming. This is an operating mosque. Men and women visitors are equally welcome, and enter at the back, from where you have an excellent view of the whole, airy structure.

A vast and magnificent mosque. Perched on one of the highest points in Istanbul, it seems to float above the city. It was one of Sinan's finest buildings dating from the 16th century. The interior is stunning and definitely worth a visit.

That place was very nice to visit!. In my opinion this is nicer than sultanahmet mosque. i think its more beatiful on the inside and it has less tourists there so its easier to get in and out without ques.there's a restroom there that u need to pay 1 tl to get in, it was clean and not too far from the mosque building, there's a nice park right outside and plenty of cafes and restaurants on the street opposite to the mosque. it was a walking distance from sultanahmet mosque and walked more to get to the ferry boat area where u can take a ferry ride to different destinations for 3 TL for one way. took several awesome pics of the mosque from the ferry boat.

A must in Istanbul. An absulute essential to see when in Istanbul.It is the largest mosque in Istanbul. You can not miss it when you come to Istanbul and Sultanahmet.Another great piece from Architect Sinan (mid 16th Century)
Eye opener. Very friendly warm mosque. Most impressed with the people here. Interesting to see how much mosques differ from european churches.

the biggest imperial mosque of Istanbul. the size of the mosque is huge. the area where it is located is less touristic but the recently made renovation is not completed well, did not like the renovation work!
Nice place to visit when going out for a walk. I wouldn't give it a five star, but defnitely worth a walk, they have night markets where tidbits are sold!
Interesting. I love viewing far away places and seeing the world through the eyes of other people. This is one of the many grand places in the world worth visiting.
Wow. Incredibly detailed mosque. The ceiling colours are much more vibrant than in any of the other mosques. Also a quiet mosque with good surrounding parkland if the Blue Mosque is too busy.
Fell in love. On our last day we went there at noon prayer, amazing mosque, serene and not as crowded as the other mosques.

Peaceful. A lovely mosque - not crowded at all, women need to cover their heads to enter. Great view from the gardens. We would really recommend a visit to this mosque just for the peaceful feeling you get from being there (we visited early in the morning and there were no tour groups while we were there).

Beautiful & Serene. Had already visited the Blue Mosque and have to admit preferred this mosque which was less ornate but had simpler design and a definite air of serenity, gardens surrounding it are well worth a walk around.
large mosque, interesting. beautiful courtyard and out-buildings. Like most mosques it was large and impressive. beautiful architecture and windows

So peacful and bright. Very nice worth a visit . Nice views and garden. Not so many tourists like in Blue mosque and you have more time and peace to admire and to try to understand this so special world.
Largest Mosque. It was a nice place to visit. it is just next to the grand mosque on the left. the interior is wow, the columns are huge.

A magnificent edifice. Its prominent situation on a hill dominating the city. The vast
space/garden shaded by huge trees.
Disliked: the contrasting neighbourhood and maze of sloping streets with their derilict, run down houses and the poor living conditions of the least fortunate inhabitants of Istanbul.

Almost as nice as the blue mosque. I loved visiting this mosque. It was more peaceful than the blue mosque because it had less visitors and was very nice.It is definitely worth visiting to compare it to the blue mosque as this is more of a traditional mosque.
Suleyman's Magnificent Mosque. On top of the hill, 4 minarets, visible from everywhere, large and imposing complex, truly worthy to reflect Suleyman's power and magnificence.

Is It Better Than Hagia Sofia?. Big, but better? Hagia Sofia is still the example by which all others are judged, given its age and methods and size of construction (from my humble view). Still, Suleymaniye is a magnificent example of architect Sinan's skills and one of the two top basilica/mosque buildings in Istanbul.

very peaceful. the mosque in itself is really nice but the most spectacular thing is the sorrouding garden and the view that you have on the side of the mosque all over the city. pity that the mausoleums with the tombs were closed for renovation.

Worth a visit. The mosque is a bit of an uphill walk from the Spice Market areas of town (or a less uphill walk from the Grand Bazaar area. We found that this was a little less crowded that the Blue Mosque and Hafia Sofia, so we enjoyed it and it had nice location that had some views of the Bosphorous. The interior was a little less elaborate than the Blue Mosque, but impressive and a nice contrast as well.

a six-minaret mosque. Ask your guide to explain the significance of the number of minarets and the number of balconies on them. You will better appreciate the Suleymaniye Mosque. Quite a bit better than the Blue Mosque

Elegant and lovely. Since my husband's background is architecture, this was a must. We were both moved by it's elegant beauty. Truly a great way to appreciate Sinan's genius and not as packed with tourists as other sites.

Big and famous, deservedly. Probably the most visited, after the Blue Mosque, and certainly the most spectacular mosque in Istanbul. Huge and beautiful. You already know it is a must see. There is also a great online "virtual tour" of it that is available if you google for it. Not like being there, but including some shots that you probably won't see in person. The architect was the real master.
good one. i liked this mosque. it was beautiful. and the view from the mosque is also good. there're to many things i like but im not in mood to tell you

In A Very Interesting Part of Istanbul. Anther fully working mosque so appropriate clothing needed. Plenty of eating places outside along Addicts Alley but no alcohol served as next to the mosque, food very good especially the moussaka, no menu you just walk into the kitchen and choose your dish.The mosque is interesting but not as richly decorated as some, good view across the old town to the Bosphorus from the enclosure walls.

No 2 mosque. There are a great many mosques of impressive size in the city. If you just want to check out a couple this should be included (apart from the obvious Blue Mosque). The sunken café to behind the main courtyard should not be missed, lots of local colour and the tea is only 1 euro.

Better atmosphere than the Blue Mosque. This mosque was not as crowded as the Blue Mosque and i was able to sense the peacefullness and holiness. You must dress modestly and cover up, women must wear a scarf over their hair, if you do not have one they will lend one to you but they apparently smell like old socks!

Fewer tourists than Blue Mosque...and beautiful. We'd visited the Blue Mosque and though it was beautiful we were a bit disappointed at the crowds, noise etc. This visit was completely different. We were able to sit and take a moment in peace to take in our surroundings and appreciate the fact that we were in a place of beauty the like of which we're never likely to be in again. If you do visit, stop at either the sunken garden tea garden (beautiful and atmospheric) or the beautiful restaurant tea garden next door (quieter, still beautiful) for a drink of tea. Both are in the mosque grounds complex. A lovely visit altogether - recommended.

Sultan Suleymans tomb. We wanted to visit a tomb of Sultan the Magnificent and his wife Hurem.... we were a bit disappointed since the tomb was closed due to restoration. Nevertheless, Mosque is wonderful and we enjoyed visit...

Even Mort Beautioful than the Blus Mosque. Among the historic major mosques to visit in Istanbul,the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia get the most publicity. But as a piece of architectural genius, this masterpiece of Sinan The Architect tops them both. So light and bright! In addition, it is less crowded than the Blue Mosque, and a higher proportion of visitors are Moslem, giving the visit more of an unhurried and less touristic feel.

No shortage of mosques in Istanbul!. Istanbul has many mosques to choose from. They are all different and this one is one of my favourites. It probaby gets less visitors that The Blue Mosque or Hagia Sophia, but it's worth making the effort to come here. This is one of the world's great ancient buildings. Tourists love this building for a reason. I stayed in Istanbul with my teenage son as part of our 10,000-mile cycle expedition from Ireland to Japan (book: Long Road, Hard Lessons). Plenty to do nearby with some excellent street restaurants etc.
Suleymaniye Mosque - as good if not better than Blue Mosque. This was worth the walk. I found it a little hard to find but it was worth it. It was as good if not better than the Blue Mosque.

Beautiful - one of my favorites for the tile and script.. I confess that after a trip throughout Turkey many of the mosques run together but this one stood out because of the beautiful tile and script on the walls and ceilings. It's just unbelievable not only the architecture they accomplished but the detail of the decorations. I also liked the low lighting chandeliers as well. The exterior is of course equally dramatic.

Worth a walk. Set behind the university we found the Mosque easily, despite being duped by a shoeshine man! The interior of the Mosque is beautiful and the place serene. Shame some of the locals still insist on using their mobile phones, even whilst kneeling in the most sacred of areas.

Magnificent Mosque. Suleymaniye Mosque is as beautiful as the Blue Mosque, but not crowded. It is located across from the university, a 10-15 min hike uphill from the waterfront. It's a must place to visit .

Tourist Area. Avoid if possible on the weekends.. many locals too flock to see the sites and it gets kinda crazy. kept very clean and people in general very helpful to point in the right direction.. always buy a drink outside attractions cost less...for the budget wise travelers

beautiful but.... If you get a chance to go to say... Uzbekistan, you will see blue mosque after blue mosque.... this one is beautiful as well and sadly too many tourists and makes me sad for the women...

Beautiful mosque. Beautiful. I caught this one on a quiet day as there were not many crowds. The view from the rear is breathtaking. The interior isn't as dramatic as the Blue Mosque but still exquisite.

Spiritually Inspiring. I arrived just at prayer time and sat in respectful meditation. I was having trouble kneeling and someone brought me a stool to sit on. I really wish the tourists would not snap photos or make movies of us while we pray I thought it was rude but that is what uncultured homos do i guess. real people have respect for one another.

Best Mosque to visit in Istanbul. Maybe not as oft-visited or spoken of as the Blue Mosque, but a much more intimate and interesting place to visit. Compared to the hordes of tour groups and chatter that made the Blue Mosque (as beautiful as it was inside) seem like the Grand Central Station, Suleymaniye Mosque was quiet, grand and a great place to sit down for 30 minutes in relative peace and just take in the stunning architecture and serenity of the place. I even had a nice conversation about the Boston Celtics with the gentleman outside who was guiding visitors with proper protocols for visiting mosques.A much better place to visit than the Blue Mosque, in my opinion. It's every bit as beautiful without the hordes of disrespectful tourists who mostly ignored the rather simple rules of etiquette for visiting a place of worship.

Stunning, a must see. Bearing in mind I didn't get to Ayia Sophia or the Blue Mosque whilst in Istanbul, Suleymaniye came up no 1 for me of all of the mosques I did go to. From the mosaics on the ceiling down to the carpets it is really something special.

Exquisite and serene. Forget the other mosques and visit this one. Learn the history of this religious complex which originally included a hospital, schools, a college, and other components. We walked up a steep route from the spice market but there are other less strenuous routes, or take a taxi. Just don't miss!

The sultan's mosque or blue mosque. The sultan whose the mosque has its name built this mosque to rival the Christian church of Hagia Sophia in the early 1400's. After he made Hagia Sofia a mosque and had four minarets added to it, he built the blue mosque with six minarets. This had not done before. This mosque even though it looks huge is smaller than Hagia Sofia. The dome is 47 m high while Hagia Sofia is 52 m high. They face each other about four blocks apart. They look great coming in from the sea. They are in the heart of old Istambul.

The Best. Of all the mosques we visited, this was my favorite. The use of tile and mosaics is beautiful. Few tourists visit this mosque as it is located up a hill from the spice market. Well worth the 15-minute walk.
Great. This is a commanding presence on the Istanbul skyline and well worth seeing. Although the Blue Mosque is grand, this one is just as impressive and there is no admission fee.
Dont miss the view. This mosque is huge. İ personaly liked it more from the outside, the garden and views of the city. Best place for pictures. Great location. Area around it is very nice.

The alternative to the Blue Mosque. We rather ended up at the Suleymaniye Mosque by coincidence. And were surprised by its beauty and simpleness. It's just been renovated and is not overrun by tourists like the Blue Mosque. And one has amazing views over the Bosphorus from the garden just behind the mosque.
very big. nice from outside and inside, very interesting and big mosque, near a bazar. you must visit it. and there was suleiman's tomb also
Very beautiful. History, great building, had a private guide there, nice to learn about the religion, take off your shoes and walk through...

Truly magnificent. Dominating the city's landscape, this mosque is beautiful, both inside and out. Be sure to walk around and enjoy the view from the terrace, seek out Sinan's tomb and the outbuildings, both across the street from the courtyard (today Daruzziyafe Restaurant) and under the terrace. It's a big complex. Unfortunately the tombs of Suleyman and Roxelana were closed for restoration.

It's Big. It is huge but not overly warm. Not that a Mosque should be warm but after seeing The Blue Mosque, the Suleymaniye was not as impressive. It is near the Grand Bazaar so you can kill two birds with one stone !!

A true highlight, but a little out of the way. The Suleymaniye Mosque is certainly worth a look, if you can get there. Our small tourist bus had trouble finding a park, even to let 11 of us out for a look. Its a beautiful example of Islamic art and architecture. Quieter than the Blue Mosque, which was also good news. It gave us more time and less crush to reflect on its many fine features.

Extremely beautiful and moving. We have been to several of the "major" mosques in Istanbul, and this is our favorite. It is majestic, architecturally dramatic, and very pleasing and spiritual in its spareness. We were lucky enough to visit when there were no crowds, which may have helped! This is definitely a place to see when in Istanbul!
Simply beautiful. The architecture is stunning and the washrooms are SO clean! The grounds are peaceful and offer much green space. Great for a rest from sight-seeing.
Incredible. The interior and exterior of this place is difficult to describe. The mosaics in the walls are just a piece of art. few places in the world can match this place.
Impressive. Well worth a visit just for the inside view of the main dome. Best to go in the evening to avoid the main tour parties.
Great. Very nice and attractive Mosque to see. Just few minutes to Grand bazaar. It was bright and clean and full of gorgeous mosaics and architecture.

Beautiful. This mosque is one of the most beautiful we have seen in Istanbul. Interior and surrounding area are great. It was the first mosque where tourists were allowed to stay during prying time. That was very interesting experience and a great moment for reflection. At least 50 tourists form many different countries and cultures were sitting and attending this moment in total silence.

Better than Blue Mosque!. I enjoyed my visit to Suleymaniye Mosque more than Blue Mosque mostly because it wasn't as crowded. They do provide wraps to cover legs and head if not dressed appropriately. There was a beautiful view of city from here and quiet grass area to sit and relax in busy city.
Fantastic panoramic view over Istanbul. Beautiful mosque with plenty of opportunities to take photos inside and out, plus it offers a fantastic panoramic view over Istanbul

A beautiful mosque that makes you feel welcome. A very impressive mosque with positively stunning ceilings and domes. Women, please make sure you have legs, arms and head covered when you attempt to visit.

A definite must see. Far fewer tourists than Blue Mosque and more worshippers. Gorgeous inside and out. Well worth it. Also restaurants just outside are not bad places to eat - look for the one that invites you into the kitchen to select from the 'menu of simmering pots'. The lamb casserole I had was just great. Oh and Mosque toilets are fre and clean!

Nice and clean and spacious. I liked this mosque because it wasn't as crowded as the Blue Mosque. We went earlier in the day, and it was so peaceful to stand in the open courtyard and then walk in the garden. I had to cover my head but not my arms. I screwed up on my other review of the Dolmabahçe Palace. The disgusting restaurant was outside this place, not that one. Don't go, even if they hustle you hard to sit down. It looked authentic, but the meat was yucky, no menus, and cold french fries. :(
Great Mosque. Very nice and attractive Mosque to see. Just few min to Grand bazaar. A must see if you are in Istanbul the city of the world !
Impressive. The colored marble arches highlight the white structure and complement the decorations of the domes. Private, peaceful and soothing like all spiritual places should be

Peaceful retreat. We visited the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia, and found them filled with tourists. We did not have the tranquility to enjoy the mosques. At the Suleymaniye Mosque, we found it to be almost as big as the other two, but had much fewer tourists. The elegantly decorated mosque instilled a sense of happiness, and to see a man quietly lecturing to a few women was spell binding. We sat on the carpet by the wall and soaked in the peacefulness. Those ten minutes of quiet retreat will remain in our memory above all else in Istanbul.

Gorgeous!. Absolutely beautiful mosque, inside and out. Whatever renovations were done, I'm glad they were finished by the time I visited. It was bright and clean and full of gorgeous mosaics and architecture. A much better visit than the Blue Mosque.

Stunning. This is perhaps the most beautiful of Mosque's that I have been in - such a stunning building with such a fabulous interior. The colours are so bright and in general inside feels bright and alive.
the stained glass is worth a visit on its own.. The dome above this mosque seems to float on thin air. It is cool, quiet and beautiful inside - the stained glass is worth a visit on its own.

Beautiful Mosque- rich in history, but still accessible to the modern traveller. The Suleymaniye Mosque has something I hadn't seen with any other site visited in Istanbul (The Hagia Sohpia for example) yet- really great bathrooms. It might sound like a funny thing to appreciate, but when you're visiting crowded tourist destinations and you gotta go, it makes a difference when you find nice, clean restrooms. Asides from that, it would still be a must-see for anyone in Istanbul. It's right down the street from Istanbul University, so the roads leading to and from The Suleymaniye Mosque, particularly the road toward the Grand Bazaar, are easily accessible, quiet (which for Istanbul roads is saying something) and easy to navigate. I actually got to the Mosque right as prayer was beginning, didn't want to wait for it to finish- so I went in and did prayer. That's the first time I've ever done prayer, so I think I have some bragging rights. That's one of the cool things about the historic mosques of Istanbul- they're still mostly all functional as spiritual places and they're very peaceful and feel very comfortable.

Hard to get in!. We tried four times in one day to get into this mosque and each time there were different prays happening. We looked up the times in advance but this didn't seem to make any difference! Eventually we made one last attempt to get inside before heading back and we were so pleased we did. It is staggering. The outside grounds are wonderful too and do make sure you have a proper look around. You could do this mosque first then head to the grand bazaar which is nearby, but give yourself a lot of time for both. And make sure you wear comfy shoes!! You will be doing A LOT of walking...

This is the mosque to see in Istanbul. Not as famous as Sultan Ahmet's mosque (better know as the blue mosque), this one was designed by the famed architext Sinan (his student designed the blue Mosque). One can see the real archictectural genius of Sinan in the simple elegance of the building and it's construction. Sinan didn't need immense quantities of blue tiles to make his mosque beautful.Our guide told us a story of how Sinan also engineered the building so that any smoke would be funneled out through one area; he apparently investigated by smoking a narghile (Turkish word for hookaH) while strolling about to confirm that the design was appropriate.

Atmospheric Mosque well worth a visit. We visited after the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia and I found Suleymaniye even more atmospheric than the other two. Of course it is a working mosque not a museum so we tried hard to be respectful. I found it quite hard keeping my head covered with slippery scarf and trying to take photos. It did feel lovely walking on the carpet having taken shoes off· The ceilings are truly opulent and the symetry of the decoration wonderful·
well worth searching out. well worth searching out better than the Blue mosque insidemuch quieter but very spectacularbe respecful of worshipers when visiting
Space, air and light. The dome above this mosque seems to float on thin air. It is cool, quiet and beautiful inside - the stained glass is worth a visit on its own.
wow. my favourite mosque, it was a bit far to walk from beizayt but definately worth it.....the architecture and design was wonderful

Blue Mosque an unusual sight. We visited the Blue Mosque on our last day in Istanbul and hired one of the many private guides for a nominal fee, learned much about the history leading to the construction and multiple renovations of this most unusual mosque, and were able to enjoy our visit despite the crush of the cruise ship crowds in the morning. Tip: get there by 8:30 am and see as much as you can before these boat people swarm in.

Just as beautiful as the Blue Mosque!. If the Blue Mosque is a little too crowded for your taste, head to the Suleymaniye Mosque. It has an even larger and equally beautiful dome— fewer visitors and just as remarkable.Read more at: www.thetattooedtraveler.com
Outstanding mosque, a real surprise. Istanbul has many iconic buildings but this is a real surprise. This is worth visiting in conjunction with the Spice Market.

No 2 must see sight.. Very welcoming to visitors of all faiths. However can not see prayers taking place. Beautiful building. Unfortunately not all tourists respect rules of covering heads and not talking all the time - and this can spoil the experience for other visitors.
One guide said this is best mosque in the country. If you are into architecture this is the place. Close to the spice market and very non-touristy shops that surroung the spice market.

Be prepared to visit this site.. Ladies: Respectfully remember to wear long pants or dress, covered arms and bring a pashmina to cover your head. All are asked to remove their shoes; you can carry them in your bag.

Fascinating place to visit.. We saw this as part of our tour with Salih from My Local Tour Guide of Istanbul. Salih explained all about its history and took us inside and explained various things about it that we would have missed without a private tour guide.Take your headscarf and make sure you remove your shoes before entering.

More Celestial than the Blue Mosque. The Blue Mosque is awesome, but if I were to choose one to see, I would choose the Suleymaniye Mosque. It is located near the Grand Bazaar; so it will not be much out of the way of most visitors.Why Suleymaniye Mosque? It was designed by Sinan, the preeminent architect of the time when the Ottomans first came to great power. He had a sense of space and vision that did not need elaborate decoration to create awe. The Mosque has recently been cleaned; so the contrasts between the predominantly light walls and the highly colored boundaries are striking. To me, the impacts of the overlapping shapes and lines were far greater here than at the Blue Mosque. Every different angle of view held new surprises.Most importantly, the Suleymaniye Mosque evoked a feeling of spiritual presence that was not at the Blue Mosque. This is in part due to the quality of the space, but also because it had only a small fraction of the number of visitors that were at the Blue Mosque
