very beautiful. Very beautiful mosque, with a beautiful garden outside, but I liked blue mosque even more. There is special entrance for tourists so you do not disturb muslim prayers

Peace and beauty combined. If you have the time it is worth supplementing your visit to the Blue Mosque with a visit to Suleymaniye Mosque. The mosque is not that far from the Grand Bazaar, so it makes good sense to do the two on the same day. Suleymaniye Mosque is not nearly as touristic as Blue Mosque and very, very peaceful place to sit and just observe what a wonderful place it is. It is very light - due to the colours and the windows - and rather special to see, but in an understated way. The immediate area around the mosque with magnificient views of Istanbul are also worth spending a bit of time on.
Long walk, but worth it. It looks different from every other mosque you'll see in Istanbul since it has so many windows and is white inside.

As beautiful outside as inside. This gorgeous masterpiece of a mosque is as lovely from the outside as in. The stunning stained glass windows and ceiling decoration is more than matched by the coloured marbles of the courtyard, the cleverly cut arch stones, the glittering minarets and the well-proportioned gardens. Take time to enjoy the stunning views from the northern terrace, make use of the spotless loos, then enjoy a leisurely lunch at one of the local cafes in "Addicts Alley" just outside. Eat what the locals eat and you will get a tasty and filling vegetarian meal (with a drink) for 5.75 lira - that is about £2.20 at time of writing.

a beautiful mosque. It's a little bit out of the way, but the Suleymaniye is worth the visit. There are not that much visitors so there is time the enjoy the beautiful architecture of Sinan. The Suleymaniye is more than the mosque, around there are a lot of smaller buildings also part of the whole Suleymaniye complex.

Breath taking. Suleymania Mosque is amazing it will take your breath away many many people have become muslims after visiting and hearing the amazing call of prayer, Islam is the fastest growing religion in the whole world, its very peaceful religion, i promise you will fall in love with the mosque.

A majestic mosque. One of the most stunning venues in Istanbul; perched high on a hill overlooking the Golden Horn, with views across to Beyoglu, the Bosphorus and the Asian side of the city, Suleymaniye is the masterwork of Sinan, chief architect to Suleyman the Magnificent, during whose reign the Ottoman Empire reached its zenith. This is perhaps the penultimate mosque in Istanbul, with an internal and external harmony, and architectural integrity unsurpassed among all the major mosques in the city. it avoids the large crowds that the more famous Blue Mosque gets, and allows visitors relative serenity and peace for quiet contemplation within its magnificent vast interior. Well worth the time and effort to visit, it should be a highlight of any visit to Istanbul.

Mesmerizing experience. My friend took me to this mosque which is less filled with tourists than all the famous others in Istanbul. After my third time there it was also time to see something else. Lovely lovely ambiance and architecture by famous architect Sinan. The very interesting thing is all the surroundings of the mosque with what used to be the barracks , the shops, the hospital etc. Also there is a fantastic view.

Far less crowds - beautiful exterior also - great views from outside across Bosphorous. Loved this mosque - no crowds very quiet. Outside area was a fabulous view across to the Galata Tower - got some great photos.

Visit at sunset for great views of Istanbul. I liked this mosque better than any of the other ones we visited, even more than the Blue Mosque. It looked newer or better kept and the interior was breathtaking. If you go around sunset time, there is a great view of Istanbul from the grounds.
Gorgeous. Suleymaniye is as beautiful as the Blue Mosque, but less crowded. It is located across from the university, a 10-15 min hike uphill from the waterfront.
Another mosque?. Sorry but this is not the best mosque. It's one of the 3 domes and minarets that you recognize in the city skyline but inside is just... plain and boring.

A blend of Bzantine and Islamic architecture. Visiting this amazing mosque one cannot help admire the superb archtitecture of this building. Having previosuly visited the Hagia Sofia, the visitor may be temopeted to note similarities in the basic design, with the difference that in both cases the traditional minarets were added. This mosque is also more popularly known as The Blue Mosque.

On par with the Blue Mosque. It was the first time I visited this mosque and really liked it. I'd say it is at least on par with the Blue Mosque - the gardens are amazingly beautiful, and the tiles inside are even better than the Blue Mosque. Loved it.
Way better than the Blue Moskee. Way less people! This is the place to get the time and opportunity to see what is a moskee really about

Amazing!. Went there twice, once in the morning and once in the evening...up on a hill, walking distance from Grand bazar, my hotel was in Aksaray so we easily walked to our hotel from there... great cheap gift items outside... very pretty from the inside, worth a visit definitely!

Worlds best religious building. Serene, peaceful, beautifully proportioned, tasteful and restrained, yet grand and inspirational.
An inspiration to architects and enginneers.
awesome. it is slightly cut off from the main sights and, hence, much less crowded. but its the most beautiful mosque in istanbul!

Beautiful and serene. This is an immaculate mosque that does not see the crowds of the other more famous sights of the city. As such it is much more serene and at the same time it is immaculately kept. I enjoyed being informed about Islam by the scholar who was there to explain such things to any visitor who wished to learn about this fascinating religion.
Absolutely wonderful achitecture. We thought this mosque was a bit above that of the "Blue" Mosque although the beauty of both is quite exquisite
stunning. As lovely as the Blue Mosque, but much less crowded with tourists, you can get a much better feel for the quiet and harmonic proportions of an architectural masterpiece.
Ahhhh. This is a MUST MUST MUST - the accomplishment of Sinan the architect is breathtaking and the understated
Beautiful. Just amazing. I waited to get inside because prayers were going on at first, and it was worth the wait.

Huge and peaceful. This was the first mosque we visited in Istanbul, which maybe accounts for my very positive impression. It's very big - as you can see from a distance, as you approach over the Galata bridge - and when we were there, there were very few tourists. So the peace of the space seemed to surround us, and we spent quite a lot of time just sitting on the carpet looking. Everyone removes shoes, women should be prepared to cover their heads, but this mosque (unlike the Blue Mosque for example) did not seem too worried about legs - men were wearing shorts, women dresses showing their lower legs.

wonderful mosque, far less crowded. Great mosque, far less crowded than the blue mosque. We really enjoyed it. Also walk around the outside of the mosque walls and there are a number of nice stores to look in, including a couple artsy ones.
Beautiful Mosque in a Stunning Location. This was one of the most airy and light mosques we visited with the added bonus of a stunning view down over the Golden Horn and Bosporus Sea.
Beautiful. This is a must see historic and cultural site in Istanbul. Stumbled upon it near the University and th Grand Bazaar on tram T-1 line.
Blue Mosque. Wow! A magnificent building, inside and out. Incredible craftsmanship, how did they build and decorate this place!? As places of worship go this is up there with the best. Magnificent.

beautiful renovations. it was closed for renovations 2 years ago when we visited so it was at the top of the list on this trip and should be at the top of anyone's list period. the place is breath taking.

Awesome mosque. We found this mosque to be quite beautiful. Most of all, it was not nearly as crowded as the Blue Mosque, which allowed us to really enjoy it in a quiet and peaceful setting. Worth the trip.

See the surrounding buildings too. We visited this mosque toward the end of our Turkey Trip, and it certainly wasn't just another mosque! It seemed to have cleaner lines in it's design - and had interesting buildings around it - we went into what is now a restaurant with some neat pictures, saw a sunken tea room area and the tomb of Sinan, the architect.

Magnifesent. One of the most beautiful mosques of Istanbul, designed & built by mimar Sinan the greatest architect in the history of the Ottoman empire. Acoustics were improved by 61 clay pots buried in different parts. Sinan created a ventilation system that sucked the smoke from the 4000 oil lamps through a certain window to prevent the smoke from affecting the wall decoration (genious)
Worth a visit. Beautiful and serene . Very peaceful. So colourful and beautiful interior. Staff were polite but felt more of them could cold have spoken English to deal with the overseas visitors.

far, but worth a visit. Although not in the main tourist zone, it's worth visiting. Scarfs are provided for women to cover their head, and it's much less crowded than the Blue Mosque. There's a small cafe on the back street outside (Şifahane Sokak) that saved me from fainting after walking under the August sun, which served the purpose to refill our energies to continue sightseeing.

Beautiful & Historical. This is the first mosque we visited in Istanbul. Probably the most famous building designed by Mimar Sinan, chief Ottoman architect in the 1500's. We also visited his mosque in Edirne and highly admire his skill.

My favorite mosque in istanbul. Want to really experience a mosque? Interested in the architecture? My recommendation is to skip the overcrowded Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia. Instead spend some time visiting the Suleymaniye Mosque. It is a tranquil spot with beautiful views of Istanbul. The courtyard has excellent proportions and the mosque itself is rather unadorned-- allowing you to marvel at the feat of engineering. Also, it has been recently restored and is absolutely gleaming!

Time your visit!. Since this is an active mosque you must time your visit since it is closed during prayers. This is one of the "must see" iconic Istanbul sites and well worth the visit. It is breathtakingly beautiful inside

beautiful mosque. This mosque is less crowdy as the blue mosque but just as beautiful. Walk around the whole bilding and when you leave take a çay in Lale çay bahçesi at the right side of the mosque outside of the mosque walls.

One of the wonders of the world. I am neither a Muslim nor an architect. But the mosques of Istanbul are a must-see for anyone visiting the city - though you could never see them all as there are more than 2000. The architect Sinan, who designed the magnificent Sulymaniye Mosque (where he is also buried) left an indelible mark on the city. He was a contemporary of Michaelangelo, and is an artist of similar rank. The Suleymaniye is absolutely gorgeous, and, being a little off the beaten track, is relatively tourist free - unlike the Blue Mosque.Sinan's Rustem Pasha Mosque is also a must with its exquisite Iznik tile decoration.

impressive. I was really impressed with the organization. we were provided with plastic bags to carry our shoes in during the visit inside the mosque. There was no cover charge, but contributions to keep up the mosque were appreciated. Must see this beautiful piece of architecture

Make part of your trip. Another place in Istanbul that is worth visiting and understand the history behind it..There was some renovations going on when I visited that was not convenient. It would take an hour or so to visit the mosque and walk around the area.. It is not as hectic as Sultan Ahmet area...
What a view .... One of the great mosques you have to visit ... Near to grand bazaar and Istanbul university ... View to the posophor ... A rich historical feeling up there
My favuorit Mosque in Istanbul. Some might prefer Haja Sofia or the blue mosque but personally i find Suleymaniye mosque to be more glamorous, neat and more relaxing to look at its interior ..
Great. If you like architecture you MUST visit this wonderful mosque and area around. Come when tourists are out to enjoy and make photos
Great. It's one of the best historical place to visit in Istanbul near to the bazar and it can be very nice to go after or before going around the Grand Bazar.

Splendid. We arrived just 20 minutes before the mid day prayer so were (along with all other visitors who were not there to pray) ushered out very firmly 'playtime finish, playtime finish'. As soon as we all got outside the heavens opened and the thunder commenced. The mosque guards took pity on all these poor tourists and allowed us back in out of the wet on the proviso that we be quiet. What a spiritual experience that was. And what a privilege it was to observe the muslim prayer ritual, so very different from our own.
Amazing mosque!!. the mosque size was tottally unexpected beautiful mosque and prayed there too try to reach there in time for a prayer
the most beautiful mosque in istanbul. For me is the the most beautiful mosque in istanbul. I recommend a visit to this mosque, to do a nice climb to get there, but once at the top it's worth it

Rich Muslim Culture. It was really an spritual experience for me to visit this great mosque. Wonderful place to go for muslims specially, however it was heart breaking to see westerners not ensuring repect for Islam and women were entering with out proper clothing. This is not acceptable by the religion it self. It hurts the feelings of muslims and should be avoided. Women must cover thery arms, legs and head before entering all such holy places of worship as a matter of respect.

A breathtaking mosque!. To reach there, you will need to climb a little hill .. So if you're not in a good shape, maybe you can take a taxi .. It's simply one of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul, especially with its gardens & the breathtaking view over the Bosphorus! You will definitely enjoy every minute of your visit .. However, please be aware that this is a worship place .. Hence females need to wear decent clothes & cover their heads when they enter, & males shouldn't wear shorts, or at least cover their knees .. You will also be asked to remove your shoes ..

The most Beautiful Mosque in the World. I've never seen any Mosque like this one. It's So beautiful. I was just going to Pray a very short prayer and take a few shots, but I couldn't leave the place. I stayed till Noon prayer (Duhr Prayer) and prayed with the locals Jamaa. It was very calm and peaceful. As an Architect I was really amazed by the scale and beauty of the building. It was a great experience. You mustn't miss it. The view from there towards the Bosphorus is Amazing.

Calm place. To arrive there, you must climb a small hill. So, if you are in bad shape, maybe it is a good idea to take a taxi… Ambiance is so calm (yes, not crowded of tourists), it is a pleasure to stay inside and admire the architecture and decoration of this mosque… outside, there is a well maintained garden too. It was lunch time, but we do not find any good restaurant near the mosque, only modest ones, so be aware.

worth the hike up the hill. beautiful mosque. not as lavish as some of the mosques we've seen. this is a bit off the beaten path. we were one of the few tourists there when we went and it did make for a more peaceful visit.it's amazing and disconcerting how so many people forget when it should be a matter of common sense: take off your shoes. ladies, cover your hair. this is a place of worship. you can be a tourist, look around, and take photos. but still be respectful of the folks who come here to worship.

A great mosque with great views. The mosque was restored in 2010 (somebody told us) and now it's interior is great, with the famous Turkish tiles. The garden has a great atmosphere, from you can contemplate nice views of the Golden Horn. Since it receives less visitors than the great mosque, it's ambience is much more relaxed. Defiantly, it's a must see in Istambul.

Amazing Site!. I loved the Suleymaniye Mosque, but unfortunately when I visited in May of 2010, parts of it were closed. Beautiful architecture and grounds, as well as a cemetery well worth exploring and reading inscriptions on tombstones. Of course, the tile-work is spectacular here, as at most Turkish mosques.

Look up for the calm. Having never been in a mosque until this trip I have to say that I found the ceilings calming. There are no human icons so I appreciated that aspect of the building. Just remember to look up for the calm.

Majestic Structure. This is off the beaten path for typical tourists but it is well-worth visiting. It is a magnificent structure with a great view. Getting there is not easy. I have taken taxis there and then walked down the hill (feeling my way) to the water where I know I will find taxis again. I do not recommend walking alone at night in that zone (just because it is not well-lit and it seems to be full of migrant workers).
Impressive mosque complex. Very impressive area that deserves a visit. Not as crowded as the blue mosque which means you can enjoy the mosque in silence and appreciate the grandeur of the place.

magnificent!. I visited several mosques in my visit to Istanbul this summer and Suleymaniye mosque was by far the most magnificent and breath-taking one. The acoustics inside the mosque simply blew my mind. Although the steep path to the mosque seems a bit daunting, it is def worth the effort.

Probably my favorite of the mosques in Old Town. Many of the sites in Istanbul are just mind-boggling. This one most certainly is. I just moved to Istanbul and have loved every minute of it so far. If you get a chance to come, please do so. The grounds are well kept and the domes upon domes of the mosques (this one in particular) are amazing.

Beautiful. Designed by famed Turkish architect Sinan, this mosque was my favorite in all of Istanbul. Not too many tourists visit the place, so there was a more intimate setting when viewing this beautiful mosque- so much so that I came back to it again on my last day of traveling. The imam has a wonderful voice if you are lucky enough to visit while he is reciting from the Qur'an too. The colors of red/orange and black give this mosque a different feel than others that I visited while in Istanbul.
Gorgeous Mosque, but be respectful. Absolutely breath-taking mosque. However, be respectful and remove your shoes. Ladies, please bring a scarf to wear over your hair. "When in Rome"...
place for sultan and his wife. it was made by architect sinan for one of the most important empire and empiress... it has a school, library and a turkish bath special for empire and empiress
peaceful mosque. Unlike the Blue Mosque, Suleymaniye feels like a holy place. It's decor is more understated but I think more beautiful than others.

Nice Mosque, beautiful view from the back. Very impressive structure, at a very nice location, up on the hill. The view to the north, across the Golden Horn is very nice: make sure you walk all the way over to the "wall" on the northeast side to look out over the city.
Even more beautiful than the Blue Mosque. Built by Sinan in the Sixteenth Century, this may be the finest example of mosque architectutre in all of Istanbul. The dome is especially worthy of note.

Great ARCH. Beautiful view from garden. This is my favorite mosque in istanbul even nicer than blue mosque, is builded on one of the 7 hils in istanbul and have very nice acoustic, The view from the garden is georgeus, The only think is that we visited during ramadan and was so crowded therefore I would recomend go in the morning

Speechless Wonder. This is truly an amazing architectural feat and to say it is incredibly beautiful is an understatement. I had the pleasure of viewing this mosque with a Turkish friend and was treated to many marvelous stories about the mosque. A must see !

Amazing .. even with the wait. What a beautiful mosque , amazing grounds amazing history. Line to get in not so much. We waited in line for about 45 minutes . Make sure you wear long sleeves an below the knee pants unless you want a blue scarf/wrap in all your pictures.
A beautiful mosque with a beautiful view. The mosque is beautiful. Stroll down to her garden and listen to the call to prayer, take a picture of Galata Tower and sit on the stairs and enjoy.

The best Mosque to visit in Istanbul. This mosque, perched atop a hill, is far less visited than the blue mosque and Haigha Sophia, and all the better for it.Far more a community mosque than a state mosque it was once the centre of community life and the sourrounding buildings are all part of a complex of markets and schools associated with the mosque.To my mind as imposing as the blue mosque, but far far less crowded yet far more atmospheric. If you only have time to visit one make it this one.
Went on a friday -- did not go in. This is a very impressive mosque but was unable to go in as I was there on a friday during Ramadan, the most busy day of the week and year so didn't go in.

sustaining hilltop complex. quite special - whilst it is an example of imperial triumphalism, it does have a certain serenity as well - the complex includes the amazing manuscript library, hammam and other buildings. Generally tends to be less tourist-ridden than the Sultanahmet mosques

Amazing architecture. Of all the beautiful structures in Istanbul, this was by far my favorite. It is situated out of the way, but is actually not that far from the other major sites in the Sultanahmet district. Nevertheless, it is much less crowded than the Blue Mosque and so it feels a little more peaceful. The decoration inside is even more light and airy than the Blue Mosque and a little more subdued, which adds to the feeling of peacefulness that you get inside this mosque. It is a wonderful place to just sit quietly and appreciate the architecture. Once you go out into the courtyard, there are great views of the water- it is another wonderful place to just sit and enjoy the surroundings.

A calm and beautiful mosque, much less-visited by tourists. The Blue Mosque in Istanbul is the most famous in the City, but it suffers, as a result, from crowds of visitors, many of whom seem to have little regard for the significance of the site for those of the Islamic faith. The Suleymaniye mosque, in contrast, sits on a hill away from the main tourist centres. As a result, the number of tourists when we visited was no more than a handful, and we were able to sit quietly on the floor of this wonderful building, admiring the architecture and wonderful decoration, and also watching the faithful at prayer. Well worth a visit.

Perfect, majestic space. This is my top recommendation for everyone visiting Istanbul. It's an exquisite piece of architecture, full of light, and very encouraging of a real communal feeling. The interior is perhaps the best you'll see in Istanbul. The courtyard is beautiful and is, by the way, an excellent place to seat yourself during one of the prayer calls. There is a park surrounding that is very relaxed and is a great place to take a break in what can be a very exhausting city.
Nice change!. Well-constructed mosque, set in the heart of Istanbul, with more locals visiting it rather than tourists. You get a different feel of the religious life they live.
Beautiful. It's a gorgeous Mosque and it's worth it to go and see. You need to cover your knees and shoulders - but if you forget, they will provide you with a lovely skirt and scarf!

very real. After visiting the Hagia Sofia and The Blue Mosque this was a change because it feels like less of a sight and more like a unique mosque being used by the inhabitants of Istanbul. And of course it's beautiful!

A hidden gem. While everyone is rushing to the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia (well worth visits) not so many people trek up the hill the Suleymaniye. The mosque is beautiful and there were very few people there, so it was also quite peaceful. We were able to really see the prayer rugs and to sit an contemplate. A very nice respite from the hectic city - and a little cool down from a very hot day.

Hot but breezy. It was very hot on this day but somehow, the way it was designed, the mosque seemed very cool. The courtyard was breezy. So it did not feel too humid. Women had to cover their exposed shoulders and need a head scarf (provided free at the entrance. All had to take off shoes and put in plastic bags (also provided free).
Worth the uphill trek. This active mosque is behind the Grand Bazaar. We had to walk a ways to get to it. The interior is beautiful.

My favorite mosque. Get food in the cafe in front of the mosque. Not expensive and VERY authentic and delicious!Also, souvenirs in that area are cheaper that in down town Sultanahmet, so it would be a good chance for you.The last, thing, if you are a photograper, go away from the mosque in the direction where the souvenirs and cafes are, pass through the arch and the first building on the left is a student dormitory or some kind of student campus. You can go there and ask the students to go on the balcony and take an awesome picture of the mosque!! If you dare of course:)
Humongous mosque. The tiles all over the wall must have taken aeons to make,well preserved.what more to say.Very centrally located as well.
Impressive hilltop position. Another great large mosque with good views over Sultanahmet and the Bosphorus. Rivals the Blue Mosque for sheer size.

Most pretty mosque in Istanbul. It's a bit far from the main touristic area but definitely don't miss this place, it's less crowded and it is the most pretty mosque in Istanbul for its very colorful inside decorations.

Impressive Excellent Condition. The Suleymaiye Mosque has impressive architecture, and is in excellent condition. Once inside the gates of the mosque you can look around the grounds, take pictures, and then go inside and look at the structure of the building, the beautiful calligraphy and tiles. The site does not take much of your time and makes great pictures.
Friday prayer. We went to relax in the gardens during the Friday prayer. It was one of the most relaxing and fascinating experiences I have had so far. Worth a visit!
best viewed from outside. the tilework inside is spectacular but the real star is the building itself and I cannot reccomend the smell inside in summer!
Serenity. A bit of a walk out through the grand bazaar and but a very calm atmosphere and gorgeous mosque.

Just a-mazing!. I've been to this mosque multiple times, and just can't get enough of it. As practically all mosques, it's grand but yet very peaceful and serene. The architecture is amazing, and just the thought that this was built centuries ago and is still standing after all those wars and earthquakes... breathtaking.

Did my Friday Prayers there :). Good Big mosque...some kind of food was served after the prayers.. big grounds outside.. nice architecture...if you are close by to go and visit.. but if you are far.. no need to go only for this..:) honest here..

was not allowed in. i had had a couple of drinks and was a bit unsteady on my feet so was not allowed in which was fair enough but i got some beautiful photos from outside if ever i go back will go inside

Nice. I thought it was interesting to see the men outside cleaning up along the wall of faucets as they got ready to pray. This is less of a tourist destination than Blue and Haggia Sophia, so it's more pleasant in that respect. You can easily walk to the Spice Market from here, so it's worth a quick trip.

Beautiful mosque + excellent restuarant nearby. The mosque was just stunning. Don't miss the beautiful hilltop view of Bosphorous. Afterwards, skip the tourist restaurants and visit Safranbolu Pidecisi a few blocks away at Number 19 İsmetiye Street. Family-run spot with pides cooked in wood-fire brick oven...unforgettable.

The Magnificent mosque of sultan Süleiman "the Magnificent". While being lucky to stay one week in the neighborhood of this great and beautiful mosque from the 1550’s I was able to visit the mosque and its surroundings at my leisure. This is one of the most peaceful attractions in Istanbul without the crowds of the more popular ones. You can enter the mosque through the visitors’ entrance. There is a pedestrian street in front of the mosque with a few cafes serving decent local food – not to mention the Mimar Sinan Terrace Café (see my other review). There is a beautiful view over the city and the Golden Horn from the mosque garden.
A really lovely mosque. It was worth seeing, but take a taxi cos it's uphill. Really beautiful
how does the roof stay up???. The sheer scale of the building and the beauty of the tiled walls takes ones breath away
exquisite mosque. I watched the Turkish series "Muhtasem yuzyil" so it was cool to see the place

Magnificent. If you are a fan of religion and of site dedicated to God, that you should visit this place. No entry fee and if you are not in praying time, you will be very impressed. I've visited this place 3 times in one week, and I will visit this again if I will return. It's great and it;s a lot different then all the cathedrals and churches in Europe.
Worth seeing. Huge, nice, but after Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), every other mosque is redundant to see.
old & grey. once u have visited sultanahmet mosque,u see all mosques alike.but the children enjoyed feeding the birds outside.
Lovely. Beautiful place worth seeing if you have the time then go!

It was a decent experience. maybe i expected too much, but it was a decent overall experience. But I wasn't taken in by the grandeur. Should have saved this for the last (if time permits kind of place)
Awe inspiring. I loved this mosque, the building are beautifully proportioned and the the whole place radiates a feeling of calm.

Stunning. Huge mosque. Muslim's prayer place. Still in use. You need to cover yourself properly and decently. Some head covers are available at the gate. Need to remove your shoes. Plastic covers are there to put your shoes and carry them. No tickets to enter. You can donate if you like. Lovely decorated interior. At night, it looks mysterious with lovely lighting.

Beautiful mosque with large grounds. Very beautiful inside and if you go late in the afternoon, there are very few people there. There are cafes nearby so you can get some refreshments -- they are housed in previous stables or guest house areas of the old mosque

Don't miss this!. Sulaymaniyah the Magnificent did amazing things in Istanbul. You need to see this, if only to marvel at the engineering feat that has kept it pristine and undamaged through countless big earthquakes. It's beautiful to boot.

A must see. This is a more conservative mosque than the Blue Mosque so women have to wear head scarves to get in. I also wore a maxi dress so that I would be covered. They give you a plastic bag for you to carry your shoes when you go in so you don't have to worry about leaving them outside. There are prayers 5x's a day and they close the mosque down for an hour each time for prayers. The restrooms are on the side of the mosque (you have to pay of course) and are very clean.
Beautiful interior. A visit inside is great, but beware the queues can be long and hot. Outside looks fantastic in the evenings.
Suleymaniye mosque. An old building but still bears teatament to the formal glory

Worth the time. This mosque is a magnificent example of Ottoman architecture and the work of one of its greatest architects Sinan, whose tomb is on the grounds. The mosque is elegant in its simplicity and the stained-glass windows are incredible, especially on a sunny day when the light passes through them into the mosque. Remember to dress conservatively -- long pants and shirts with sleeves -- an women should wear head scarves. The mosque complex includes an opportunity to shop as well enjoy some tea and watch the crowds.
Even better after the refurbishment. In my opinion is the best inside visit of any Mosque in Istanbul.

Incredible, Don't Miss. We spotted this Mosque whilst having sunset drinks on the rooftop terrace of our hotel in Sirkeci. With the help of the waiters we worked out which Mosque this was and so the next day we wandered the streets behind the Spice Bazaar trying to find it! It is a very steep walk up hills (which can be a challenge in summer) but upon finding it the walk was completely forgottten. Its almost like finding an oasis in the middle of the city. Even on a hot summers day (it was 35 degrees celcius when we visited) there is a cool breeze blowing and the mosque has fantastic views out over the Golden Horn. The gardens are beautiful and the inside almost rivals the Blue Mosque. We actually found it to be more breathtaking and as we were one of very few visitors there was a real sense of calm and serenity in the mosque. There is some work going on so your can't walk all the way around the mosque but it really is worth a trip. You can also tie it into a visit to the Grand Bazaar and approach it from the other side of the hill.
Beautiful. Perfect for artists sketching! Nice shopping area and local restaurants outside. Try the white broad beans in tomato stew with rice :)))

Simple but Impressive!. A self-sustaining village of a mosque. Beautiful inside and out! If you visit the restaurants that are tenants of the mosque, be sure to try the bean soup.Be aware: you must remove your shoes and cover your legs and shoulders before entering the mosque. Covering your head is optional, but is a sign of respect.
Sweet Surprise. This was our favorite mosque! It's a little ways from Sultan Ahmet but worth the trip. It is just beautiful and so peaceful. You also get a great view of the city from it's gardens.
Great & amazing. Great & amazing mosque .You need at least 1 to 2 hours to cover it all .

Stunning!. Beautiful place, remember to go an hour before or after prayer times to be let in. The provide skirts and scarves to cover your legs and shoulders so don't worry to much about how you're dressed.

One of my most favorite sights in Istanbul. I absolutely enjoyed visiting this mosque more than any other in Istanbul. It was much less crowded and had incredible views over the city. The interior was as nice if not more interesting than the Blue Mosque. Don't miss seeing it.
Worth a visit. Beautiful architecture, inside and out. Beautiful stained glass and domes.
Fascinating. The Mosque is fascinating. Arround the Mosque you can find also very good shops.
Magnificent. Don't forget to visit Sinan's tomb adjacent to the mosque
splendid. a lovely piece of art. You should be wearing modestly when visiting the mosque if you are not going to pray
finally open. was closed forever for renovations but is now open and beautiful. another outstanding mosque in istanbul
amazing. this is another wonderful mosque with gorgeous dome and its calligraphy, the inside of the mosque is really beautiful . but the outside view doesn't really represent its inside beauty
Majestic. Iconic building always visible in the istanbul skyline. We said our Friday prayers at the mosque and really enjoyed it.

Subdued Elegance. This mosque is still in use as such, so there is a lovely quietude about it. Just know, that the mausoleum where Suleymann is buried is under refurbishment, so you cannot go in right now.

Inspiring. Because of its position high on the hill this mosque has tickled me since my first visit – but on previous visits it wasn’t accessible because of extensive renovation. And a good job was done! We went there early (around 10:30), and maybe because of the time or the walking distance there were few tourists - heavenly! One could therefore experience the solemnness of the space, unlike the more popular Blue Mosque. The space is vast and simple, and for this reason the detail stands out. Really worth the trek! (was approached by a 'volunteer' who wanted to tell me more about the religion than the mosque ... !?)
Beautiful by day or night. A visit to the mosque is a must by day, but dont forget to have a look at the mosque at dusk! The lighting and the dark makes it beautiful.
Very impressive!. A very impressive cultural experience. Women don't forget your scarf and dress modestly.
spectacular scenery. Beautiful mosque! Very quiet and peaceful, although we were told it was the most important one in Istanbul.

Great quiet mosque with few tourist groups. A lovely mosque with not to many tourist groups. Make sure you checkout the view from here it is great. Also make sure you stop and eat at one of the eateries outside it was the best meal we had in Istanbul. You go in side to select your food and I had rice stuffed eggplant and stuffed pepper, the flavours were to die for!! If you need to buy scarves do so here they are so much cheaper than anywhere else TL10. You can easily walk to the spice markets from here.

Worth the wait..... I tried to visit this mosque on my two prior trips to Istanbul, but it was closed for a three year renovation. Finally, I was able to visit in June 2012, and it was well worth the wait! Suleimaniye is the creation of Mimar Sinan, Istanbul's greatest architect and "Turkish Leonardo". He was a military genius and prolific architect. Go early to avoid crowds and plan on at least one half to one hour to view this masterpiece. Lovingly restored, its grand court, dome and side ornaments are worth close inspection. Mimar Sinan is buried in a modest tomb just outside the mosque's northeast wall; visit this tomb to pay your respects to a great man, then wander the back streets down to the Spice (Eqyptian) market and the Golden Horn. Each street has a speciality: tin and copper, porcelain, textiles etc. and is a shopper's dream. The mosque is a fairly easy 15 minute walk north from the tram stop in Beyazit (Lale University area); the walk is uphill, so plan accordingly.
Well-designed, well-made. We found this Mosque by accident and if was a good find to find.
Big and Blue. OK, yeah it was cool and all, but given the choce, the Hagia Sophia is better, prettier and more important.
Beautiful and tranquil. Get a tram or cab to visit this mosque. Its beautiful, quieter than the blue Mosque and so worth the visit,

Do not miss this mosque!. My personal favourite from Istanbul, further away from the two most famous mosques (Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque), but still close to the Old City and the Galata bridge, this mosque is has an amazing interior and a "clean" feeling. An other bonus is the relative lack of tourists, compared to the Blue Mosque of course. It also stands on the highest hill of Istanbul, and so there is a great view on the Bosporus and the Galata side. Not to miss.

Beautiful mosque and a nice Hammam by Mimar Sinan. The mosque is bigger but less sophisticated than Sultan Ahmet Cami (the blue mosque in Sultan Ahmet District) but not less beautiful. There is a nice Hammam in the area built by Mimmar Sinan which is a must see.
Hard to climb up to the hill. Suleymaniye mosque located in an interesting area very old building a lot of small stores like wholesalers. Taxi woul not take you up to the hill since traffic is crazy.
Worth the walk from the Sultanahmet. Lovely gardens and beautiful mosque. Definitely visit this holy place

Islam. This is a multicultural country. If people can't accept that,don't go. For women always carry a scarf for around your head and be sensible. This is a beautiful place of Worship but the dress codes are strict. Respect them
My Favorite Mosque. Good condition as compared to some of the other mosques, ornate decorations and charming quarters across the street. Good for some Chai.

Magnificent Mosque, with resting place of Roksolana. We walked to this mosque from the port, while on a Mediterranean cruise (Celebrity-Equinox, which was fantastic!) The mosque itself was grandiose, and perched on top of a hill, very visible from the port and the bridge across the river. It is a working mosque, and has the typical "foot-washing" stations on the side, as well as in the (free) restrooms in the courtyard, where we were surprised to see a gorgeous marble-tiled version. The grounds were immense, and the structure was designed by a foremost architect. Very impressive! But our main intent was to see the resting place of the sultan and of his wife - Roksolana. The cemetery was closed, due to renovations and restoration work. However, we were stumbled upon the gorl in charge of the restoration work, and she pointed out the octogonal tower structures, that are the tombs of the two. The Library structure was particularly beautiful. There were nearly no people there when we visited, making it a good alternative to the Blue Mosque (if you want to avoid crowds). The area under the Mosque was also noteworthy - We walked down the hill, back towards the Spice Market and Port, to our ship. The walk down was also very interesting, seeing the local merchants, and the streets designated by the different types of materials that were sold (fabric, scarves, buttons, trim, cookware, etc.) And while walking across the bridge, we watched a hundred hopeful fishermen with LARGE fishingpoles (but saw noone actually catch any fish, despite traversing the bridge numerous times...) We look forward to visiting Istambul at greater length in the future!

IMPRESSIVE GIGANTIC. The biggest mosque with grounds of enormous extensions. Thelocation on a hill makes a visit to the garden grounds a pleasantexperience. Take the tram to the station Laleli and check out the university and part of the Valens viaduct on the way to the mosque. From there it is a 15 minute walk to the Grand Bazaar.

Suleymaniye the Magnificent's mosque. The sound of the ezan, call to prayer, summoning the faithful to the nearby Suleymaniye the Magnificent's mosque, filters down the warren-like avenues & streets of the Grand Bazaar. As though carried by its notes men rush along, carrying boxes filled with everything from scarves to plums. One of the most magnificent & beautiful of Istanbul's Imperial mosques, the Suleymaniye has reopened after a 3-year, £9 million restoration that saw its courtyards, minarets & interiors cleaned. During the work, original Iznik tiles were uncovered & restored.

Masterpiece.... Suleymaniye is one of the land marks of Istanbul that is situated on one of the 7 hills of the old town. The view is breathtaking and looks like a miniature from the courtyard.. enjoy it... after visiting the mosque you can take a stroll along the narrow back streets of Istanbul...
Sublime. a very beautiful and special mosque. I'm so glad I visited it, as it was as amazing as I had heard.
Interesting Mosque. women must wear a scarf, they charge a lot for a lender. Very interesting
The peace. I was lucky i could visit the mosque almost empty, and feel its greatness in silence, wonderful...
Sukeymanie Mosque. Best Mosque we visited, and shoudn't be missed. The building is amazing as are the gardens and the views are fabulous over the Golden Horn o the New City.

Best Mosque Ever. Sinan, Ottoman mosque architect par excellence pulled out all the stops for Suleman the Magnificent with this Mosque. The most prayerful, inspiring, and spiritual space in Istanbul. The soul stirs and the spirit soars and we are not Muslims but were much moved.
Mosque. although there was a line it moved fast. Women don't forget head covering and long pants or skirt to cover legs. Beautiful site especially the domed roof
Avoid it at prayer times. It is wheelchair accessible. I found it beautiful, but I think travel guides I had read exaggerated it a little.
Another Byzantine beautiful mosque. A bit like Blue mosque, beautiful and atmospheric.

Much less crowded than Blue Mosque. This mosque is a little off the tourist route, so is far less crowded than the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sofia. Nevertheless it's well worth a visit. The locals argue eternally which of the two mosques is more magnificent, the Blue Mosque or this. To my mind they are both magnificent, with the advantage that this one was started by none other than Suleyman the Magnificent.
the most important Mosque to visit in Istanbul. beautiful mosque and quite a site to see - different to other places, in its scale and colour scheme.

My favourite Mosque. We went there on a morning visit, & were stunned to see only few tourists. It's well organized, you have to remove your shoes by the main entry (no bad smell detected), disposable plastic bags are available. It is requested that women should be dressed appropriately (no shorts & mini skirts & sleevless tops) & preferably to cover at least part of their hair before entering.The mosque is big, very clean & organized in many sections, it's beautifully designed. For some reason we felt safe & peaceful & we ended up spending an hour resting in there.
Mosque. One of The nicests Mosques of Istanbul, not too crowded. Plan visit right after service.

Must see. Excellent details in the interior. You need take off your shoes and put them into a plastic bag before stepping in so expect a lot of smelly feet around. Ignore the smell and discover the amazing details of the interior.The exterior is distinctively Istanbul.

Beautiful. We went early in the morning and it was free, cool, picturesque and nearly deserted. A far cry from Agia Sophia in the afternoon where it was sweltering, expensive and full of tourists. And it was a lovely mosque - maybe not as impressive as the Blue Mosque, but serene and wonderful anyway. Go there to get away from the crowds. Easy walk to the Grand Bazaar.
dont miss this!. Absolutely stunning - definitely one of the most stunning in a city of mosques!

Suleymaniye Mosque after restoration... Magnificient masterpiece of Sinan since magnificient century! It worths to be seen after long term of restoration. The whole complexity arroundthe mosque itself including the tomb of the architect Sinan will require at least half of your day to visit..

Excellent Toilets!!. The mosque itself is now restired and looks lovely on the inside.
I have to say that the toilets were the cleanest I have seen in Istanbul. They are located towards the rear underground, but do not be worried about descending the stairs as they are very clean.
Breadthtaking. The mosque in on top of one of seven hills of Istanbul. Amazing archtecture and ornamentation. The location is very quiet and peaceful.

Liked it a lot. This is a good place to visit. Brilliant views over the city, very peaceful and a lot more 'spirtual' feeling than the Blue Mosque.
After you are done walk down hill towards the spice market and on to the port area for a fish sandwich. Good half day activity for this city.
Great interior. Looking resplendent after its recent refurb - the decoration in here is far superior to the Blue Mosque

Beautiful. This mosque was being renovated in 2009 when I last visited Turkey, therefore a must see for my recent trip, and it did not disappoint. Beautiful and serene, picturesque and elegant with alovely surrounding area. Not a lot of tourists making it a nice change from the other major sites. A group of tourists were perhaps behaving inappropriately (laughing and giggling). Very happy that I finally visited this mosque.

University - Suleymaniye Mosque - Hasircilar Caddesi - Spice Market (Great walk!). Beautiful mosque! Very quiet and peaceful, although we were told it was the most important one in Istanbul. Great views of the Golden Horn! We took a suggested route from DK travel guide (90 minute walk from Beyazit to Galata) but found the hole walk very tiring (it continued to Galata Bridge, Karakoy and Galata Tower - all by walk! this is not possible in 90 minutes...). This section of the suggested route though (University - Suleymaniye Mosque - Hasircilar Caddesi - Spice Market) is OK and very nice. Reserve a morning for this walk and, depending on your tiredness, decide later if you can continue!

Beautiful mosque - shame disrespectful visitors.. This mosque is very beautiful inside and I would like to have spent longer here to fully appreciate it. However, the behaviour of many visitors disappointed me, even those who were accompanied by local guides and compelled me to leave. In order to facilitate visits by those not accustomed to the etiquette when visiting a mosque, headscarves and sarongs are provided free of charge so that customs can be observed and respect be shown. Unfortunately, once inside, too many visitors removed the headscarves and wandered around with it in their hands. I am not religious, but I was very disappointed at the lack of respect shown to the religion of those who kindly allow entry to their place of worship. This is perhaps just something to be aware of when planning your visit.
Another Huge Mosque. Almost big as St.Sophia. Magnificent Mosque. Architect Sinan built it for Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. You must visit and it's free.
My first mosque. Take your time and make sure you have a good look both inside and out.

Looks like a newly built mosque. This mosque recently reopened after a three year renovation. A visit to this beautiful building is defininately worthwhile . The neighborhood where it is located makes for a very interesting walkabout. Neighborhoods devoted to belt making, tin smithing, yard goods, etc. A bit of everyday life in Istanbul.
Beautifull. Beautiful,The biggest mosque of the area.Very similar looking to Blue Mosque

Beautiful and less crowded. Perhaps not as well known as the Blue Mosque, but Sulemaniye Mosque is just as amazing. The artwork is simpler, utilizing the natural colours of the marble and stones to enhance the arches and domes. The use of white space allows the visitor to appreciate the existing art work more. And most importantly, it is less crowded! Fewer people to distract from the awe inspiring size of the dome.
Enjoy the slower pace. Beautiful. Much quieter in location and and visitation than the more highly touted Blue Mosque.
Near the Grand Bazaar. It's another beautiful mosque, and is one of so many that are worth visiting while in Istanbul.

Similar to Blue Mosque. Had a similar feel to Blue Mosque in my opinion, however still worth a visit as we were told this mosque belonged or belongs to one of the more powerful families in Turkey's history.

an amazing place to visit. this is a mosque worth visiting and taking pictures, as are all the mosques in Istanbul. near it is the old city market with artifacts and regionmal things to but, especially the bronze tea tray with the traditional cups
Very grand. The outside and inside of this mosque are equally impressive! Very beautiful.

Calm in the busy city !. Located not far from the frantic Grand Bazaar, this is a great example of Istanbuls many great Mosques, which I found to be very calm and relaxing. We enjoyed the mosque and its gardens with good views out to the Bosphorous and then had lunch in one of the quieter streets just outside.

not as beautiful as the others. Nice mosque, but if u already seen the blue mosque and sofia mosque it appears really less fashinable. However, in this mosque u have free access and u must cover. Here the controls are even more strict than the other mosques.

Less touristy than the Blue Mosque or Aya Sofya. We had lunch at "Darruzifaye", located inside the mosque compound, in a royal courtyard, serving Ottoman cuisine. It's a very tranquil setting, and the food is decent with good service.
Wonderfull complex. It is great to look into the cultural, social and theological meanings of the mosque and it's surrounding buildings.

Architecture beauty... It was made for one of the famous Ottoman Empire (Suleyman the magnificient) and Empress. It was made by Architect Sinan..During the ottoman era there is a school (school prepare children for ottoman goverment), a library, a turkish bath (just for empire and empress). If you have time do yourself a favour and visit this place.. :)
Magnificant. One of the most beautiful Mosques in the world. Very well maintained.
Interesting but many tourists did not treat with respect. Worried me that so many people walking through seemed more intent on posing for pictures than actually experiencing the mosque
Which Mosque. This mosque was well worth a walk. Quiet and more accessable than the Blue Mosque.
Worth the visit`. Near the ocean and spice bazaar. Well taken care off and takes you to a different era
Beautiful. Well worth the extra walk as it is empty and no queues to get inside. Another stunning interior and gardens
Captivating. Arrived very early and found myself alone in this wonderful site. Having seen it dominate the Istanbul skyline I was delighted to finally go there in person. Truly a beautiful experience
Great place . .. Great place . . .but pity about the vast crowds . . .

Call to Prayer. Go to the mosque, go to all the famous ones...they are all wonderful in their own ways, but my favorite thing was to sit outside during the call to prayer...you do not have to be islamic to feel a stirring of emotion as the call to prayer sings out across the city from the hundreds of mosques that dot the neighborhoods.

Do not miss this place; it fills you with tranquility and almost transcends. Oner Ayan. I have visited many other religious places; churches, mosques, temples; but the light and the air in this place is different. If you go there during Ramadan, then it is totally a different experience; a better one. During Friday noon, you will see it very crowded, but in one hour it will be quiet and calming again. Go inside, sit down and stay for 15 minutes, look around; you will feel different. Oner Ayan

Beautiful and less crowded. Don't miss. The beauty is on par with the blue mosque, but with less crowds. You can take more time to enjoy. Great views across the Golden Horn in back. Walking distance to the University and Grand Bazaar.
mosque and sinan tomb. beautiful grounds, architechtural wonder, Sinan's tomb
Liked it more than Blue Mosq. Very impressive, very clear inside. Beautifull total site with view over Galata bridge site

Magnificent architecture. The Suleymaniye Mosque do not get as many tourists as the Blue Mosque but it is so beautiful and really worth a visit. The Mosque was build by Sinan and is an exceptionally beautiful example of Ottoman architecture. It is set in big grounds and you should walk around and also visit the tombs in the grounds. From the back of the Mosque you will have a lovely view of the Bosphorus and the Galata bridge. The surrounding area is interresting to eplore. You can take the tram to the Beyazit (Grand Bazaar) stop. Or walk from Sultanahmet as we did.Facing the bazaar towards your left is the big gates of the University. On the left side of the gates you will see the sign for the Suleymaniye Mosque. Just walk up the road and the roads ends at the entrance to the Mosque.
Walk from Spice Bazzar ro suleymaniye Mosque. Here it was not as crowded as at the Sultanahmet area. Good view from the top overlooking the sea.

"breathtaking". As a Muslim i was looking forward to coming here. Make sure out of respect you have a scarf and have your lgs covered. Scarves and bag are provided to place your shoes in. Entrance is delayd 10 mins at prayer time, however the queues are large in the morning. Best time to go is 1400 onwards when the rush has moved on.Take time to sit somwhere and just admire the workmanship, architecture and sense of peace. the photos i have taken have come out wonderful. Highly recommend a visit here - read up on the history and catch good shots from most angles.There is a ladies secton gaurded by screens if you wish to say a prayer. So glad i visited this pleace took my breath away.
secret place. this mosque is so beatifull and more attractive then others....secret place not so many tourists around.you should walk all around the place
Super view. Wonderful view from up here. Make sure to get a coffee or drink in "Addicts Alley" and watch the people and cats.

Go to the north wall outside the mosque for a great view. Very clear, airy, bright mosque. The views from the north wall of the mosque's boundaries is unmissable - looks out over the old town, the golden horn and bosphorous - but is a little tucked away

Go for Friday Prayers. I am not Muslim but attended Friday evening prayers and was awed by the experience. Tourists and non-Muslims are welcome, as you adhere to the rules--basically, take your shoes off (women cover heads) and act like you're at church and not Disneyland.
Beautiful architecture. I loved the decoration on the ceilings, the mosques are stunning and beautiful to look at.
Impressive. Situated on a hill, this big mosque deserves a visit! For the ladies: don't forget to bring something to cover your hair.
Gloriously renovated. This is Sinan's largest mosque and is stunning in its size and design.
a must see place. if you go to Istambul and just have time for one think make it this, it will worth the visit
elegant. I enjoyed the delicacy and elegance of this beautiful mosque.

Not a fan of historical sites but this mosque is unique.. Specially the columns inside and the dome is breath taking, also try to listen pray(called "ezan") when two prayers of Sultanahmet and Hagia Sophia make duet... Unforgettable...
Very peaceful place. A the top of a hill next to the university. You climb through the windy streets of the old town to get there. It's a pleasant mosque with a nice little garden adjacent.

Magnificent. Among the most impressive mosques built by the famous architect Sinan (compared with Michelangelo), this mosque gives to the visitor the image of the "possible impossible", realised following the desire of Suleiman the Magnificent.
Average. Not as nice as we were told, but OK. I will say average.
Just Another Mosque. Neat architecture, but we weren't able to go inside. Lot's of large mosques to see in Istanbul, so if you don't make it here, don't worry...you're bound to pass another.

Peaceful place. There's not a lot of visitors like the Blue mosque but this place is real nice. Less crowd. Sit down for about 10 mins and sink it all in. Read the pamphlets and take pictures. Watch the ppl praying and just take it all in.
Interesting. Beautiful, but not as impressive as the Hagia Sophia

Observe the detail to appreciate the whole. Being very much in the working heart of Istanbul, I gained a much better impression of how the mosque is part of the daily religious life of the city and its citizens than at the Blue Mosque. Partly because it is further away from the main tourist areas and partly because of the architecture this has a wonderful sense of calm and space. As in all historic Istanbul mosques, the detail is worth seeking out and taking time to appreciate: the stained-glass windows, the calligraphy on the walls, the beautiful tiles and the patterns on the carpets.

Perhaps the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul.. This is one of Sinan's masterpieces. The soaring dome and muted blue decorations are splendid. Be certain to tour around the entire complex and stop by Sinan's tomb directly behind the mosque complex.

Another beautiful mosque of Istanbul. Some say that this mosque is more beautiful than the Blue Mosque so we made sure that we visited it. The architecture is perhaps a little more pleasing to the eye from the outside but the inside of the Blue Mosque is as beautiful as Suleymaniye. The Suleymaniye quibla wall is perhaps just a little more intricate and sophisticated in decoration. It is quite a long walk to get to from Sultanahmet (and quite easy to get lost). If you have limited time in Istanbul then you could just visit the Blue Mosque.Practical tips - there is a separate tourist entrance through the courtyard to the left of the main entrance. When there are prayers, there will be a sign put up and you cannot enter but it will indicate approximately how long prayers will last. You can wait either in this big courtyard or in the gardens at the front where there are lots of benches. On the left as you go in through the tourst entrance are head scarves that ladies can borrow for free.
Beautiful mosque. Suleymaniye Mosque is a beautiful mosque, located in an excellent location. Quite rushy place, specially on weekends.

One of Islam's principal mosques.. Also know as the "Blue Mosque" it competes with the St. Sophia basilica for the title of the most beautiful building of worship in Turkey and one of the most beautiful in the world.

Fantastic architecture and views. A bit of a climb to get here but boy, was it worth it !Stunning architecture and views. Not crowded when we visited. Free entrance. Respect that it is a functioning mosque !

Must See. extraordinary historical site in Istanbul. the blue tiles are beautiful and the central dome takes your breath away but the thing that really amazed me was the hundreds of lamps that could be raised and lowered within the room. Like all the mosques in Instanbul - the Blue Mosque is in use as a place of worship for Muslims so pick your timing right to avoid the daily prays and remember to take your shoes off at the entrance. Well worth visiting.

suleymaniye mosque. as i stayed at Istanbul Inn at Sultan Ahmet Mosque area it was a good idea to go walk around to warm my body(morning exercise).as before during my visit to galata tower by crossing galata bridge i can see a wonderful mosque on the top of a hill.i thought it was too far to go by walk. after finished visiting the galata tower to went to brosphrous cruse tour and then went back to hotel.the next morning i went to the grand bazar located not far from my hotel. after spent a n hour inside i went to see some tourist attraction around. from there i went to a nearby Istanbul University and entered its compound. as i went deep inside the compound i was so surprised as infront of me standing a magnificent building known as suleymaniye mosque. i went inside the compound and entered the building. wow awesome architecture by the turkish architect.i took the opportunity to capture picture of the mosque. as i looked to the asia side of istanbul i can see the galata tower and the galata bridge.wow wonderful scene. around the mosque i can see restaurant serving turkist foods. after spending more tahn one hour roaming around then it was time for me to go back to my hotel. for those of you who wise to visit istanbul dont forget to visit this mosque. there is no need to use taxi. just walk through the narrow street of istanbul university. you may use map to guide you to the location.
Better than the Blue Mosque. The interior is elegant and the architecture sublime. Makes the Blue Mosque look like a bourgeois imitation. Like Carla Bruni compared to the Queen.
Beautiful. Just go inside and you will see a beautiful building with wonderful colors and a magnificent sphere!
Smaller than the Blue Mosque, but not in impact. Such a beautiful mosque and surrounds. Seemed more intimate than the Blue Mosque and less of a tourist attraction somehow. We liked it a lot.

This is a lovely, peaceful accessible mosque without hoards of tourists. Our daughter, who has been living in Istanbul for the last 9 months, insisted that we go to this mosque as it is her favorite. We could easily see why when we got there. The grounds and courtyard are lovely and peaceful. There were no tour buses, unlike the Aya Sophia or the Blue Mosque. The interior is simple in terms of design, but lovely to look at. There is a visitors entrance where you are provided with a plastic bag to place your shoes and carry them. Women must cover their head and shoulders and knees. Men must cover their knees, meaning no shorts. Please respect this as we did see a few people who did not. There are two sets of washrooms that are lovely and clean. One side you must pay one lira to use, the other is free. Not sure why the difference but the free one is outside the courtyard area on the northern side of the mosque. There are Western and Turkish toilets in both.

beautiful beautiful.... This mosque is situated on top of a hill near the university,We visited at sunset.the mosque is absolutely beautiful inside,and has lovely surrounding gardens to relax and marvel at the structure.The architecture is simply stunning.Be sure to eat at one of the little cafes outside the mosque.a short walk and you're at the grand Bazaar!

Big and beautiful. Best approached from the direction of the Grand Bazaar - coming from the Golden Horn / Eminönü side mens afair climb - this is an architectural masterpiece that at least rivals the "Blue Mosque". The grave of the architect Mimar Sinan is nearby.
Exotic. Beautiful building both inside and outside. One request to other visitors, ladies, please respect other cultures and cover your head, legs and shoulders - many ignore the request

One of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul. The Blue Mosque is a must see on most travelers itineraries but I think Suleymaniye is more beautiful. The interior feels light and airy and it is truly elegant.
Peace and tranquility. This mosque did not sem to be frequented by the coach loads of tourists from the Cruise Liners. it was peaceful, beautiful and very calm and well worth the walk to get to it

Huge!. The biggest of Istanbul's mosques, it is not the most beautiful (that is the Blue Mosque), but it's huge size is counterbalanced by its apparent lightness. It truly deserves a visit, and you can also visit Suleyman and his wife's tomb in the cemetery. It also offers beautiful views on the city.
So so. Nice to visit, but not that much to engagge you with it if you're not religious.
GREAT DATE. This is a must see mosque - huge, beautiful and fascinating.
Impressive mosque. So big, clean, peaceful. Very impressive. We heard it has been renovated recently: this is definitely a success. And the view to the city from there is great
How many times can you say "Wow!". Beautiful experience, appreciate the opportunity to see this magnificent building. Be aware that tourists aren't allowed in the Mosque during prayer services.
A must see. It is clean and well maintained, sometimes overshadowed by the blue mosque...but serene. The wishing well was good too.
Be just yourself, a good place to thank God for everything. A good first step for awakening, next you should go to Eyup Sultan on the Golden Horn

Beautiful. This mosque is simply amazing. The construction is fantastic and interior decor is gorgeous. It is no wonder people call it the most beautiful mosque in Turkey.
Although the building itself may not be as striking as the Ayasofya (Hagia Sofia) or Sultan Ahmet Camii (Blue Mosque), the interior certainly is.

Similar to the others, less crowded. Another beautiful mosque. Michael Palin's favorite in Istanbul, it has a nice courtyard with flowers and trees, same breathtaking, huge interior as the Blue Mosque.It's on the campus of Istanbul University, so wander North-ish through the Grand Bazaar to get there. The Suleymaniye Mosque is a nice place to go for a reprieve from the flocks of tourists surrounding central Sultanahmet.
Mosque, the sound was so beautiful.. I think that this is the perfect place of worship of Muslims.Mosque, the sound made ​​me very happy, peaceful moments lived.

Which mosque is more beautiful?. It is hard to say which mosque is more beautiful in Istanbul...they are all amazing and many were designed by the same architect, so they have some subtle similarities.All are worth visiting and you should not miss this one.Entrance to mosques is free, so beware of people who try to charge you to get in! You will have to put your shoes in plastic bags that they provide and wear a wrap, that they also provide, over shorts, mini skirts, and bare shoulders. We did not need to cover our heads.

Quiet. After the crowds at the Blue Mosque we found this mosque far more peaceful and just as impressive, no queueing to get in either, nice grounds and an interesting high view point from the top of the old gate by the university.
Pretty Mosque. This mosque was airy, light and prettier than the Blue Mosque. An uphill walk but worth it.
Biggest mosque. It was a great mosque and I have learnt that it is the biggest mosque in Istanbul. Definetely visit that great mosque.
Beautiful at night. Situated at a top of a hill, with its beautiful lights of the minares, it's a lovely sight at night.
A must. Beautiful mosque! Inside is so harmonious, colors are lovely, the dome is awe inspiring. If you're a muslim, then you really can't miss going inside and praying...

Perhaps the most beautiful mosque in the world?. Hard to distinguish between the beautiful mosques in Istanbul, but Sulemaniye mosque certainly stands out as EVEN MORE beautiful than the rest. It stands out too when compared to mosques in North Africa and the Middle East - and it's great that non-Muslims can visit too. Don't forget to dress respectfully (a mini-skirt and a headscarf don't quite cut it!), and enjoy
Suleymaniye. Beautifull harmonious simple design and very light inside. The surroundings also very pleasant and some reasonable restaurants for lunch with a view of the mosque.
good to visit. It’s a place you have to visit it spatially if you have read sultan Sulaiman story you really want to see his mosque and visit his grave.

Definitely worth going to. Although it was outside of the main historic district, this mosque is definitely worth going to. While the Blue Mosque is more impressive on the outside, the inside of this mosque may have been even nicer. Very large and impressive domes. If you want a great picture of it, go down to the docks at Eminonu. If you do, be sure to get a chicken and french fry sandwich for less than $3 USD.
Gorgeous!. This feels like a real mosque that locals use - whereas the Blue Mosque is a virtual traffic jam of tourists.

Spectacular. Thıs ıs probably the most spectacular camıı of them all. It sıts beautıfully on the top of a hıll and a bıt of a hıke to get to ıt, but ıt's worth ıt at the end. Go at prayer tıme and get the complete experıence.
grandiose. this is not merely a mosque, it's an entire complex. there was a hospice, school, baths, soup kitchen and more in this vast complex. the view of istanbul and the golden horn is splendid.

beautiful tile work grounds and views. Go early to avoid crowds. Fee is 25 to get in but another 15 to see harem quarters which was not in guudebook. Lines to see treasures and srtifacts were the longest
wonderful. Visit the Suleymaniye Hammam and then go this mosque afterwards. Also have tea in the courtyard.
Fascinating. So great to visit these old buildings - this was unlike any place we've ever been.
i love it. i loved that mosque and you will like its story and how it was built and how long it took
It is a wonder. It is wonderful mosque and there are alot of interesting things to see inside and its free to enter.
Excellent.... Definitely worth visiting here. Striking architecture. Amazing feat of engineering considering the time it was constructed. Beautiful interior.
Don't miss. Compare to the blue mosk so as to better understand the different architecture and reasons for it. Watch prayer times as you will not be able to get in.
Incredible!. This is a must see mosque - huge, beautiful and fascinating. The decorations here are crisper and more restrained than some of the other mosques - but no less impressive!
Filled with light and tranquillity. A first class experience! A magnificent building, graceful and peaceful. We were welcomed kindly and delighted in the soaring spiritual architecture.
Historical. Istanbul is blessed with history and this is the reason for my visit

Stunning. From the moment I walked down the steps and set my eyes upon this wonderful construction I was blown away and awestruck with its grandeur Built in 527-565 I would rate the cisterns as one of the wonders of the world

Beautiful surroundings. The mosque is beautiful, but what I really liked and I think makes it so special is the surroundings. There are gardens all around the mosque and a wall, it is really beautiful. We were there on a cold afternoon and I don´t know if it is always as peaceful as it was when we were there but I really enjoyed it. We were kind of in a hurry and I wished a had had much more time to spend there and take pictures.

Best Mosque in Istanbul. One of the best Mosque in the World, a master piece.Quiet, clean, perfect!No gold, no ceramic but a master piece of a genius architect.The grand bazar is just 2 steps from the Mosque and the view over the golden horn is magic.The are id still in renovation, but the mosque can be visited without a problem (except during the prayers times).
The best. Very peaceful and beautiful, a great scenic view. Not a long walk from tram stop, but get out your map.

More impressive than the Blue Mosque. Surrounded by a serene courtyard, the Suleymaniye Mosque was the most breathtaking of the seven mosques I saw here. An exquisite work of art in every way, this mosque should not be missed. After Hagia Sophia, this is the next most beautiful structure in Istanbul.

Not quite as pretty as the Blue Mosque. Not quite as pretty as the Blue (Sultanahmet) Mosque, and a bit further from the touristy Sultanahmet centre, but a lot quieter and more peaceful. There's an excellent view of the Bosphorus and the bridge from the gardens too. (Plastic bags are provided for your shoes, and they request you dress conservatively - no shorts, with shoulders and arms covered, and women should cover their head with a scarf.)
Fantastic. Beautiful colours, courtyard is great, peace and quiet
Stunning. Eat the the local restaurant - Daruzzuyafe - the old soup kitchen. Extensive menu with attratcrive courtyard garden.
Architect Sinan's masterpiece. Size, dome, courtyards all are sensational. Probably best Turkish construction of history

Worth the "detour". The mosque itself is the equal to the Blue, but the grounds, (with the associated park and landscaping) make this one worth a visit. It is a little to the west of most other sights, but the surrounding streets are also a bit more authentic and less touristy. Definitely worth the time to look around here and get a better sense of more "real" Old city Istanbul.

Nice during the day, beautiful a few minutes after the sunset. The better time to take pictures is a few minutes after the sunset when there is a few day light and the city lights are already on. Just magic!
The best Mosque. Is our favorite Mosque in Istanbul: the architecture, the design and the history. It is one of the best places to visit in this lovely city that is Istanbul.

Disappointed. I had hoped for more from the Suleymaniye Mosque. While its proportions are outstanding, I really like decoration in the form of tiles and mosaics, and that is just not the case for this mosque. It is very spare in that regard.
Beautiful as you would expect. This is just as good as you would expect. be prepared to queue. For my money, the Sheikh Zayed Mosque in Abu Dhabi is more beautiful, but this is good.
Spectacular. Loved this mosque from sinan the great. Enjoyed the Turkish baths by sinan also nearby
Watch out for prayer times!. Interesting mosque and campus. However, if you get there at the time of the midday prayers, there's an hour wait to see the interior of the mosque.
Another can't skip in Istanbul. This is a very beautiful building that delivers an entirely different feeling than a Christian church.

The best mosque to visit.. Not only the biggest mosque in the city, but also a great location with panoramic city views from the gardens. It adjoins Istanbul Uni which is well worth a visit, and nearby the Ali Baba restaurant, the best place we found for lunch, packed with locals and really good value.

One of the best mosques in Istanbul. This mosque and Blue mosque are always at the top of peoples lists. I'd say that Suleymaniye Mosque has a better courtyard and a great view of the bosphourous, and the interior feels spacious as its made of whites and greys with red accents. However I just personally like the tile work in Blue Mosque a little better.
Blue Mosque. This is a fabulous place to visit and a must if you are in Istanbul for the first time. Take time to savour it and soak up the rich history.
East Meets West. Fantastic Building which help one understand the history of this Nation

Worth the trip.... This was a surprise site for us. After visiting the Spice Bazaar we wondered out into the streets and just started walking. As we continued away from the Spice Bazaar we found streets that seemed to be themed with stores and wares. One block was selling housewares, the next hardware, the next appliances, the next plumbing and so on. We turned up to the left (away from the Golden Horn) towards a great Mosque we could see up on the hill. After passing through an interesting neighborhood showing what appeared to be true Istanbul life of a certain kind, and after climbing rather steep hills - we arrived at what turned out to be the Suleymaniye Mosque. This was truly worth the effort. What a stunning place - I actually liked it better than the Blue Mosque. There were far fewer tourists here - so the experience was better. Upon exiting, we were hungry and enjoyed a nice meal at a restaurant just outside the exit/entrance. The north side of the Mosque courtyard offered sweeping views of the city and the Golden Horn. Make the trip here - it will be worth the time. Enjoy!

A joy after restoration. The masterpice of Mimar Sinan is finishing its restauration. The complñex has been fully refurbished recently, except the Mausoleum aea still under work (beggining of april 2012). A must of islamic architecture.
Reverence to the Dead Sultans. You could so eaisly pass this very interesting resting place located opposite the Grand Mosque. You can photography, but do not touch.

Absolutely stunning. The walk up to the Suleymaniye Mosque is part of the experience. The streets are noisy and utterly cramped and become progressively narrower until, following a corridor with an obstructed view, the Mosque rises from the ground. It's larger than the Blue Mosque and far more picturesque. The surrounding area is a well-maintained courtyard with seating and .. cats. Love the Turkish cats. The scope of the Mosque is such that, in the noon to afternoon sun, it looks more like a matte painting than a three dimensional object. The cafes that are outside of the mosque, though still with a view of it, are quiet and nice places to relax before heading down.
Stunning mosque,. The other huge mosque with a white outer courtyard. All in pristine condition. Good views of Istanbul.

Not my favourite. It's a famous mosque but I actually did not find it that amazing. Found other mosques that I would go to before this one.And also, in the facts of the place it says that Sinan was the architect of this mosque and therefore it had many similarities to Hagia Sophia. Hagia Sophia was built in the 6th century and Sinan made only smaller changes to Hagia Sophia in the 16th century. More or less Hagia Sophia is considered to be a masterpiece of architecture and therefor has become the role model of mosques built - also Suleymaniye (just for the wiseacre architect in me)

Very Impressive Building, Shame about the visitors.
