Visit was ruined by the disrespectful tourists who refused to wear head cover, spoke loudly/shouted despite signs requesting silence, took numerous flash photos and encroached the prayer the enclosed area just so they could get an even better snap.Otherwise a mightily impressive structure.Having recently visited Morocco, where foreigners/tourists are not permitted into mosques, it is hard to disagree with the Moroccans.

An out of the way mosque worth trekking to. Situated at the other end of the Grand Bazaar its a bit of trek through the markets but your efforts will be rewarded with a sublime mosque designed by The Christopher Wren of mosque architecture. We loved the street food in the cafes around the perimeter.

Atmospheric and quieter than the "big sights". The Mosque was as enjoyable as the Blue Mosque but without the people. It may not be as intricate inside however the courtyards and grounds were as pretty. One of our favourite cheap eats were located next door in the cafes serving beans and rice.
Amazing. Not many tourist venture here but this mosque was fabulous and certainly worth a visit. There are small markets nearby and the side streets where the locals shop were very well prices.
Cold winter's day. A spectacular structure, but still an active mosque. Our stockinged feet were cold, even on the carpets, on a chilly winter's day.
Largest Mosque in Istanbul. Suleymaniye is a newer mosque near Istanbul University and over looking Bosphorus. It's definitely worth a walk uphill!

Very nice place. This mosque is very big, the grounds are very pretty and the view from the top of the hill is gorgeous. You can walk there from the Spice Market but be ware it's up hill. It's worth the walk because you'll cross the commercial areas of Istanbul, lots of wholesale stores with accessories, cooking ware and home goods. The Mosque is big, you can easily appreciate the basic structure of a Mosque and it's grounds: the kitchen, the cemetery, the main building, the traveler's home, etc. Go to the back and take a look at the water, it's very nice.
Lovely restoratıon. A 'must see' ıf you are ınterested ın vısıtıng mosques.
Beautiful. A lovely mosque to go and see. Very peaceful and time for reflection.
very impressive piece of Sinan architecture. really impressive piece of architecture! Very easy to get into with clear instructions at the entrance for Westerners.
OK. I preferred. the Blue Mosque. This for me was just another example of a Mosque. I did not find any specifics to set it apart.

Beautiful!. My favourite sight seeing monument!
We went in the morning, it was so calm and peaceful and the inside is so pretty! I would definitely recommend seeing this Mosque

Wonderful view of a mosque in use. Superb building. Huge domw made intimiate buy the low light and the the light circles suspended a few metres from the carpet.
Immense output of plastic covers for every tourist foot before entry.
Make sure you walk around the outside as well !!
Suleymaniye. My friend took me there and I felt such an experience in this, I believe, the 3rd larges mosque in the world. The restauration is fantastic
Suleymaniye. One of, Great Architect Sinan's master piece. The big columns and the getaway's for the candle smut(smog) is a thing to research.

Don't tell the secret. Most people go to the Blue Mosque (it's central, close to things and no need to "climb") but Suleymaniye is actually bigger, although not so decorated. It's on top of the hill, so the view is great and the walk (up and down) is very nice, going through a nice old quarter. The surroundings are equally interesting!
This is the one to see!. There are a lot of mosques in Istanbul so if you are limited in time this is the one to choose
Huge and Moving. Magnificent building out and in. As a non muslim, found it all very moving and different in many ways to Christian churches

Hard to find but worth it in the end. It is truly difficult to find this place. My spouse has amazing directional skills, and it was still difficult! This mosque is more amazing than the Blue Mosque. The interior is ornate and detailed. Must SEE!
A huge place. We had to take off our shoes which we could take with us,the ceilings were amazing,a very spiritual place.

Don't Miss!. This is one of three don't-miss mosques in Istanbul, along with the Blue Mosque and Rustem Pasha. The architect, Sinan, is at his very best here, and the view from the inner courtyard up at the domes and minarets is breath-taking. See this one before the Blue Mosque so that you can fully appreciate its elegant understatement.
Unbelievable. That mosque is the biggest mosque in Istanbul (maybe in the world ) I just admired
Nice Mosque. Very nice Mosque, well decorated and with nice gardens that give views over the city

An amazing building. Nestled in the middle of bustling Istanbul University streets, old city walls and market traders, the Suleymaniye Mosque is of striking beauty and grace.It is more impressive than the Blue Mosque, I would say- and a powerful place to visit.When we were there the Prime Minister of Turkey attended Friday prayers so the place was rife with security officers and police, which all added to the excitement! but hey, if it's good enough for him...
Peaceful. A bit more out of the way than some other sights. Graveyard area very peaceful to wander about. Stunning architecture.
One of the nicer mosques.. This is one of the prettiest mosques in Istanbul as well S one of the largest. It is very well maintained.
Beautiful. This is a mosque that is not very touristic, but the architecture, thanks to Sinan, is splendid.

IZNIK TILES. Everywhere blue tiles on the walls,Only Mecca Grand Mosque and Blue Mosque have 5 minareds!!!!.Sinan architect build it across the Hagia Sophia to confront the size and the brilliance of the Greek Church.Enter there barefoot..only.

Amazing Mosque, bad area. The mosque was worth the trip because as bonus you get to visit the tomb of its architect Sinan. The only thing that killed this trip for me was the fact that I was handed a counterfeit 20 bill in change after paying in one of the surrounding cafes. Avoid the surrounding shops but definitely add this mosque to your itinerary.
my favorite place in istanbul!. It is the most beautiful mosque in Istanbul with own special spirit.

Watch out for the other visitors !. An incredibly beautiful building, but the disrespect of the fellow tourists who chattered loudly while people were praying was quite incredible You are asked, as a woman, to cover your head with a scarf, which is provided in case you have not got one, and not to talk while you are inside. Unfortunately we were surrounded by three different groups who ignored this completely and chattered away loudly, ruining the atmosphere of this incredible building. It ruined the visit. Would love to go back another day and see it without this distraction !

Brilliant mosque. was under renovation for ages,we went there for three years and it wasnt completed untill last year.Its truly magnificent.400 years old cemetry and old kitchen is just adjacent to it.Not far from Byazit tram station.
Impressive. Another beautiful mosque with impressive size and solemn experience.
Beautiful archttecture. Stop there and keep watching, everything is perfect...
mosque. this mosque is very old and it says us the old architect dezine of istanbul the marble and the tiles dezines are very good
Breathtaking building. Also known as the Blue Mosque. The size and beauty of this building is incredible, inside and out. When inside-look up at the dome.An absolute MUST for a visit.
Off the beaten tourist track. Similar to Blue Mosque but little to no tourists. Got to catch this during prayer which was a spinetingling moment. Nice restaurants nearby.

Beautiful mosque. We stopped by the Suleymaniye Mosque on our last morning in Istanbul and I'm glad we did! The mosque was a 20 minute walk from our hotel but it was easy to find. The building itself is gorgeous and the grounds well tended. While not as big or quite so awe inspiring as the Blue Mosque the Suleymaniye Mosque is well worth a stop. We visited on a Monday so some of the areas were closed to the public.

More modern than blue mosque. Comparing to blue mosque it has more modern color inside.. more orange color and less flower pattern. But I like this mosque much better especially from the outside. Its more tidy and tranquil in my eyes. Must go site for me personally
one of worlds' wonderful places. no words to say, you must step inside and feel the aura of this great place.
peaceful, amazing. the architecture is spectacular. stay for one of the prayer services - the Quran recitations are incredibly soothing.

Amazing. This is also a must-see in Istanbul. A little harder to get to than the Blue Mosque or Aya Sofya but incredible once inside. The views over the city from the back terrace facing the Bosphorus are worth going for alone

Blue Mosque a must. First time inside a Mosque - and was so shocked as to how beautiful it was! Absolute amazement inside the mosque. Unbelievable. As a Christian, didn't know a whole lot about Islam - other than the obvious. Our tour guide was fantastic and really explained the whole procedure of prayers and the "basics" of Islam. definitely a must see.
One of our favorite Mosques!. There are several beautiful mosques in Istanbul but this one stands out as a shining example.

Süleymaniye Camii. This Ottoman style mosque is well worth the visit in my opinion. It is right next to the Spice market which really shouldn't be missed as a feature of Istanbul. The majestic Bosphorus is right across the road as is the Sirkeci Garı, the quaint Turkish rail Station which at one time launched the Orient Express.  The vaulted domes of Süleymaniye Camii are mind boggling and the courtyard for washing feet and hands is particularly lovely. This is a well used Mosque and so it is important to visit with reverence. Women should cover their heads and shoes need to me removed. I loved the rose, green, and gold colored domes and the incredible ornament of this place. It is especially lovely at night as it is entirely lit up and easy to see from the Karakoy or Galata side of the water. This mosque is truly a beauty.

Captivating. We walked to the Suleymaniye mosque from the Spice Bazaar. It felt like an extremely long walk as it was all up hill (and freezing cold!) but it was worth the hike as we got to see panoramic views of the city on the sea. We later realised you can take a tram to Beyazit and the walk from there is much quicker as it is behind the Istanbul University. At some points we werent sure if we were going in the right direction as there are no signs anywhere!! However as we approached the top of the hill through very narrow lanes we saw a sign which indicated it was close by. The mosque is fascinating but it is important to know about the history for it to really have an impact on you. Otherwise it would just look like every other mosque in Istanbul. The tile work is beautiful and i could not help but constantly stare at the ceiling in awe. Women are required to cover their head and dress modestly as it is still an active place of worship and of course both men and women need to remove their shoes before entering however there are plastic bags outside that you can use to carry your shoes in. Best of all its free to visit and you probably only need 30 mins or so to see the entire mosque. It is closed to tourists during prayer times and you cant take any photos during these times.
Its not something special. Big Mosque with great history but its not something special.

Not worth the hike.. We approached from the Spice Bazaar...it was like climbing Everest - especially with the icy conditions we had. Poorly sign-posted (some graffiti actually helped to show the way) and involving plenty of alley-ways I would have preferred to avoid I was extremely disappointed on arrival. We spent maybe 10/15 mins inside. It was nothing special at all. The surrounding area was also disappointing and felt a little dodgy. There was, like with the Topkapi palace, no sense of this complex as it may have been used. Addicts alley was quite grim and we couldn't wait to leave the area. I cannot understand why this is rated so highly.

Huge and impressive Mosque. This must be one of the biggest mosques in the City and surrounded by linked buildings. The tile work was brilliant and the interior beautiful. Nice ground but snowing when we were there.
Beautiful and serene. Loved the architectural aesthetic, sad that the tombs of Suleyman and Roxelana were closed at the time

Favourite Mosque in Istanbul. Suleymaniye mosque is beautiful and recently renovated. It's an active mosque and you can enter, but not take pictures, during prayer time. Women should, but unfortunately often don't, cover their hair and arms and wear a skirt - scarves and skirt wraps are provided at the entrance if you're not dressed properly. I found it to be much more beautiful than the Blue Mosque - the interior is much lighter and more delicate. It's behind the university and easy to find - it's a nice walk uphill from the Spice Bazaar. I've visited the mosque four times now.

Poor copy of Hagia Sophia. It is enough to watch this mosque from outside. Inside of it, there are only hundreds of carpets, placed with no care about colors, a lot of barefoot people and some arabic letters all around.

Amazing interior, recently renovated. It was a little hike to the top of the hill this mosque sits on, but really worth it! It was recently renovated--the interior is immaculate but it's over 400 years old! On the grounds are the impressive tombs of Suleyman and Roxelana, who have a very interesting history.
Big Mosque. Suleymaniye Mosque is old mosque also new mosque. there is really big and nice .
Beautiful. Stunning mosque especially in the night :) We were mesmerized by this place

Less people and looks nicer than Blue Mosque. Less tourists inside so it was better for taking pictures. Even though Blue Mosque looks prettier outside this one is nicer in the inside and better maintained. But after you've visited one mosque the others look the same.
marvelous. exactly what you expect from previous pictures, but the impact to actually see it is amazing
GREAT. I had really looked forward to visiting the Suleymaniye Mosque and I was not disappointed at all...
Calm and beautiful. Sometimes its in shadow of Blue Mosque, but whey you catch right time, its so peacefull place to rest... Just calmly sit and watch magnificent cemii.

Suleymaniye. It's a good example of beautiful architecture, and there are wonderful views of Istanbul from the mosque. However, the security guard intimidated us by forcing us to go behind the visitors barrier, even though it wasn't prayer time.

Impressive site. I arrived there shortly before prayer so my trip was more rushed than it would have been at another time. Still I could not help comparing it to the incomparable Blue Mosque. It is beautiful, to be sure, and certainly worth a visit.

Extraordinary.... We walked through snowy streets through the university from Beyazit to this wonderful Mosque. The sun came out as we arrived and the whole building was surrounded by snow and glowing. Light and airy interior, simpler than the Blue Mosque and empty of tourists. Not always on the top 5 attractions for some reason because this is the best mosque in Istanbul, end of story...

Fascinating Mosque made by Sinan. this is a giant mosque and splendid architecture. For me a piece of art that i couldn't stop admiring it. everybody visits Aya Sophia or Sultan Ahmet which are a must to see for sure but this one is unique for me.you have to spend enough time there. I surprised that there are so many persian texts on memorials and thombs.

Wow. Loved how big this place was and as it was snowing when i visited it made it more beautiful. I liked the fact that you were able to go in and visit but didnt like that many tourists that visited didnt adhere to covering up to respect the faith and culture of locals who were also there
Not to be missed!!!. You must not go to Istanbul without seeing this wonderful, architectural marvel. Amazing!!!
Should definitely see it if in Istanbul. Very welcoming and many people ready to share information in an enthusiastic and inclusive way.

One of the best mosques. My 22 year old son and I visited in June '11. While the Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque are wonderful, there is something special about "discovering" this mosque away from the crowds in the Sultanahmet area. No lines the day we were there. We could take our time in the mosque and walk around the grounds. As you can see in the pictures this is a beautiful and peaceful place

Impressive, though a bit unconfortable.. Despite the bad weather, the Mosque is really worth the visit. Unfortunately it is horrible when you get out of it and you have to put on your shoes in cold open air (while at the entrance they made a covered area for taking our the shoes).
Most impressive of the Mosques.. Beautiful. Seemed to be the best preserved of the mosques we toured. About a 20 min. walk from our Millennium Suites hotel...just past the Grand Bazaar.

A magnificent Mosque dominating the Istanbul skyline. This large Mosque exudes peace and solemnity. It has a vast dome and wonderful decoration. From the tranquility of the Mosque and its surroundings the visitor can quickly make their way to the bustle of the bazaar quarter
sultan suleyman mosque. Sultan suleyman ordered Sinan to build this mosque. They made it bigger then Hagia Sophia. Sinan is a well known architect build many mosques and bridges.

Interesting place to visit. The mosque is quite impressing from the outside. The gardens are nicely kept and there are some lovely cats there. The inside is beautiful but I was more impressed by the interior of the Blue Mosque. The row of restaurants/cafes provides a good resting spot.

Excellent, not very crowded. This mosque is in Galina bridge area. We went there in the evening and it was not as crowded as the Blue Mosque. The architecture is as fascinating and you can examine it in detail without being rushed through the crowds

Most beautiful Mosque in Istanbul. For me is the best mosque in istanbul... more than Blue Mosque..
it's really important go there to see this perfect place!

The Blue Mosque. I loved the Mosque! I walked all the way around the outside, took numerous pictures from various places around the Mosque and inside the Mosque when I went in. One of my night shots from a "Panoramic" restaurant will make my calendar next year for sure. I appreciated the opportunity to go inside and take in the beauty and even though I am not Muslim, I felt it was a very spiritual place to visit.
Beautiful. You can not go to Istanbul without visiting this beautiful Mosque
Place where you feel quiet. I like the place because you really feel it is holy and you can pray there.
Wow. The Süleymaniye Mosque is an Ottoman imperial mosque located on the Third Hill of Istanbul, Turkey. It is the second largest mosque in the city, and one of the best ...
Dont miss it!. You wont believe the acoustique this mosque have and dont forget to visit tumb of sultan suleyman beside of the mosque
Must see. One of the prime sights to be seen. Terrific view from the grounds.
One of the best mosques in Istanbul. One of my favorite mosques in Istanbul. Fantastic place. While you're inside the feeling is as your soul is flying high. Definitely must visit to all.

quiet lovely space to reflect in. Walking into a mosque is like walking into tranquility - you remove your shoes of course, but it is all carpeted, so unlike a church there are no echoes and the ceilings are beautifully decorated. It seems warm compared to a church.

Beautiful and less crowded than Blue Mosque. We really enjoyed this mosque. There are FAR fewer tourists than at the blue mosque, so we felt that we got to enjoy the inside more. People seemed more respective here and were quiet inside and wore scarves on their heads. There were also no touts in the courtyard trying to sell us carpets - huge plus. The tiles inside are gorgeous and as I mentioned it is much more peaceful than the blue mosque. For those reasons I highly recommend visiting this mosque.There is also a good view of the new city from the outside grounds. We walked here from the ferry boat terminals and walked to the grand bazaar afterwards. The walks are definitely doable and we did not experience any hassle becuase there are less tourists in this area. There are free bathrooms on the side that exits towards the walled Istanbul University. Entry to the mosque is free and they give you bags for your shoes. It also looked like they had scarves to borrow for those ladies that forget to bring one.
Finally !. This mosque has long been in the remodeling and renovation. Now it is finished beautifully. Very impressive. Recommended to look at this.
Sulemaniye. worth it with great history, great mosaics and a true wonder
Standing alone on the summit on Istanbul. An astounding open space in contrast to the somewhat constricted space in the Blue Mosque

Might be most beautiful mosque in Istanbul. May people including myself think Suleman mosque is more beautiful that Blue Mosque. It is hard to explain but you will definitely recognize the difference in architecture when you are there.
The Best Ottoman Monument. The peace which I felt inside in a so big place is very relaxing.
Not so blue. Nice mosque, not so blue as it called(if you don't know that it is called blue and they ask what color looks like it is diificult to say blue, even in sunshine weather).
The hearts skips a beat when you are inside. the place is very holy and you feel how you are close to god greatness. the lights and the people praying looked amazing.

Awe-inspiring. It is truly beautiful. Be aware of the entry times for tourists. These are posted by the tourist entrance at the side. It is astonishing how many tourists behave disrespectfully inside, despite all the information about what not to do in the mosque.
Sultan's extravaganza. Kept in very good condition; biggest mosque built in Istanbul
magnifiecnt view. ıt was amazing with its speacil tiles and great view from golden horn. speacially you shall watch ıt by night from galata bridge
Wonderful. Simply wonderful, cannot loose it. The athmosfere is great and the building really marvellous
Great view. It is the biggest mosque in the city, it is really nicely decorated and there is a magnificient view over the city from its terrace.
Magnificent. It is the most subdued in decor and material, but has the strongest impression due to its quiet grandeur. Once you enter, you are transferred to a state of quiet contemplation and awe.

I'll keep it brief.... It's worthwhile to show some modesty and respect and bring a headscarf and don't wear a skirt. It's a historic place with it's own rules. As a man, when I walk into a room, I take off my hat. That does not mean that I respect myself less, by showing due respect...
Impressive, beautiful mosque. Not as well-known as Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque, this is far more impressive. It is in a remarkably good condition thanks to a restoration in 2010.
Most beautiful mosque ever seen.. It's entire location, atmosfere, splendid architecture.
Great piece of architecture. For those who are looking for real great piece of muslim architecture. For those who want to see why it is also a part of belief

Suleymaniye. A stunning mosque, with great views over Istanbul at the back of the mosque. Only disappointment was that the tombs were closed when I visited in Dec 2011 - looked like maintenance work was being done.
Beautiful and enormous Mosque. You must visit this beautiful and enormous Mosque, where you can find a very quiet environment.
Unforgetable. Don't miss it.Does not matter wich religion you are belonging to.
The mosque in Istanbul. This is the main spot in the Istanbul skyline and historically perhaps the most imporant mosque in Istanbul. Walk around and see the social institutions and the mausoleum.

Inpressive. As all mosque you vist there is a protocol to follow this mosque is no different from any other but the building is quite inpressive with its minuet`s and outer grounds ,inside archtecture was also impressive also the size
A terrific site.. I was pleased to see that instead of having to take off your shoes, you could don plastic covers to walk around. This was appreciated as the weather was cold.
serene.. Almost felt very much at peace .. a grand mosque and very picturesque.. will appeal to all.. Must see!

Impressive!. The interiors are amazing and very historic. It is impressive that they have been able to maintain it so well.
Best time to go is between the noon and mid-day prayers, which would be like between 4pm to a little earlier than sunset.

Worth the UpUpUp-Hill Walk. Easily rivals Hagia and Blue as a Mosque to be seen. Sinan's masterpiece (16th century architect). Unfortunately when we were there the tomb area was closed but that would have just added to our visit.
BONUS - easy downhill walk to the Grand Bazaar.
Beautifull view to Bosporus. Mosque is a very nice but the most attractive place there is a beautiful view to Bosporus. it is really amazing.
Big!. And inviting. We were welcomed in every mosque we sought out. This is the big one in Istanbul. Just lovely.

Better than the Blue Mosque. A bit of a hike from the Blue Mosque, this is definitely worth the trip. Without the low rumble of a crowd and people constantly running into you, you're able to truly enjoy the serene atmosphere of this Mosque. The architecture is incredible and the view of the city just outside is amazing around sunset. Put this on your list of must-see in Istanbul!

Beautifully Impressive. Very high pedestrian traffic into and around the Mosque, and with reason - everyone should see this impressive site! Incredibly ornate inside, and plastic bags are provided for you to carry your shoes in when you remove them on entry. Long skirts are provided for women to wear if their clothing is not quite modest enough, but women are not expected to cover their hair on entry. Still in use as a place of worship, so avoid prayer time visits if you want to go inside and/or take pictures.
Definitely worth a visit. A beautiful calm place where there is no pressure to pay, wear a headscarf (though I did out of respect) and I genuinely enjoyed my visit.
Small compared with the other mosques but interesting. Mosque is near the Spice Bazaar. The mosque is intimate and easier to absorb the surroundings.

Most Beautiful Mosque. The mosque were erected during reigning of sultan Suleyman the Magnificent. And really, it is the most magnificent mosque in Istanbul built by sultan's architect Sinan (the tombs of Syleyman and Sinan you will find around the mosque as well as Suleyman's wife Roksolana (Haseki Hurem) who was Ukrainian and brought to Istanbul as a slave.When you come in the mosque you will got dizzy because of the height of the сonstruction. To central dome is about 70 m above the ground.
Gorgeous. One of many beautiful mosques in the area, that you need to check out.

Stunning. This is a bit apart from the Sultanahmet district, so may get missed by some travelers, which would truly be a shame. A local said that while the Blue Mosque is favored by foreigners, this mosque is the favorite of Turkish people. The dimensions are hard to fathom until you step inside. We happened to be there during evening prayer time, and were very quiet & stayed in back. It was an amazing experience, very humbling, really. Don't miss it!
great mosque. Its intresting to make walk to the mosque. You will see on the walk to there intrestings and beatyfull yhing. Do it
Amazing. Best time to go is night time...everything is lit up beautifully!
Huge. It is not as famous as other mosques but it is so huge and impressive you should go and visit it also at night, to see the outer lights
Great Sinan. Wonderful architecture. You can see a big difference from the Blu Mosque. Inspired architect. You can feel that it is a spiritual place.
Nice one. Nice mosque, another huge mosque in Istanbul, similar to Blue Mosque
Beautiful Mosque. Another absolutely beautiful building. A must see on your trip.
A humbling experience. Not quite the draw for tourists as the Blue Mosque, but in some ways a more reflective and interesting experience. Excellent views from the grounds.

Worth the walk. We walked up from the Spice Bazaar, and though it is a bit of a walk, there's all kinds of interesting streets to explore along the way. You can see the structure from a great distance, so it's not too hard to find.We arrived at noon prayers, and sat outside on the benches and just enjoyed the peace and quiet. There are many cats who live on the grounds, and it's fun to watch them play and sleep and do the things cats do.The courtyard and interior were open, as was the view over the old kitchens, which looks out over the Bosphorus. Unfortunately, the graveyard and burial places were still closed for renovation.The mosque is very beautiful, and has a lighter interior than other mosques, which gives it a more ethereal feeling. Definitely worth a visit and stroll around the grounds.

JUst complted restoration, i have been to this cami 3 times now, always has been closed. This trip the cami was open! beautifuly done, gorgeous colors . Very large cami next to the blue mosque in size. Not location. The outdoor yard is now closed for restoration, but i saw that last year, it has many tombstones and graves, very interesting to see.
Learn the history of the architect. Amazing building and the personal History of the architect is sad, so it makes the stories in the tiles and the building very interesting.

WOW!. The atmosphere at this mosque was amazing. The grounds were peaceful and beautiful, providing a fantastic view of Istanbul below (it sits on a hill). The inside was even more breathtaking. There were fewer tourists, allowing you to relax and soak in the atmosphere after taking photos. The lighting in the Suleymaniye Mosque was very cool too. Highly recommend making this a stop!

Loved the architecture. We got there just before evening prayer. The mosque and its surrounding building form an impressive complex. The architecture is fantastic and the atmosphere here was more authentic. Few tourists and many locals who came to pray. It's a fantastic place to watch Turkish family life unfold, as many of the worshippers are families that after the prayer stop by one of the outdoor cafes for a tea or a bite to eat. We did the same and just sat and enjoyed watching people go by their daily activities.
It's open again!. Beautiful mosque, I believe better than the Blue Mosque. Only disappointment, the mosoleums of Suleyman and Roxelana werer closed (:}(>

Magnificant!. A stunningly beautiful building and large grounds area. There is also a great little restaurant across the street from it, serving delicious rice, beans and soups. It's a limited menu but with great results. We ate there before going to the Mosque and saw many Turks doing the same. The tiny restaurant is called "Erzincanli" and was recommended to us by our wonderful Istanbul hotel, Hotel Basileus.

Beautifully understated. We went to both the Blue Mosque and this one and though the Blue Mosque may be more colorful and elaborate I really recommend that you visit this one especially if you only have time to visit 1 of them. It is beautiful and because it is not as well known as the Blue Mosque it was much quieter and could be enjoyed much more. Having your own tour guide is very helpful to really appreciate it. Loved it.
Magnificent!. This was much less crowded than the Blue Mosque and so afforded a more spiritual experience. The surrounding grounds are lovely and the restaurant is beautiful.
Incredible!. A must see....the grounds are wonderful and the mosque unbelievably beautiful...Great coffee near by!
Loved this. Worth the walk up the hill! A beautiful, light filled and uncrowded mosque. Loved the grave yard. Include the original Turkish bath just around the corner - a great experience!
beautiful mosque. It is similer to blue mosque but good location because it is close to grand bazar so you can visit both in one trip.

Classically stunning mosque and grounds. The mosque has just recently reopened after a major renovation. it is located within the walls of a beautifully landscaped garden (magestic cypress trees) that also contains an old cemetery. The interiors of the mosque are of a restrained blue and pinkish tiles, lush carpets, intricately carved trellis work. Everything about the newly refurbished mosque speaks to a restrained, classical and simple but regal place of worship. The interiors, the well kept gardens and cemetery are beyond compare. One cannot help but feel spiritual. Even the public washrooms are fantastically done. This is my favorite of all the mosques we visited in Istanbul. A definite MUST VISIT.

WOW! Finally restoured. II was in Istanbul April 2009 and the mosque was closed due to restoration. I don't know what it looked like before, but it sure looks better than the Blue Mosque of the Hayia Sophia.
Newly restored. Not as crowded as the Blue Mosque, peaceful atmosphere

Must see if you have time. The inside is brighter than the Blue (Sultan Ahmed) Mosque. The surrounding area is really nice. Another free attraction, Valens Aqueduct, is within walking distance. But if your time is limited, then I would just stick with Blue Mosque which is very close Hagia Sophia, Topkapi palace, and Istanbul Archaeology Museum.
So peacful and so big. Do not need to be a muslim. Take of your shoes and sit down. Close your eyes for five minutes and thank to all beauties of life.
Don't miss this one. Really our favorite of the mosques - so serene and historic
A Mosque with History. This mosque is the biggest mosque in Istanbul. You would like the architecture

Well worth a visit. Although not as spectacular as the Sultan Ahmed (Blue) Mosque, this was just as intricate in detail and well worth a visit. Ladies...don't forget to bring a headscarf as a mark of respect...we were astounded that some tourists simply walked around in shorts with uncovered heads despite the please from tour guides and signs. Some people have no respect for other cultures!

Probably the most beautiful of Istanbul's mosques!. Probably the most beautiful mosque that is included in the main attractions and monuments of the city. If one doesn't stay in Istanbul for a long time, I would suggest visiting this mosque rather than any other.

Best Mosque in Istanbul. After seeing the Blue Mosque, we didn't know what to expect. We were gobsmacked. The domes, the paintings, the detals were amazing. We visited twice and were lucky enough on our second vist to witness an actual prayer session. If you can only visit one mosque in Istanbul, skip the Blue Mosque and visit Suleymaniye
Interesting. Biggest mosque in Istanbul. Not as fabulous as Blue Mosque. Tomb of Sueyman the Magnificent (one of the main sights) was closed

Like it better than the Blue Mosque. Arrived during late afternoon prayers so we had to wait in the lovely courtyard area. There is a garden area and cemetery worth visiting. The interior of the mosque seems more serene than the Blue Mosque. Colors are more muted but the archetecture and decor are so stunning.
A must see.. Spectacular and a must see for those visiting Istanbul

Suleyman the Magnificent's magnificent mosque. Designed by Sinan, the remarkable Imperial Architect, this mosque reopened recently after a thorough multi-year renovation. It is light, inspiring, a marvelous blend of tiles, painted cellings, harmonious colours and much more. Beautiful domes, amazingly light and airy for a massive structure. A tour de force. Definitely go.

Smaller, but more pleasant and less touristy than the Blue Mosque.. We had a very nice experience by the sunset in this Mosque. It is situated on the top of a hill at the old town and both the surroundings and the Mosque were not so crowded by that time. Some of the locals prayed and washed their hands and feet, while the colors of the outside of the Mosque changed. The sound of that kind of music used to call the muslims was very pleasant and the inside of the mosque was very beautiful and had a positive atmosphere.

Nice place for a picnic!. This mosque has a nice, quiet, park-like setting. There were a couple people sitting and having a picnic in the surrounding grounds. It is a lovely setting. Nearby are some gift shops and a couple restaurants - try the Corba! This mosque is free to visit.

Wonderful Place!!. this place was just stunning!!! i mean i could hardly believe my eyes on how beautiful and high the place was!! the paintings are just beautiful and you can have a try at the wishing pillar! wonderful place that you must definitely see!
Worth the visit. It's definitely quieter to visit here than the Blue Mosque or Aya Sophia. And it's beautiful condition.
A good working mosque.. A much better mosque than the blue mosque,les hype more style and authanticity.
Suleymaniye Mosque. Another great place to visit. Leave time to see it's worth a trip.
The most beautiful Mosque. Gorgeous, quiet and not highly toured unlike the Blue Mosque. Seemed more like a house of prayer.

One of the greatest mosques in Istanbul. This has been recently renovated and it looks wonderful; you can also visit the tomb of Suleiman the magnificient in the ground of the mosque; the views from here is wonderful.
to me, the most beautiful Istanbul mosque. a real, working mosque, but friendly to visitors and not too crowded

Incredible mosque in use. The Suleymaniye Mosque provided an authetic look at a mosque used for prayer and worship, instead of tourist visits. The dress code is strictly enforced as well as the request of no talking. My favorite mosque in Istanbul.
Most Beautiful Mosque. This is the most spectacular mosque in Istanbul. A must see.

The highest mosque I ever seen. The mosque were erected during reigning of sultan Suleyman the Magnificent. And really, it is the most magnificent mosque in Istanbul built by sultan's architect Sinan (the tombs of Syleyman and Sinan you will find around the mosque as well as Suleyman's wife Roksolana (Haseki Hurem) who was Ukrainian and brought to Istanbul as a slave.When you come in the mosque you will got dizzy because of the height of the сonstruction. To central dome is about 70 m above the ground.

Beautiful Mosque. This mosque is beautiful and also a very busy place. We visited on a Friday at worship time, so we had to wait until prayers were over to visit, but the prayers were very beautiful to listen to and the people watching was fantastic. Very peaceful place. If you are a woman, don't forget to take a scarf and slip on shoes will also come in handy to visit mosques as you have to take them off before you enter. Rugs and tiles are beautiful.
very nice. blue mosque is more impressive, but still very nice and big.
Suleymaniye Mosque. Although I'm not Muslim, I have to give credit to the architects and artists who decorated this masjid. It's beautiful and is a must see for anyone.

Renovations.... As a scholar of Ottoman art, one of the wonders I wanted to see was the Suleymaniye. Unfortunately, it was under renovations while I was there, and I was only able to see the outside. This is a problem with a lot of mosques and historical buildings in Istanbul, so you should check the status of the projects before planning a trip to specific sites.
Gorgeous. There are many mosques and they really show mans desire to serve God.

Favourite mosque!. Not religious at all but this was a very nice mosque inside, even more so than the Sultanahmet we felt. As it's on a hill it's a little harder to get to but it's worth it. They had a graveyard there but it was closed to public. A definite to put on your to-see list!
A fantastic contrast in mosque decoration.. After visiting the Blue Mosque, you must experience this one for its contrasting decor, more geometric but still superb.
Master Piece. The architecture is just beautiful, the color combinations the scale the light the ventilation the caligraphy all were breathtaking. I am lucky to have seen it in my life.

Simply SPECTACULAR! My favorite in Istanbul...it's BREATH-TAKING. This mosque was my favorite mosque in all of Istanbul! This is a HUGEmosque, similar in size to the Blue Mosque. I know it's not as famousas the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sophia, but I thought it was the prettiestof the three. The light pastel colors were simply breath-taking. Icannot tell you gorgeous this mosque is on the inside, it's simplySPECTACULAR. I did pray in this mosque and I felt special to do so.The attention to detail is amazing. There is so much work andcraftsmanship everywhere. This mosque looks brand new! It was restoredabsolutely perfectly. Visiting this mosque was one of the highlightsof my trip.This mosque is a little farther away and on a big hill, so it's a niceuphill walk. But because it is farther away, it is not crowded at all! It was practically empty when we went. I would not suggest taking acab either up or down this hill to get here because there is sooo muchtraffic, you'll just be sitting at a standstill while the meter runsup. We tried to take a cab back down, but the cabbie was honest andsaid it's not a good idea. When a cabbie turns you down for a big fareand tells you it's not worth it cause it will cost a lot, he's gottabe right!Anyways, the cemetary and tombs were closed when we went and so we hadto miss those. They had also closed off the section which would giveyou the best view of the city from the courtyard. However, thecourtyard is very pretty and it was nice and windy and just gorgeousto walk around in. Tip: the vendors outside the courtyard sell pashminascheaper than the Grand Bazaar does--so pick them up here. We foundthat similar pashminas were almost double at the bazaar.

mosque on a grand scale!. Not as decorated as some of the other mosques in Istanbul. Graveyard was not open; many disappointed visitors were trying to catch glimpses of what was within the walls. Nice garden areas, though in need of some clean-up.

Very beautiful. Of course you must visit the Blue Mosque but do not miss this one. It is even mor beautiful with less crowds and views to the water. the lighting system is much less intrusive and makes for wonderful photos. Don't miss the small Rustem Pasha Mosque near by...both near to the Spice Market

Istanbul's No.1 Mosque. To me this was the most beautiful Mosque in Istanbul and i have seen so many, it's very distinctive with its style and art ... just sit there and watch its beauty reveal itself ... a good thing is that it's never as crowded as the blue Mosque or Hagia Sofia ... i left this Mosque with much peace of mind and tranqulity

Exquisite and grand mosque. Don't miss this beautiful temple, which is quite calmer (and in my opinion grander) than the Blue Mosque. You can access the mosque climbing from Eminonu, do stop by the Rustem Pasa mosque on the way (and the Hamami if you're into it); or (easier path) from Beyazit and the University. Mind the prayer hours, because there is little around to pass the time while you wait.

See both Suleymaniye Mosque and the Blue Mosque. We saw Suleymaniye Mosque before we saw the Blue Mosque. Both make the visitor feel lighter than air...but Suleymaniye has far fewer visitors so you can also get a sense of peace and wonder.... Suleymaniye Mosque can be difficult to find. We walked from the transport station through a fascinating commercial district...it was a great adventure

Worth a Visit. This mosque is a long walk away from the main tourist areas of Sultanamhet but is worth a visit. It has the same architect as the Blue Mosque, Sinan and is just as beautiful but is much less crowded. The buildings surrounding the mosque courtyard are interesting as is the nearby cemetery. You will be able to get a better appreciation of the interior spaces because of the lack of crowds compared to the Blue Mosque
Just gorgeous!. Beautiful mosque with fewer crowds than the rest. Some serious renovations going on at places so the whole complex can't be explored but still worth a visit.

So far, my favourite mosque.. Even if it's smaller than the blue mosque, I find it much more beautiful. It's illuminated inside with lights and sunlights which creates a relaxing atmosphere. Beautiful decorations.

Best of them all. After visiting the Aya Sofia, and the Blue Mosque, we thought we had seen the greatest mosques in Istanbul. While there are several others worthy of a visit, the large Suleymaniye mosque was our favorite, for the beautiful interior, and more peaceful location. Add it to your 2nd day list!

Definitely worth a visit. Last time we were in Istanbul this masterwork by Sinan was closed for restoration but we were just there for a day in March and we were able to finally see it now that the restoration is complete. Yes, it is by the same architect who created the Blue Mosque (among others) so there are some similar design elements, but it is it is definitely is own mosque. And very beautiful. Also check out Sinan's tomb in the cemetery next door.

Amazing mosquee. Thé suleymane mosquée finds itself on the summit of a hill. It is very nice to be a bit far from the commercants who want to sell you anything all the day. So this mosquée is beautiful but I regret that it looks like thé blue mosquée. The outside is very nice but a part was under restauration... Unfortunately there is nothing to put easily your shoes again at the exit of the monument :)

Wonderful Piece of Architecture and History. I visited the Suleymaniye Mosque in December 2010 and it was finally opened after a renovation. The easiest way to walk there is from Grand Bazaar and Beyazit Square. Suleymaniye Mosque, built in the 16th century, is a beautiful piece of architecture and history, an endowement of sultan Suleyman the Magnificent and a work of legendary Mimar Sinan. An Istanbul landmark that shoudn't be missed. Graveyard behind the mosque with the tombs of Suleyman and his wife Roxelana is now closed for restauration, and also a part of the mosque yard. Fortunately, it's possible to enjoy the magnificent interior and to walk around the mosque complex. Near the mosque is also the tomb of the great Mimar Sinan.The mosque is closed during the prayer times. In between, you should deffinitely go and see it although it’s a little up the hill. I like it much more than the Blue Mosque.A view from Eminonu, with Suleymaniye Mosque raising above the city is also wonderful.

Beautiful mosque on top of a hill. It's quite an effort to get to it because it is located on top a very high hill. Second, it's currently on works so you can't visit the inside, only the surroundings and the tomb of the sultan inside. Despite all this, it's a magnificent building, visible from all Istanbul and possibly bigger than the Blue Mosque. The surroundings are not very interesting, there's a shop and a bar on the outside, so it's up to you to go up there to see, barely nothing, it's much nicer to see it from the Galata Tower.

Steep climb to the mosque but worth it. Although this mosque was part closed for renovations when we visited last June, I still rank it as one of my best experiences in Istanbul. It was virtually desolate when we arrived. The gardens/cemetery are simply beautiful with roses planted everywhere and the sun streaming through. The cats that live there are sweet and very friendly. We took some simply divine pictures by walking around the grounds. The area outside is equally relaxing with some lovely little alfresco cafe's serving Turkish coffee and soothing music without the vicious harassment that you get in areas frequented by tourists. If you are looking for something cultural but relaxing then visit this site whilst renovations are ongoing. You won't be dissappointed.

Great Architecture - However Closed for Renovation. I walked from the Grand Bazaar to the Suleymaniye Mosque and it was worth it despite the fact that you can see nothing of the great interiror which is undergoing extensive renovations. The grave of Suleyman the magnificent though makes it worth the visit. The grave of Roxelana though smaller in comparison is also interesting. From the Grand Bazaar it is quite a hike uphill, though short it is very steep.

Still Under Renovation. The mosque, while sitting on perhaps the best site in the city and is extremely impressive from the exterior, is still under extensive renovation. That in itself is not the reason to avoid it for it does have a very nice graveyard which is open and free to explore.No, the reason to avoid it is the very persistent gentleman outside 'gently' reminding visitors to cough up a donation. He was too persistent and annoying hitting you both going in and and coming out. It left a bitter taste. Nothing of the interior, nothing of the courtyard can be seen so until the renovation is over, skip it.

As of December 2008 is almost completely closed for renovation--skip it. I visited in late December of 2008 and the mosque is almost completely closed for renovations. It was unclear when the renovation work would be finished, but it appeared to be pretty extensive. You can still go in a little side part of the mosque, but there is really nothing to see there. Skip it until the restoration work is complete.

Correction. This note is to correct what I am seeing on this page about the Suleymaniye Mosque. It is indeed one of the most beautiful mosques of Istanbul and it was indeed built by the great Sinan. But he has not built Hagia Sophia! While Sinan worked long after the fall of constantinople (1453) Hagia Sophia was built around 800 c.e.
